Title: Please read this before posting about feeling suicidal.
Text:
There has been an increase in the number of posts of individuals who are feeling suicidal. And to be perfectly honest, most of us have been isolated, scared, lonely, and there’s a lot of uncertainty in the world due to COVID.

Unfortunately, most of us in this community are not trained to handle mental health crises. While I and a handful of others are licensed professionals, an anonymous internet forum is not the best place to really provide the correct amount of help and support you need.

That being said, I’m not surprised that many of us in this community are struggling. For those who are struggling, you are not alone. I may be doing well now, but I have two attempts and OCD was a huge factor.

I have never regretted being stopped.

Since you are thinking of posting for help, you won't regret stopping yourself.

So, right now everything seems dark and you don’t see a way out. That’s ok. However, I guarantee you there is a light. Your eyes just have not adjusted yet.

So what can you do in this moment when everything just seems awful.

First off, if you have a plan and you intend on carrying out that plan, I very strongly suggest going to your nearest ER. If you do not feel like you can keep yourself safe, you need to be somewhere where others can keep you safe. Psych hospitals are not wonderful places, they can be scary and frustrating. but you will be around to leave the hospital and get yourself moving in a better direction.

If you are not actively planning to suicide but the thought is very loud and prominent in your head, let's start with some basics. When’s the last time you had food or water? Actual food; something with vegetables, grains, and protein. If you can’t remember or it’s been more than 4 to 5 hours, eat something and drink some water. Your brain cannot work if it does not have fuel.

Next, are you supposed to be sleeping right now? If the answer is yes go to bed. Turn on some soothing music or ambient sounds so that you can focus on the noise and the sounds rather than ruminating about how bad you feel.

If you can’t sleep, try progressive muscle relaxation or some breathing exercises. Have your brain focus on a scene that you find relaxing such as sitting on a beach and watching the waves rolling in or sitting by a brook and listening to the water. Go through each of your five senses and visualize as well as imagine what your senses would be feeling if you were in that space.

If you’re hydrated, fed, and properly rested, ask yourself these questions when is the last time you talked to an actual human being? And I do mean talking as in heard their actual voice. Phone calls count for this one. If it’s been a while. Call someone. It doesn’t matter who, just talk to an actual human being.

Go outside. Get in nature. This actually has research behind it. There is a bacteria or chemical in soil that also happens to be in the air that has mood boosting properties. There are literally countries where doctors will prescribe going for a walk in the woods to their patients.

When is the last time you did something creative? If depression and obsessive-compulsive disorder have gotten in the way of doing creative things that you love, pull out that sketchbook or that camera and just start doing things.

When’s the last time you did something kind for another human being? This may just be me as a social worker, but doing things for others, helps me feel better. So figure out a place you can volunteer and go do it.

When is the last time that you did something pleasurable just for pleasure's sake? Read a book take a bath. You will have to force yourself to do something but that’s OK.

You have worth and you can get through this. Like I said I have had two attempts and now I am a licensed social worker. Things do get better, you just have to get through the dark stuff first.

You will be ok and you can make it through this.

We are all rooting for you.

https://www.supportiv.com/tools/international-resources-crisis-and-warmlines

Title: Reassurance seeking and providing: Rules of this subreddit and other information
Text:
There has been some confusion regarding reassurance seeking and providing in this subreddit.

**Reassurance seeking** (a person asking for reassurance) is **allowed only if it is limited** — **no repeated seeking of reassurance**.

**Reassurance providing** (a person giving reassurance) is **not allowed**.

## What constitutes reassurance providing?

Before commenting on a reassurance-seeking question, answer to yourself this question: Are you **directly** answering what the person is asking, and is the answer meant to cause the person to feel better?

**If the answer leads towards a "yes", refrain from commenting.**

## How should I comment on reassurance-seeking questions then?

The issue concerned in reassurance-seeking questions is the emotional obsessive distress that is occurring in the moment, **not the question itself**.

When you answer those reassurance-seeking questions to quell the person's emotional obsessive distress, **it's an act of providing emotional comfort to the person** — even if you don't have such explicit intention in mind — rather than an act of providing knowledge.

The person just wants to know they are "fine" in relation to the obsessive question/thought. **The answer itself is irrelevant** — that's why we don't answer questions of a reassurance-seeking nature directly.

**You can comment in any way you want — even providing encouragement and hope — but refrain from addressing the reassurance-seeking question itself.**

## What if the reassurance-seeking question turns out to be true?

Consider this question: What if the reassurance-seeking question didn't even occur in the first place? What then?

We can go round and round with more "what-ifs", but it circles back to the fact that reality is uncertain, and will always be uncertain. **That is why the acceptance of uncertainty is crucial to recovery.**

## Does that mean the reassurance-seeking question is totally invalid? Because I had a question that was based on reality.

Take note that in the context of OCD, the issue rests with how a person is dealing with the issues, **and not so much the issues themselves**.

**The issues can be entirely valid**, but what we are dealing with here — especially with reassurance — is **how we respond** to such issues.

**Separate the reassurance part — the emotional comfort part — from the issues themselves.**

## All of this is not true. My therapist taught me in the beginning of therapy that these thoughts are not true, and then I got better.

It's important to understand the intent and purpose of each and every information provided.

When a person with OCD is beginning to learn about OCD, they can be taught, for example, that the obsessive thoughts do not reflect on their true character.

The intent and purpose of that example information is **cognitive-based** — to educate the person — and that helps to, subsequently, **be followed up by ERP, which is behavioural-based** — hence **cognitive-behavioural therapy** (of which ERP is a part of).

When a person seeks reassurance, it is mostly solely behavioural: **the concern here is to quell the emotional obsessive distress** — take that emotional obsessive distress away, and the reassurance-seeking question suddenly becomes largely irrelevant and of less urgency.

## This is so un-compassionate. Are we seriously going to let these people suffer?

Providing reassurance doesn't really help the person not suffer either — the way out of that suffering is through the proper therapy and treatment, **and providing reassurance to the person only interferes with this process**.

Consider as well that if reassurance is provided to the person, where an outcome is guaranteed to the person ("You won't be this! I guarantee you!").

**What if the reassurance turns out to be false? What happens then? How much more distressful would the person be (given that they would've trusted the reassurance to keep them safe, only now for their entire world to fall apart)?**

Before considering that not providing reassurance is un-compassionate, perhaps it's also wise to consider what providing reassurance can lead to as well.

The reality will always be uncertain, as it is. There is no such solution that guarantees the person won't suffer, but we can at least minimise the suffering **by doing what is helpful towards the person** (especially in terms of the therapy and treatment) — and that doesn't always necessarily entail making the person feel better in the moment.

Title: Accidentally forgetting what you were obsessing about and feeling good for one short moment?
Text:
I am very new to the whole ocd thing. I’ve been in therapy for around 9 months  and my therapist and I are slowly realizing that I might have ocd instead of previously assumed general anxiety. Therefore I would like to know if any of you experience this:
I spend most of my day obsessing over things in thoughts. So I constantly think about everything I still need to do, past situations, etc. and my brain usually picks one thing to make me feel bad that I then think about for a long time. If I get suddenly interrupted and distracted tho, sometimes I forget what I was thinking about and feel like a weight has been lifted off me. That feeling only lasts a second tho, because I can hear myself think „nah hold on, what were we stressed about, I know we were worrying about something“ and before I even realize it, I’m back at obsessing over the thing I was thinking about. 
Does this sound like a familiar situation to any of you?

Title: Has your OCD made you "thankful" at times?
Text: First off, in no way am I condoning the way OCD makes us think, but I just want to know if anyone else has experienced this too? I suffer from lots of different types of OCD, mostly contamination. And I do hate OCD with a passion, but at times I’ve caught myself saying "thank you OCD" for "saving me" from a situation I was afraid would happen if I didn’t do this compulsion, and sometimes it has. For example, I’ve checked for stains on my clothes before and one time I did, I wore another shirt bevause of it, and in that way I was thankful, because if I hadn’t, I felt like the stain would still be there. I realize this is a compulsion, but that fear creeps in and takes over. So has anyone had a moment where "OCD saved them" from a fear coming true?

Title: Terrified of being cancelled
Text:
Hey everyone,

I'm 23 and have been super scared of being cancelled ever since I was fired from a temp job when I was 19 (it was a misunderstanding, I said/did some things that people took as offensive but I truly don't know how it could be - I've obsessed for hours and hours over whether I was in the wrong or not, I would never want to hurt or offend people, but I'm trying to stop overanalyzing the incident because it's just another obsession/OCD thing. Again, please don't think I'm a terrible person, lol).

I'm starting my career, as I graduated from college, and I really want to be a political journalist/theorist. Now, this is the worst job ever for someone with an intense fear of being cancelled, because politics is so inherently controversial it just feels like someone is inevitably going to try to ruin my life even if I only have good intentions. The problem is that a lot of people know about this incident where I was fired, and a lot of them have really different politics than me - I'm so scared they're going to bring it up somehow, or report it to another employer, or something. And people reassuring me, saying "cancellation doesn't happen or is unlikely," just...doesn't help, because I feel like I was already cancelled when I was fired - or, even worse, I was actually in the wrong and did/said bad stuff, in which case I'd feel super guilty because I hurt people and the people looking to cancel me would actually have legitimate reason to cancel me. And now I'm going through all the things I've ever said or done that could be portrayed in a really bad way, or were actually bad, and mistakes I've made, and I'm just convinced I'm on borrowed time before I get booted out of public life - which I would want to be in for my job - entirely, or ostracized from everyone I know and will ever meet.

Idk. I'm just super freaked out, and it's stopping me from pursuing my career and dreams.

Title: Doesn’t OCD seem so pointless?
Text: I’m sure others here have thought this before or have had moments of “clarity” with the disorder and it’s nonsense. There’s just times where I’ll stop in my car and think “why the fuck am I even worrying about (insert your theme)?” There’s just times I’ll realize it just doesn’t make sense, I personally struggle with HOCD terribly, for 4.5 years, and I find it mind boggling that I’ve let the thoughts/fears/obsessions over rather I’m gay, straight, bi, etc ruin my life, it JUST DOESNT MAKE SENSE!!!! I’ve figured by now my mind would’ve been bored by it, but it seems like it just continues to grow stronger even with therapy, meds. Gahhh. Over it. I hate this disease. I wish I could hold on to those moments of clarity and just freeze that feeling and run with it. Praying for you all.

Title: Typing Anxiety?
Text: Does anybody have this type of OCD involving fear of keyboards? Do you ever find yourself typing a response to somebody on social media and then have this compulsion to keep editing the post over and over because you have this fear you might type something incorrect or you’ll say some embarrassing secret about yourself or somebody else? This is something I’ve experienced for more than a decade. Sometimes I’ll post something and then quickly delete it. Or I’ll get this urge to go back and edit it over and over even if I’m just typing the same thing. Let me know if this is something you or anybody you know has experienced.

Title: Sexual ocd, please help
Text:
NSFW. It all started when I was 16, full blown porn addict day in and day out. I wasn’t watching weird shit per say but definitely really hardcore pornography. I always question if I could’ve prevented this from happening to my brain if I didn’t watch porn, but the day my ocd onset was also the same day I suffered a really traumatic event that triggered my PTSD (non sexual) I’m not sure which one caused it but I’ve always leaned more towards porn induced because it makes sense. I’ve been suffering for 4 years and it has been a living hell. I’ve been on multiple Ssri medications and been in CBT therapy (hard to find access to a ERP therapist) I also never quit porn until a few months ago, it’s something I’ve always struggled with on top of this bullshit. I have sexual intrusive thoughts of all kinds of shit, mostly HOCD though. I know who I am and who I’m emotionally attracted to but it causes me to irrationally question 24/7. 
I’ve been in a couple relationships since this started and I have had times where I was doing great but other times where its just so fucking debilitating. I have suicidal thoughts and feel so worthless because of it, I feel like a joke. Dealing with grief/personal hardship in my life has made it much worse. I isolate most the time which I know isn’t good for me but I can’t bear to deal with these thoughts around people I love and care about. 
To anyone out there who has dealt with this pos disorder, did you ever conquer it? How are you now? Is there hope

I might be seeking reassurance but fuck I just want to talk to people who have dealt with the same thing I have.

Title: How do you accept things?
Text:
This is something I’m really struggling with. How do you sit with and accept the thoughts/feelings? Like sometimes I’m not sure if I am supposed to basically relax myself and then just whatever horrible thing it throws at me genuinely feel like I’m accepting the thought/feeling and just not acting on it? Even though it feels risky? Or so I mockingly agree with it? What if it feels like there’s a real risk? I’m scared to accept it because sometimes when I try it feels like I’m going to do it. But then I don’t. But will those feelings go away? I’d really like my life and my feelings back and I know fighting with it is just going to keep them away. 

Edit: I just realized how to describe it in a clearer way. Mockingly accepting it feels like I’m fighting to keep my head above water and keep the “real” me resisting it. Accepting it feels like I’m actually accepting it - just not acting on it. And I’m afraid that’s dangerous because it’s close to being real.

Title: i have done something horrible and unfortunately unforgivable
Text:
last night i got triggered by something regarding my ocd theme (zocd) and i desperately felt the need to check that it was not applicable to me. it was a post regarding someone stating that they felt a false attraction when they cat brushed their tail against their private area. they were basically over their cat

i was so worried that was my case and i desperately wanted to check that it wasn’t true. so, i brought my cat into my room and i sat down on the edge of my bed and put him on his back on my legs (like parents do with babies). its something i have always done with him because he is my baby and i like doing that. and then, i literally started crying, i was crying a river and it was horrible. i was so distressed and i was so panicked. he got off my lap and went around the room, and then came back to me and sat next to me, on my arm and looked in a very concerning way at me. after that he went on the other side and sat next to me trying to go to sleep

at this point i was feeling horrible and just so disgusting and i decided to go on with my night routine. before i left the room, i took him in my lap one last time and i hugged him and cried over him because i just felt so fucking horrible. i kissed him and after that i said “no, i wont check” and i left the room with him to put him back in his sleeping place

im just so exhausted, i thought about this all day long. i honestly don’t even remember thinking about checking anymore because i just started crying but i feel like i acted on my thought and i hurt him. i don’t want to hurt him, i love him so much. nothing happened, his tail didn’t even reach that part and i didn’t want it to, i just had him on his back on my legs and i was petting him. i feel disgusting, why did i do that? 

please i would really need some help, anything, i want some guidance on how to deal with this, not necessarily reassurance. i just feel disgusting

Title: Starting Therapy today
Text:
I have been dealing with OCD for at least 4 years but I had always been ashamed to talk about them, about 2 years ago I managed to heal myself and control it to leave it almost null in my life, but this year I had several changes in my life that overwhelmed me and this caused a relapse with a much more severe OCD than I was used to, there have been days that I have been doing compulsions for at least 5 hours, this weekend I had perhaps the strongest crisis I have ever had and I decided to finally make decisions and letters on the matter, it is a little complex because I do not have the money to pay for a therapy but I have informed myself, read and learned a lot about this shitty disorder and today I took the courage to start doing what is necessary to destroy it, I already did it once I’ll do it again.

Later I will talk about it with my loved ones because I feel that it is an advance for me, I am ready to recover my life.

I know that there will be difficult and challenging moments but I am willing to face them, I remember a phrase that they once told me, "things are done with everything and with fear, but they are done" I prefer to face them to stay all my life thinking horrible things and doing compulsions that at the end of the day are just things in my brain

Title: Cannot wear my fav clothes anymore for a crazy reason
Text:
So I’ve noticed this got worse over the almost 4 years I’ve been taking college classes. My freshman year, and in high school before, I had always worn either skirts and tights or some sort of cute outfit. 

But increasingly I have only been able to wear black clothes and no skirts or jeans because I am afraid I am either going to pee myself or get my period. I do not have a history of peeing myself and there’s no reason this should be an issue, but I commute to school and I’m so scared that somehow my tights or pants will be ruined and I won’t be able to do anything about it.

In the last days I did wear light clothes like jeans I would spend the whole class anxious that I peed myself and was convinced when I stood up everyone would see I peed, and would even convince myself as I was leaving the classroom that people were giving shocked looks. I’d proceed to go to the bathroom and not even have to pee.

I have so many cute expensive jeans I can’t wear, so many skirts and tights. Every time I even look at them or take them out to wear before school my brain is like ARE YOU CRAZY? and it’s either the same black leggings or scream pajama pants. Even the thought of wearing anything else fills me with wild discomfort even though I would look much better and less messy if I dress the way I used to. 

I don’t know how to solve this or reason with this, but as my therapist said I was right to characterize my ocd thoughts as immune to logic. I don’t know how to get rid of this fear, I would love to dress cute again and be comfortable

It is exhausting to live this way, I am only 21

Title: What stops you from ignoring intrusive thoughts/feelings?
Text:
I will mention some of my reasons:

* This thought is much worse 
* What if I want this?
* It looks very real
* This seems like it was my thought/feeling
* I need to remember if this really happened
* I need to remember what my intentions were when this happened
* Fear of act on my thoughts

Title: Your OCD "subtype" doesn't really matter
Text: I see a growing tendency on this sub to categorize OCD into types, like pure-O or hocd. I think it's a bad idea to box yourself into specific symptoms. OCD symptoms vary, one month you may be obsessed with germs and the other with magic numbers. Don't get me wrong, knowing the specific  symptoms you have at the moment may help your therapist to provide better treatment, however the focus should be on the larger picture, the broader features like rumination, guit, anxiety, etc. That way you will be able to tackle whatever symptom or subtype you happen to develop.

Title: I am always thinking. I’m so exhausted
Text: I’m just so tired of always thinking and always worrying over the smallest things ever. I have constant intrusive thoughts, but when they finally are done flaring up, my mind just chooses the next thing to pointlessly worry about. It’s all just so stupid, so useless but yet I constantly think about these things. I’m always anxious, worried, miserable and it’s developed me to just feel so badly about myself. I always focus on the negative instead of the good, I’m so dissatisfied with everything around me, especially with myself. I hate being like this, I hate that my OCD will follow me for the rest of my life, I’m exhausted and I’ve been trying to keep up a good face towards my life, but I’ve just gotten to the point where I’m just tired of it all. I don’t know how to contain these thoughts, I just want to have one day where I’m not bombarded with these thoughts

Title: Obsession with hair
Text: This is gonna sound ridiculous, but I have absolutely frustrating obsession with my hair. I’ve always liked my hair, but in the good way. I was taking care of them, wanted them to be pretty and long. But after a while I created obsession. My hair MUST be perfectly straight cut, like the same length on every side. I’m so scared that maybe hairdresser cut it wrong and somewhere there is longer piece of hair that sticks out.. or I’m scared that something will happen to my hair that will cause damage to them. When I look at my hair, I always find something that seems wrong, so I start checking it and I could do it the whole day. I just want to live normal life like before don’t care about my hair that much. I want to know that I’m not alone with this. It’s really pointless obsession. I think I have ocd but my parents don’t believe me and don’t even try to help me so I write here. I had smaller obsessions when I was younger, I think everything started when I was 12 (now I’m 17). I really want to get rid of it

Title: If an ocd thought/theme is making me less anxious, is it accurate not ocd anymore?
Text: I don’t want anything that’s going on in my head, I can’t tell the difference between when a thought makes me feel anxious or good anymore it feels like. Everything to do with my theme makes me feel horrible and in the brief periods it’s not so bad, I end up coming out worse because new doubts appear.

Title: OCD, Sexuality, and Faith
Text:
I just started seeing a therapist trained in ERP. I live in south Alabama with extremely limited options. But I found one. I scored a 31 on the YBOC. When we were going over it I told her I had sexual orientation OCD as a kid but as an adult discovered that I am bisexual. She responded by asking if I am sure I’m bisexual or if it’s just my OCD. She said “I mean have you ever acted on it?” And my gut reaction was to feel so invalidated and sad. I had also previously told her that after growing up very Christian, I walked away from it a few years ago. She said she wondered if that was OCD too. I just found myself not trusting her and doubting her because I am in a very conservative Christian part of the country. But I’m trying to discern if I need to just try to trust her. I know those things can be related to OCD. Maybe it was just the way she asked. Like she felt pretty certain. 

Of course now it has me doubting my sexuality. My sexual orientation OCD as a kid was me being TERRIFIED that I was gay. That certain thoughts meant I was gay. I would spend a lot of time in my head rationalizing. That stopped being an issue after like high school. Then a few years out of college after leaving christian ministry, I started to discover my sexuality. I was attracted to women, their bodies. It felt exciting to me, empowering. Of course I still have fears and doubts in the back of my mind.

What are your thoughts about my therapist? Of course my brain is black and white and wants to just cut her off. But my options are limited- I would prob have to find someone virtually. I am also considering doing an intensive program because of the severity I’m experiencing right now.

Should I still be tested for ocd?

Title: Boss wants me to come in to work after I called off
Text: Woke up not feeling well and let my boss know. At my job, we’re short staffed. Told my boss firmly that I won’t be coming in today. She responds with with a thank you and asked me if there is any way I could come in, that would be great. I said thank you and I will try. Should I feel bad for planning on not coming in today at all? I’m always covering other people’s call ins and the go to person for working for staying later because they need me. What do I do if she texts me again? I cover everyone else’s sick days, like my one coworker’s last week for 3 days. My work takes advantage of people like me but calling off triggers my OCD bad. My boss’s response didn’t help and I wish she would’ve just said thank you and feel better instead of coming in later if I can.

Title: Any OCD teachers/TAs?
Text:
I know this is a super niche question but I'm having a really hard time grading student submissions because of OCD. I end up spending an hour (sometimes more) on each paper because I get worried I'm not grading fairly. I'll like go back and constantly reread and compare grades between students. I'll also reread student papers a lot to see if I miss something (I partially have to do this because I also have ADHD and do miss stuff but I know that the amount I do it is too much). 

Also, I'm a TA so I can't change the assignment structure to be more accessible to me. Any advice/experience etc is greatly appreciated.

Title: Has Modafinil worked for anyone?
Text:
Contrary to what 3 doctors have told me, each time I'm on modafinil I pay way less attention to my obsessions, and in turn, less compulsions and rituals. It's like I focus on other (more productive) things and don't pay as much attention to my obsessive thoughts.      
I feel like I'm alone on this.   
Trying to figure out if it's actually "working" for me or what.

Title: I was abused my 2 mental health professionals today
Text: I'm going back in time to tell the whole story. After my first psych ward stay (for OCD), the psychiatrist decided I should be seen every 3 to 4 weeks by a mobile team. Basically they're a therapist and a social worker who need to check on me. I've been seeing them for 1.5 year and today, they abused me after abandoning me for 5 months. They want to force me to live in a community house for some reason. I told them my OCD was much too loud at the moment for me to do that. And I told them I felt better staying at home but they decided to abuse me. They said I was an attention-seeker and I was a bad person for using my OCD "as an excuse not to listen to them". They also said I wasn't putting any effort in my recovery and said they were going to tell me psychiatrist about it. (I also have issues with my psychiatrist, I'm changing soon). I'm so done. Even mental health professionals refuse to help.

Title: I feel like my OCD is actually the voice of God
Text: I feel like this is the final boss of OCD, at least in my case. Because now it seems like that OCD voice in my head is literally God telling me to perform certain compulsions. My intrusive thoughts are now blasphemous in nature and that causes me to get so upset. I believe in God and I believed in the past as well, even if I did not grow up in a very religious household or community. I mostly had faith in a higher power like those around me did. But now I worry about stuff like sin and condemnation almost all the time. One of my biggest struggles is I feel like bad things will happen to me if I support the Lgbt community or watch anything with gay people or any sex in it, even though before I had no problem being an ally or sex positive. I have friends and family that are part of the community and now I worry they might go to hell. I do not want to go to hell myself or make God hate me but these thoughts keep getting worse and my compulsions do not feel like enough so they have escalated too. How can I fight OCD at this state, where I feel like I disrespect God everytime I try to go against it? Even writing this I feel like I am sinning and I am a bad person. This is the first time I feel like OCD might have actually beaten me.

Title: An old obsession resurfaces: hyperawareness!

I’m convinced I’m going blind because I’m super aware of all eye floaters. My heart feels like it’s gonna stop because I probably had a little too much caffeine today. I get very mild tinnitus from time to time but it feels so severe bc I’m just super aware. I feel a little weak today (maybe because I ate garbage yesterday and slept on the couch) and I’m convinced something DEADLY is afoot.

Yes I’m medicated and have a great psychiatrist but unfortunately no therapist at the moment. My previous therapist is going through cancer treatment and I’m having trouble finding anyone else I feel super comfortable with AND who has the availability I need. Ugh. Just a rough day for me.

Title: I’m trying to recover from OCD but it’s making me obsessed with the recovery itself.
Text:
First of all I’ve struggled with OCD for many years and I’ve had multiple themes. Since following Dr Greenbergs method of stopping rumination I am feeling so much better. However there is still something holding me back from full recovery and I’m not sure how to move past it. My issue is now that I know how to recover and can see the results from not ruminating that I’ve become obsessed with the recovery itself. I know this is classed as Meta OCD and believe me I have done plenty of research to understand how this works. But I still can’t seem to move past this theme no matter how hard I try.

Don’t get me wrong I am in such a better place and I am so thankful for his advice but I feel like I’m still falling back in the cycle from time to time. My issue is self talk. I constantly talk to myself all the time especially when my anxiety is bad or I feel low. I will say something along the lines of “okay you feel bad at the moment, remember this is your OCD, we need to let the feeling be and direct our attention else where, what we’re doing right now is a choice…” and this can vary depending on how much anxiety I’m experiencing and I will end up repeating this multiple times until I get that “just right” feeling. I think I have a problem with doing it “one last time” I will feel better but then there will be that tiny bit of anxiety which makes me go back and almost remind myself and recite my OCD recovery plan. If I don’t I almost feel like I won’t realise when I’m doing it again and might fall back in the cycle without realising.

Has anyone had a similar experience when following the recovery process. I feel like I should try to just not self talk but when I do that again I will feel the need to tell myself not to (which is self talk). I do feel better but I just feel like this nagging annoying feeling will never go away and don’t know how to stop myself from going back to it and repeating the same plan in my head.

I watched a video where they said act as if you’ve already recovered from OCD or if you don’t even have it. Maybe that’s what I will try next but I just wanted to see if anyone had any advice on how I could potentially stop this?

Title: Do you ever feel like you have a little hope from your rumination but it comes back right after?
Text:
Have been experiencing this lately, while being obsessed about something like some rare tshirt you got and cannot stop thinking about the hole you accidentally did on it or something like that, and for a few seconds your mind gets quite positive and makes you feel like that you don't need to be so worried or obsessed about it?

It sucks because i try to get that feeling to stay but it goes away quite fast and instantly my anxiety kicks again and i comeback to the rumination.

Title: Pure-O about having irreversible anxiety.. impossible theme to overcome?
Text:
Hi guys,

2024 marks my 10th year of intrusive thoughts. Don't worry - it hasn't been constant, I'd say 75% of those 10 years have been anxiety free. But it seems when I get stuck in the OCD loop sometimes it can last for months.

  
My theme started in 2014 when I jokingly sniffed an aerosol can, it sent me into panic and for 3 days I thought I was going to die. It then shifted to self-harm / suicide OCD where it caused me great distress for 2 years because I thought something was wrong with me. So I didn't speak up about it until I couldn't take anymore.

When I was 17, I finally broke the cycle and escaped the thoughts. However, in 2021 it came back more intense than before. I took a medication (with no side-effects) until I saw online there was a small cohort of people claiming it gave them life changing side-effects. I noticed that one of those side-effects was anxiety / panic attacks and thus, I had a panic attack that I would be permanently anxious. It took me 5 months of therapy (no meds) to overcome this theme, to this day I think I lucked out, I don't know how I did it. Maybe someone was looking out for me.

Life has been fantastic since 2021. But I made a massive mistake, unknowingly at the time. I tried cannabis for the first time 2 weeks ago on a trip to Amsterdam and it caused a massive panic attack like I have never felt before. I didn't know it could do this. I was just trying to have a typical tourist experience. Since then, my brain has convinced me that this level of anxiety is permanent - that i'm never going to get better and that every day will feel like this forever. It's more intense, there's more layers to it. I just don't know what to do. I am in constant fear that I will never go back to how I was.

Any advice on this theme is greatly appreciated.

Title: Bad flare up around period
Text: I was doing so well and feeling myself again but I’m having a hard time right now. I just got off birth control for good around probably 6 months ago which in the past being on birth control helped with OCD but not completely. I don’t plan on going back on birth control because it’s screwed me up. I haven’t been diagnosed but I’m pretty sure I have PMDD, but I have been diagnosed with OCD. Because my hormones are going back to normal/ are changing I’m getting OCD flare ups around my period again and it’s so difficult to adjust to. I get an increase in intrusive thoughts during ovulation and before and during my period. But it can last longer if I allow it to consume me enough to become depressed. This time around I’ve been a lot more anxious about everything and I’ve had a lot more heart palpitations throughout the day. My screen time also increases because it’s my way of distracting my mind, even though I don’t think it helps in the long run. It’s kind of interesting to know that my OCD is definitely a hormonal thing but it’s not easy to convince myself that it’s just hormones and my brain chemistry. I started taking a multivitamin, magnesium glycinate, ashwagandha, and I’m planning on eating better. The cold season and time change could be adding to the intensity of my symptoms. I also want to start running again but it’s been so cold outside that it’s hard to motivate myself to do so, but I know it’d help. Has any supplements or habits helped anyone during these times? I’ve been wanting to start drinking tea again if anyone has recommendations?

Title: Relationship OCD
Text: Does anybody else suffer from this?  I'm in a relationship with the love of my life and she seems to be growing as a person so much, getting closer with God, and just is becoming more serious and ethical. She also, because of her religious beliefs and previous experiences, no longer wants to have sex until we're married. I'm a very physical lover as much as I don't like admitting it. I've never believed in God and have a dark sense of humor. I have been feeling very detached from her lately and I feel like I'm just not good enough for her. We've had multiple conversations about how I'm not there for her mentally because of all the mental health issues I'm going through, but at the same time she always says she won't give up on us and always talks about getting married and having a family. I don't know what to do. I want to get better and be there for her, but at the same time I can't tell if it's real issues that I'm trying to fix or if I'm trying to change my personality for her. I'm so conflicted. I don't know what to do. I don't want to give up on us, but I don't want her to have to deal with my problems anymore. She deserves someone who's more emotionally available, more detail-oriented, a better person in general, someone who's more like her. I feel like we've fallen out of love but I don't want to give up on us. I can't tell if its us or if its me and my mental health. I don't know what to do. I just really need support and advice.

Title: Has anyone experienced their OCD putting them in a chokehold, you feel like you can’t escape and death is the only way out?
Text:
I’ve had three instance this year where my ocd had the opportunity to kill me. The questions (my case pain obsessions) snowballed into an avalanche and drove me to insanity. 

I remember being at an intersection and feeling like all these questions filled my brain to a pressure, I couldn’t ignore them anymore. “Is this pain going to be apart of me forever?” “How’re you going to figure out the source of the pain?” 

Thank God the one thing I learned from this Reddit popped in my head as a last ditch effort and that was to say to myself “this pain may or may not be forever” and accepting the pain. I maybe using these therapies wrong but man, it worked! I escaped my own hell of questions and felt free from own enslaved mind

Title: Obsession with job applications
Text:
I have had OCD for several decades.  I have what's called "Pure O".  I often obsess about morals, including telling lies.

I have been job hunting for a while now.  I left a job after only four months back in February.  The place was toxic, and I was very nearly fired because the supervisors wanted me to perform perfectly and with minimal training.  I chose to resign instead.

I have been struggling with job applications ever since this event.  I've heard conflicting things about listing short term jobs on resumes and applications.  Some recruiters say it's okay to omit short term jobs, others make it sound like you're a liar and a horrible person if you do this.  To make my life easier, I've been omitting my last job from most resumes and applications.  None of the job applications I've encountered have asked for a "complete job history", so I don't think I'd get into trouble for leaving my last job off.  However, I feel like a bad person sometimes for the omission, and that I have to shoot myself in the foot by leaving it on and discussing this nightmare workplace in an interview.

Has anyone here been in a similar situation?  If so, how did you handle it?  I really want a job, and don't want to tell potential employers that I almost got canned after less than 6 months (this would make me look bad as a candidate). I also don't want to be a "liar."  This feels like a situation of damned if I do, damned if I don't.

Title: So I’ve been wanting intimacy with my boyfriend but intrusive thoughts hold me back!
Text:
So I’ve learned more about false attraction and how it works. It’s been making ERP a lot more easier! 

So latley I’ve had a fear that I’m attracted to my friend whom I have a kind of age gap with? I haven’t talked to this person in so long but I can admit that they’re conveniently attractive.

For more context, I have a slight hand fetish for slender hands with rings which my friend has. And he’s also the youngest out of my friend group I used to hang out with him in.

Friend told me I can find certain parts attractive but not be attracted to them. And this is something I truly do not want. 

I’ve been obsessing so hard about this possibility I am attracted to his hands in that way (I know there’s probably nothing wrong with being only attracted to his hands, but in my eyes, I don’t want that for myself) 

So again, I learnt that gorinal responses and “false attraction” is just like your brain thinking that you thought of something that’s attractive and sends a signal down there, thinking this was a “fantasy” or something. 

I haven’t had this problem until recently, I used to hang out with my friend normally and not get anxiety. I used to enjoy his presence but now I’m filled with fear everytime I see him or if he’s mentioned.

ERP has been working well recently in normal scenarios like going for a walk or just being with my boyfriend. And I’ve been doing well to not react to these thoughts, ESPECIALLY down there. sometimes it comes with a response but knowing it’s something I don’t want, and that I feel anxiety afterwords, it’s just classic OCD. 


Anyways. I’ve been really wanting to get freaky with my BF or in general because I’ve been avoiding freaky moments in fear that my friends hands will randomly pop up and make it seem like I enjoyed it. But what should I do during these intimate moments? 

There was some times where I tried using ERP during a self freaky moment and it kind of worked? I didn’t react to it and carried on. But it was until afterwords when I was done I started overthinking about it and hyperanalyzing the memories.

Title: Healing and recovery is possible! You've got this!
Text:
I just wanted to share a bit about my recovery. I want to encourage anyone going through a tough time.
I had a bad spiral that led me to spending a week at the hospital as I was concerned for my wellbeing, and ended up getting diagnosed.

Since then, I've been doing a lot better. My medication has helped the thoughts slow down, and while I still have days where I don't feel too good, they're a lot better and easier to manage. I find with the diagnosis, it makes it easier to tell what thoughts are my own and what is my OCD. Sometimes I'll even give my OCD a dumb name, and I'll just look at those awful thoughts collectively and go "No one cares what you think, Jerry."
I also find my outlook on stressful situations is different too. Of course I would prefer if they never happened, but when they do I no longer have that end of the world feeling I had before. Rather, I see an opportunity to learn and grow.
I just want to share this to give a bit of hope and encouragement to people. I know it can feel like an endless ocean in a neverending storm, but it can get better!

Title: What really sucks about having OCD is how little it matters that I have OCD
Text:
It doesn't matter that I have OCD because nothing I do can prevent any of the things I'm scared of. No amount of avoidance or other compulsions can protect me. I know it's an OCD lie. I know anything can go wrong at any time. My rational brain knows that but my OCD brain is just scared beyond belief. 

I've been stuck with the same theme for a really long time. It's exhausting, but I just can't seem to let it go. It's literally the worst theme I've ever had and I've had a lot, but I can't let it go. I'm just so scared. I'm scared to get help. I'm scared to tell anyone about it. I'm scared to even write it down. I'm scared people can read my thoughts and are judging me for it. I feel alone and I feel like I'm going crazy.

He’s being assessed today but just looking for advice on how to handle this from people who also have the same condition, how do I talk to him what are the things I do and don’t say,

He wants to get better and nobody in his life apart from the two of us know what’s going on, we’re being extremely careful with what we say and how we approach it, I just keep trying to reiterate that he’s not a bad person and not a burden and there’s no pressure on him he has time, but clearly it’s getting much much worse as the weeks go on to the point where his wife needed to call 111,

Apologises if it’s not meant for here I just don’t know where else to turn thank you

Title: I really like my therapist! Win!
Text: I saw a therapist for the first time yesterday. I researched a lot to find the right therapist thanks to this group making it known that it is very important to find a therapist who specializes in OCD! My session was emotional and exhausting but I’m really thankful for it and can’t wait for my next session. My therapist (who I really like so far!) was transparent and informed me of ERP and the steps we would be taking, and told me it would be hard and it would suck which I appreciated a lot. I know I’m likely in for some pretty rough times while I’m working through my OCD but at the same time I’m glad I’m finally taking this step and I consider that a huge win !

Anyone else relate? Advice?

Title: Do you ever feel sub-human?

I don't know if it is related to ocd or if i just don't have enough positive attributes as a person. But just seeing others living, photon drenched by the sun, like fine specimens of greek mythical charachters. They look to me just like them, so fucking distant, mythiclal. Like whatever i do i will not be as human as them. No matter how much i exercise or eat well or try to have fun. I will always grind a single thought in the back of my head, until my brain stops of exhaustion.

Title: What do I tell my intrusive thoughts?

What should I tell my intrusive thoughts? (Btw I have Harm OCD so preferably ideas specifically for harm OCD is appreciated)

Title: Reassurance seeking behavior put a strain on my relationships
Text:
Managed to distress people I love into not talking to me at all or being reluctant to. Even though I always firmly respected their need for space and time, I was in the middle of a spiral due to being overwhelmed by stress over worrying, when we had a little argument and i blurted out intrusive thoughts. Realizing I said stupid and wrong things, I panicked and was gripped with such terror that subjected them to constant reassurance seeking and apologies, repeatedly disregarding their need for space. I acted in a scary suffocating manner, not at all normal to me. Other close ones have observed episodes of me impulsively wall of texting my emotions before but even they were surprised how intense and erratic I was this time.

Had my lifelong OCD finally diagnosed and begun therapy. I still feel the need to apologize, properly now, after I managed to crawl out of the spiral. But I'm at a loss if there is a tactful way to explain my erratic behavior, without it looking like I'm simply trying to excuse myself. I still assume full responsibility for what I've done, even though I was acting very out of character for me, and I do regret it deeply and the hurt it caused.

Title: I literally don’t know what else to do
Text:
I got my OCD diagnosis about two years ago, in the beginning is was a constant rechecking of things, locking doors pulled the handles and knobs to make sure they are REALLY locked, light switches, going back in the bathroom 6 times to make sure I unplugged my hair straightener.  Then over time it developed into this nasty soul sucking monster that I feel like literally consumes me everyday.  

For the longest time I had a fear of touching trash or picking things up off the ground out of the fear of it being laced with drugs, I can’t eat food made by other people unless it’s me or a close family member due to the fact I think it’s laced with drugs.  

Over the last 6 - 8 months I have started experiencing I guess health ocd?  I have convinced myself I have brain cancer, female pattern baldness, diabetes, liver failure, kidney disease and I mean the list just goes on and on.  

I have tried CBT and nothing is helping me, I feel like I’m rotting from the inside out, I literally don’t know what to do anymore.

I am unable to walk straight cause i need to keep checking if an animal is around me. I take pictures all the time of everything around me.
Today i thought i wont come back home from a trip, cause i missed 4 trains. I am in a train nów suffering cause i didnt check one place properly. I spent entire day doing compulsions, i didnt even eat, almost fainted at some point.
I also mixed up psych schedule and i only will get meds next week. 

I need some support honestly cause I am losing my mind.

Title: My JEE Preparation Is Falling Apart Because of OCD and Addictions, and I'm Losing Hope
Text:
Honestly, I don’t know how else to say it—OCD has crept into every single part of my life, affecting everything I try to do. I’m a second-time dropper, preparing for the JEE exam. I’m sure some of you can relate to the pressure, but with OCD layered on top, it feels almost impossible. 

With JEE’s first attempt in January, I know I \*need\* to be studying, but my mind is constantly filled with intrusive thoughts. I’m also dealing with addiction, including to p\*\*\*, and I find myself drinking way too much soda. It’s like these habits are feeding into my OCD, and I’m stuck in this cycle that only makes things worse. Most days, I end up feeling overwhelmed, to the point where I’m crying or emotionally breaking down.

The self-blame is brutal. I keep telling myself I’m not good enough, that I’m unworthy of love, and the list of self-criticisms goes on. It’s like I \*know\* I should be studying, and I’m doing everything I can, but I can’t seem to move forward. And yeah, I’m on medication, Whenever I try to take it, this mental loop kicks in, and I end up avoiding it.

On top of everything, I want to go to therapy, but it’s expensive for my family. Honestly, my preparation isn’t even close to where it should be, and my syllabus is unfinished. Even the chapters I’ve studied feel like they’re slipping away from me—I’m constantly feeling like I’ve forgotten everything. 

At this point, I feel trapped. I know time is running out, and I’m trying to give it my all, but OCD keeps dragging me down.

Title: Feel helpless with OCD after moving out for Uni with no support.
Text:
Since moving to university, my OCD has gotten much worse. I worked hard to get into a top 10 UK university, being away from my family has made everything worse. I wake up nervous, overwhelmed with repetitive, negative thoughts, and constantly feel the urge to triple-check things, fearing something bad will happen if I don’t. I keep calling my family for reassurance, asking questions I know I shouldn’t but can’t stop myself from asking. It’s especially hard with thoughts about God—I’ll see something online, then spend 30 minutes checking if I accidentally liked or commented on it, even though I know I didn’t, and then pray repeatedly for forgiveness. Then I’ll start worrying that my social media is being tracked, and I feel lost and unsure of what to do.

I don’t know what to do anymore— Deadlines are appraoching and I’m falling behind in lectures, and the added stress is making my OCD worse. I’m torn between transferring to a lower-ranked university closer to home (which i will regret as i worked so hard to be here), where I feel safer with my family, or staying here and risking feeling even more depressed and helpless because of my OCD.

I feel helpless—my GP referred me to the NHS mental health department, but they just sent me back to my GP. I’m stuck being bounced between them, and it’s incredibly frustrating. The longer i wait, i feel like i am just making my OCD worse by doing the urges and negatively thinking which i can't control.

I asked my university if I could study remotely since the lectures are online, but they refused and directed me to mental health services, where I’m still waiting for an appointment. Without a diagnosis, I’m not receiving any support except from my family, who are doing all they can to help me. It’s mentally exhausting for both them and me, as I keep calling about every little negative thought. I hate relying on them so much, but my family is my only support right now since I’m not getting help from my GP.

What should I do, please help?

4o

This morning took over an hour, and he was almost late for school once again.

He also is now obsessed with anything brown being “poop”, so he is afraid to touch floors and our animals. Anything that might be brown. This has taken a toll on both me and my son. I have his therapist starting therapy on it with him, but how do I deal with the day-to-day because he cries and is barely making it places on time. This happens at least once a day now. 

His hands are red and cracked. I switched to Dove hand soap. However, I have now refused to mop anymore floors for him or clean over and over when I know things were just cleaned. 

Does anyone have any thoughts on what to do until therapy starts working?

Title: Sometimes it ain't OCD
Text:
What's up my fellow sufferers?

Recently I've really been trying to figure out what thoughts, feelings, and happenings in my life are actually OCD. If I think about it too much, I start to believe that everything is OCD. It's like that damn Ohio meme.

[Link to Ohio meme](https://cdn-useast1.kapwing.com/static/templates/always-has-been-meme-template-full-be5848f2.webp)

In reality, I know that it isn't. Sometimes a thing is just a thing. Sometimes a thing just sucks. Sometimes it is complicated. You're not necessarily overthinking something or spiraling. Sometimes you're just thinking hard about something.

This is something that I've had on my mind a lot. OCD can disguise regular 'ol thinking or analyzing as ruminating and compulsions. This isn't always the case. 

Maybe I'm just saying all of this because I've truly been worried that every thought pattern I have is OCD-tinted. I've been obsessing over every thought and reaction. For example, I may think "Oh no, I'm sad to hear that an old coworker passed away." This initial thought then makes me think "Am I actually sad that they passed, or am is their passing away getting to me because it makes me think of my own death or the deaths of people I care about. Am I actually sad not even because of the death, and I'm just a faker without a heart? What's wrong with me? I'm a psychopath!"

Nah dude (@me), you're just sad because someone died. I put myself into these thought spirals over anything. I wish I could be better about letting things just be things.

Title: HELP: Agreeing with my intrusive thoughts makes me start to believe them.
Text:
Hi, I am in a mental crisis right now. I have really bad intrusive thoughts and obviously stumbled upon the channel "OCD & Anxiety" by Nathan Peterson on Youtube. I watched some of his videos and from what I vaguely remember, one of his tips was to kind of "casually agree" with the thought, if that makes sense? Like "yeah you're right, whatever man." to an intrusive thought to try and pay it no mind.

So I've been practicing that tip but it's starting to worry me because as soon as an intrusive thought comes, I agree with it "casually" in a manner like it's no big deal. And it does help, it does reduce my obsessions over it, and I am able to let the thought fly by.

BUT here's the issue: Everytime I "agree" with the thought for the sake of letting it pass, I actually start to BELIEVE it. For example: A racist or sexist thought pops up and I "agree", but then after a number of times I do it. Or whenever those thoughts come, it's like my brain automatically actually starts to believe them as truth. It starts to ingrain those racist thoughts/beliefs or any other disturbing stuff. It's making me question my morals and now it's becoming a new obsession of itself. Fyi I definitely wasn't racist or sexist before and I don't ever wanna be, but I'm afraid agreeing with these thoughts may be developing those tendencies in small bits. 

I feel like my mind has gotten too lazy and just slumped back on some mental couch and agree with those thoughts like "yeah ur true lol". I feel like I am accidentally affirming that "yes, I agree with these thoughts, therefore these thoughts and the beliefs associated with them must be true."

I need advice on this, what is happening??

Title: Career-related OCD
Text:
I'm really struggling lately with obsessions related to the validity of my career, my education, and the decisions I've made. I find myself stuck on this idea of losing or having lost potential. I graduated high school as valedictorian, won awards throughout my undergrad, and got into every master's program into which I applied. I keep thinking about the program I chose. Like, what if it was the wrong one? What if this other school was better, more prestigious, had a better faculty? I'm constantly looking up information about the schools to confirm that the one I chose is actually okay. I'm subtly checking with faculty members and colleagues about the same kinds of questions. I spend so much time looking into other programs, making plans for what's next, planning out every part of my life to ensure that I remain impressive, particularly while I'm young. 

A few comments from someone I was casually dating really triggered a spiral for me. It felt as though he was questioning the validity of my research and the legitimacy of my discipline. It hurt me at the time and now it's in my head every time I read an article, discuss my research in class, write, review. I'm searching and talking to people to figure out if what I'm doing means anything, going down rabbit holes. 

I hate it because I know that this is the field for me. I know that I'm doing well, that I'm respected, and that I'm going down the right path. I care about what I'm doing and I think it will make a difference but I'm so obsessed with being successful. I don't want to make money or to be known. I'm terrified of anyone knowing who I am. I just want what I do to matter. I want it to be right. When I get stuck in these cycles, it feels like what I've understood as my reality is being shaken and if that's the case, who even am I? What else could fall apart?

Does anyone have advice or suggestions for this? I've started therapy but am in the early stages.

Title: Showering feels counter-productive and gross
Text:
tw; contamination? idk how to tag this... germs. poor hygiene

I've been going days without a shower because it feels gross to shower. The gap between me and the shower feels like miles. Every day that goes by, the guilt just piles on and the longer I go, the longer I go. Everyone must think I'm lazy. 'm now on day 3 which is my average. (2-4 is the norm) (f/29) 

I just want to share to see if anyone can relate to this specific type of issue I'm having (as long as i can remember but mild when I was young, getting pretty extreme now) TL;DR : I hate showering but I love being clean 

sidebar, I don't like touching water, it makes my hands dry. I have to apply lotion every time i touch water. some days worse than others but the shower issue remains unchanged regardless. 

Before the shower : 
Standing barefooted on the tile, getting contaminated with possibly urine, feces, dust, dirt, on my feet, and (not even sure how) on my face, in my mouth, hands. (laying down a towel helps, but once i step off the towel everything else feels even worse like i might puke) 

During the shower : 
The water is ok. washing hair is ok, takes forever though
 and so i feel like all the soap / clean is rinsing off of me until I'm dirty again. so I'll wash again. washing gets weird because i feel like I'm re-contaminating myself. and the longer I take the more dry my skin will feel after I'm dried off. 
(also have a thing about lotion, i have to have it and i hate re-applying it because it's a chore, it has to be everywhere after a shower)

After the shower :
Tbh idk what's worse. Getting in, or getting out. and I'm sure for anyone, going from warm cozy shower to cold air while wet, doesn't feel great. But to me i feel like I'm covered in this gross slime (the water) and touching the towel is awful. I can't look where I'm drying cause then I'll think I'm still dirty. When I'm dry, now I'm cold. Which is to be expected right. but now I have to do lotion everywhere, and wait for it to kind of soak into my skin. 

Clothes :
Lord, have mercy. Clothes on top of lotion everything is the absolute worst. But even worse without lotion. Idk which one is worse, again. 
Once I'm done done, I don't want to re-contaminate myself by leaving the bathroom so that takes a while. So I'll brush my teeth.

I'd say this process (for an everything shower) takes minimum 1-2 hours, that is including the prep, and brushing my hair afterwards which is long) 

I don't want advice I just wanted to share my experience so maybe even one person doesn't feel alone. for reference to state of mind, I'm diagnosed with cPTSD, OCD, anxiety, depression.

Title: I 28f have been having extreme contamination OCD. How can I overcome this fear? My anxiety levels have been higher the past couple months and I noticed the ocd symptoms worsened after wards.
Text: So 2 months ago I was feeling tingling on my lips and figured I was getting a cold sore so I took medicine and never got it. 2 months has passed and I feel tingling still so I keep thinking the virus is active. Because of it I'm overly cautious I constantly wash my hands, wash before grabbing toilet paper to wipe myself because I can't remember if I touched my mouth at any point, wash if I touched my mouth even for a second so I don't accidentally infect myself down there if I grab toilet paper, wash in the shower, avoid putting my mouth under the water in the shower thinking the virus will pass down to my genitalia, putting cloths in the laundry if I touch the crotch area on accident because I can't remember if I touched my mouth, etc. I am honestly so exhausted and while I know that this is full blown ocd and the likelihood of me even getting genital HSV like this is basically improbable I can't stop. My hands are so dry and cracked and I try to tell myself not to overly wash but I can't console myself fully. My therapist isn't a big help either. I guess I just want some advice or to see if anyone has experienced contamination OCD and how they got over it?? It's affecting my life a lot and I feel like I'm slowly going insane lol.

Title: Does OCD always get worse over time?

Like not to the point of suicide seeking or washing hands till it bleeds. Ofcourse it ruins most of my day and it feels like there's something missing throughout the day and manifests in different ways. I read about how it escalated to the extreme for many ppl, but my OCD is at its worst for only 2 or 3 days in a month like it was yersterday. So am I still on the early spectrum of the disorder, and it will necessarily gets worse? Or maybe because I'm doing mental compulsions mostly so it doesn't look as delibitating as physical ones? I'm doing something either in mind or some weird tics and breathing or blinking a certain way for most of my day so I don't experience the level of anxiety as usual patients face ig..... Just don't tell me I am faking it😭

Title: What to do if there is a very real possibility your worst fear will happen?
Text:
I'm scared of my parent dying suddenly - my OCD is focused on it happening when they go for a drive, while I'm at home. 

I know to help my OCD I have to stay home instead of accompanying them as I always do. 

But there is a very real chance of a fatal car accident. Especially on the occasional highway drive. Slim chance, but still. What am I supposed to do? No matter what, my brain just tells me "yeah but it *could* happen." which is a disaster for trying to calm my ruminating. 

I know it could happen but I am never ready to face it and say "Okay I will stay at home today and maybe today is the day it happens but I will manage." I'm never ready to start the day and deal with the potential of it occurring and my whole life changing.

I can't even take a shower or go outside while my parent is eating because I am afraid they will choke to death in my absence - something that could actually happen. Ugh.

I just don't know what to do. I know to ignore my compulsions of checking, but the fact my worst fear could actually happen keeps getting in my way of recovery. I am diagnosed with OCD by my old therapist who retired but I haven't been to a specific OCD therapist yet but I am planning on it. Thank you everyone <3

Title: Anyone recovered fully from ocd intrusive thoughts?

They say ocd is not curable. I have been suffering for seven years, not a single day my brain is free from thoughts. I’m so sick of it really, no matter how much i wish for a perfect day, i know it’s impossible and i’m satisfied even if i have a few intrusive thoughts a day. But why isit so hard, i can’t take it anymore. Save me please :( Anyone recovered fully from any kind of ocd intrusive thoughts?

Stop telling me to manage or control myself over my thoughts, if it was that easy i wouldn’t be here seeking for advice. I am here after trying different coping methods etc, but it is not working. It is just so frustrating and uncomfortable to have lingering anxiety even after accepting how it is.

Title: OCD worse with testosterone
Text:
To preface: I'm trans and have been on estrogen for about a year now.

Due to several reasons I've come off it and back on testosterone recently. Since then I've gotten a better grasp on the differences between how I feel on each. What particularly strikes me is that within less than a week on T, OCD thoughts and habits are flooding back that I forgot I even used to have (and now that I think about it, they phased out correlating to the timeframe that I started E/T got suppressed in) and it's been a mess to deal with to be honest.

Regardless, is there any link between either sex hormone and OCD that we know of? It'd be interesting to know if my experience isn't a one-off thing

Title: Side effect of depakote/olanzipine
Text:
I’ve never had any OCD symptoms in my life, like none at all. However, last week I was suddenly struck by these incessant compulsive thoughts. It wasn’t how OCD is presented in movies, like the physical ‘I have to close the car door three times exactly’ or something like that but it was this mental thing. Whenever I read a word of phrase my brain would fixate on it until it was satisfied, or if I saw something like a plane I would compulsively think about it, like how was it made, how was the plane invented, how does it work, then I’d start fixating on gravity. Just small meaningless crap. It made no sense and it was honestly crippling, I couldn’t look at my phone or anything without this compulsive thinking just having me in a chokehold, it was terrible. 

I found a psychiatrist asap and he asked if I’ve ever had any OCD symptoms and I told him no, he ended up prescribing me divalproex (I think it’s called depakote in the US) and olanzipine. It worked absolutely magnificently I cannot even believe it, medicine is so great. One side effect however is a huge appetite but the psychiatrist said the olanzipine would cause that and it’s not really a big deal. The other one is my main problem. When I try to be intimate with my girlfriend, the guy downstairs gets erect easily enough but the feeling is significantly diminished, I can’t feel as much as before and therefore it takes me way longer to finish, and that’s if I finish at all. Talked to my psychiatrist about it and he said only thing he can think of is maybe lowering the dose. Even worse I don’t know if it’s the divalproex or the olanzipine that’s causing it. Has anyone experienced this that can shed some light on it and any possible remedies? Thanks for reading!

Title: Coping Mechanisms Advice - Moved Cities & can’t stop having social interaction ruminations
Text:
Hi everyone! I (23f) am currently medicated (for 1.5 years now! I’m on the starter dose of Zoloft) and feel I have been managing my symptoms pretty well. I did CBT in the past, but honestly didn’t find it helpful. I felt it made 
my rumination worse and I just didn’t find it effective. For some background, I recently moved to a new city by myself to start grad school. For the most part, I’ve handled the adjustment quite well. (Also preface- I’m not super well versed in the medical terminology of all of this so please forgive me if I misspeak on it as well) Some of my ocd triggers are about social situations and I often think I insulted someone, was mean, broke something in their house, accidentally said something insane and just spoke gibberish, etc. 

Before moving, I never dealt with thoughts like this. I think it’s because I’m completely by myself out here pretty much. There’s no one that I’m close enough with that I feel comfortable bringing this up to to get some reassurance I didn’t just keyboard smash out 
loud. This is honestly the only symptom and problem I’ve been having lately. I get some side effects from my current dose of sertraline, so I honestly really don’t want to up the dosage. I could also try therapy again, but with my schedule as a grad student, I just don’t know if I think it would be worth it. I also feel like this will be an issue that goes away once I establish more friendships and feel more secure. I just was wondering if anyone had gone through/is going through anything similar and if they have any tips on how to cope with these thoughts? It just keeps me up thinking I maybe explained something completely wrong during a meeting with my advisor, or called one of my class mates a bitch out of nowhere. Short of recording myself whenever I leave the house, I’m just stuck thinking about it.

I want to add that this isn’t a dire issue. I am keeping myself busy with school, making friends, talking with old friends/family, having hobbies, watching tv, staying distracted, etc… but I do find it causing issues sometimes so I just figured I’d post after being a long time lurker.

Title: obsessive over people who are mean to me?

Title: Helping with harm ocd?
Text: A few years ago I went to therapy for a year because I was struggling with what I assumed to be psychopathic tendancies. I then found out that they were obsessions and that I was dealing with harm ocd. I never got officially diagnosed because as I came to understand these thoughts they reduced drastically, to the point where they didn't impact my daily life enough for a diagnoses. However, even 3 years later I still have my moments and it's been long enough that I don't remember all of the techniques I was taught to deal with them. Things aren't nearly as bad as they were before, but I catch myself falling into those same fears and letting them control me. Earlier today I was on campus studying and I suddenly got very sweaty and felt like I would just stand up and hurt someone. In the past few weeks I've had intrusive thoughts about hurting my cat which breaks my heart because I love my cat so much. I don't want to "relapse" because those truly were the darkest days of my life. I know I should probably talk to a therapist again, but I'm curious to know if anyone has any daily tasks or activities that have helped them manage their obsessions specifically. I just want to protect the peace I worked so hard for

My ocd is going off the roof now and this keeps replaying in my head

What if she gets mad at me and uses this instance to make a false assault police report to get me in jail. She could lie and twist the story saying it's assault

Title: Suicidal and guilty
Text:
I'm not sure what the point is of posting here, but my mind is really really loud right now and I just want it to shut the fuck up. I'm really sorry everyone.

I have a good life. Great, even. I have a house, a dog a loving partner and family. On paper, it's fine, but it feels like my brain is waging war against all that is good.

Today, I received bad news. Not life-ending bad news, and nothing that I had any influence over. I convinced myself that it's the end of the world, and that it's MY FAULT. Its my fault it happened and I have not only destroyed my life and my future, but I have ruined the lives of everyone around me so I deserve to die. I am alone today, and when the spiral started I texted my parnter, trying to convince him it was the end of the world and he should hate me because it's my fault- he tried to reassure me that it wasn't a big deal, and that it has nothing to do with me but his goodness just seems to reinforce my "badness" which makes the thoughts louder.

Now I'm sitting here, sobbing uncontrollably and fantasizing about all the ways I could end it, as my brain keeps repeating all the reasons I deserve to die. Lucky (or unlucky) for me, the fear of guilt or disappointing the people I love is keeping me from doing it. I'm scared that soon it won't be enough.

I hate this, and I hate myself so fucking much. All I want is to be a good person and do right by the people who I care about. I'm nearly 30 years old, what the fuck am I doing?? It feels like it's getting worse with time and I don't know how long I can stay here on guilt alone.

 It's so fucking loud.

Title: Coping W/ responsibility ocd (TW sexual assault)

For example, with SA I have to check every social media platform every 30 minutes to an hour to see if someone is struggling with speaking out etc,(I've even missed school because of it) or else I'm just letting it happen and I feel terrible if I don't or delay it a bit. I just need help- how can I stop such severe intrusive thoughts? I mean I wanna still help people obviously but in more affective ways that don't involve severe compulsions I might not get access to? Idk how to word that so sorry if that sounds rude or entitled. Anyone I just need coping strategies and my mom hasn't signed me up with a ocd therapist yet so I decided to talk on here

Title: Panic attacks from OCD

Title: very disruptive rituals/compulsions
Text:

i also tend to do it a lot while driving because i have frequent intrusive thoughts about myself or loved ones getting into car accidents, and it can be very distracting and honestly unsafe to focus on performing the ritual perfectly while driving. i have no idea what to do. i’ve suffered in silence for a long time because I stopped going to therapy around when my OCD symptoms first started, so ive never really talked to someone about it at length and i know i should. i simultaneously cannot imagine a world in which i’m able to overcome this even with help. i’m at such a loss and no one i know understands.

Title: Struggling with SO-OCD/ ROCD in a relationship
Text: I have always been bisexual but I have recently been struggling with obsessive thoughts and ruminating about being a lesbian despite being in a long term relationship with my current boyfriend who I have always thought of as my first true love. It started with me engaging with a lot of lesbian media and coming across posts about compulsive heterosexuality and a lot of media that vilifies men. For a couple of weeks I found myself thinking about it a lot but didn’t consider that I was obsessing over or ruminating because I didn’t feel particularly anxious about it but then everything hit me at once and I proceeded to have panic attacks that spanned across several hours every day for an entire week. During that week I was consistently obsessing over these thoughts and experiencing overwhelming feelings of guilt and shame and consistently testing my attraction towards men in my head whenever I came across any media of a man and I would feel distressed if I didn’t find them attractive because it would mean that I’m a lesbian which would mean that I would have to leave my boyfriend. This all happened from the 13th to the 20th of September and I have still been obsessing over the thought daily since. Some days I am able to recognise that it is OCD and other days I convince myself that I am in denial and that I don’t actually have OCD but I am just telling myself that so that I don’t have to confront the reality that I am not actually attracted to my boyfriend and would rather be with women. This then extended into relationship OCD where I would obsess constantly about the future and whether or not I would regret staying with him or if I will resent him or if he’s secretly a really bad person and other things like that. I feel incredibly guilty for having these feelings as he’s been nothing but amazing to me and I feel very frustrated all the time because of these feelings and I feel like that has made me more compelled to be distant from him as sometimes looking at him triggers these obsessive thoughts. It is very conflicting because I know that I am attracted to women as I’ve always been bisexual, so to be constantly triggered by feeling even the slightest bit of attraction towards a woman has been very difficult to navigate as I constantly feel as though I am in denial. I now feel like I can’t enjoy any media (whether tv shows or movies etc) that involves lesbians without it triggering these obsessive thoughts, and it has also stopped me from enjoying any of the things I usually enjoy (like art and music) because I feel this ominous feeling of dread whenever I do these things because my brain convinces me it’s just a distraction and I’ll never be able to escape the truth.
