Title: Driving anxiety
Text:
In the past 3 or so months driving has been a huge source of anxiety. For a few years I always had the “what if I accidentally ran over someone” bit would easily put it out of my mind but recently after I got rear ended months ago my small car had to be totaled and I got a bigger car. Now every time I drive it’s a huge source of anxiety. More recently I turn around and have to check to make sure I didn’t hit something. Once I even went to a police station to see if there was a report of a hit and run because I was convinced I may have been in one and didn’t realize - turns out there was nothing, it was just my brain. 

Now my brain is convincing me I hit one of the robotic deposit teller things at the bank after I was making a deposit after the bank was closed (so no employee were around and it was dark) and now I really want to go to the bank first thing in the morning and see if I really hit it or not. I’m so scared that I did and there will be a warrant out for my arrest or something of the sort. I’m working with a therapist and I haven’t officially been diagnosed with OCD but I think it’s what I’m dealing with. (Not trying to get diagnosis - I read the rules I feel I just have to put that disclaimer that I wasn’t officially diagnosed in case it isn’t OCD but I think it is)

Title: Constantly worried about being pregnant. Advice please!!!

I am riddled with thoughts such as “what if he accidentally touched me with his hands dirty” or “what if it went through our clothes?”. Logically, I know it’s not possible. But these thoughts continue to consume me. It was especially bad last month, because my period was late. Now my period was supposed to start today, but it hasn’t, so I am freaking out again. Please, someone help!! I am so sick of living this way!! It is so aggravating and I want to have intimacy and live my life without the constant fear of pregnancy! Thank you.

Title: You are badass
Text:
Living with OCD is tough, and you are a fucking badass for dealing with it.

I don’t care what your compulsions look like, I don’t care how embarrassing you think it is, and I don’t care if it makes you feel uncool because the fact is you are fighting a gruesome battle where the only way out is by subjecting yourself to your biggest fears. If that isn’t badass, I don’t know what is.

I’ll be the first to admit, sometimes I feel pathetic because of my OCD. The trivial things that I can’t do because of it make me feel so lame.

But at the end of the day I have to remember that I’m living with a brain that is actively fighting against me. Nobody in my life will be able to comprehend what that is like. The self discipline I’ve learned in ERP has truly shaped the person I am today. While I’m inhibited in many things because of my OCD, I’ve learned to be courageous in other ways because honestly when you deal with OCD the normal problems get easier. I asked out the girl I liked, I answer questions in class, I talk to people unprompted now. OCD has taught me that fear is just a feeling that needs to be challenged.

To everyone else with OCD, I see you. I see how hard you’re working, and I want you to know that I truly believe you are one of the toughest motherfuckers on the planet.

Title: Struggling with contamination and fear of germs
Text: I (f23) feel like my fears with contamination and germs is getting worse. My mom cleans the entire kitchen with one rag and I feel like that isn’t sanitary. It freaks me out so bad that I cry to myself privately because I hate how many germs are being spread. This also hurts my relationship with my mom because to her it sounds like criticism rather than advice or something. I don’t mean to make her feel bad but mopping and then putting the waste water into the sink is so disgusting to me. Put it in the toilet or outside. Now I can’t look at the sink in the same way and she thinks an old rag that’s been in the sink and she probably hasn’t washed is ok to use to clean. I feel like everything drying by the sink, hanging, near it is just contaminated by germs. I feel awful that I come across rude but I just find it surprising that no one else is grossed out by it. It’s the same thing with meat and the defrosting process. She leaves things out all day even bloody in the sink and just rinses it with water. I get nervous about danger temperature zones for food and cross contamination with food. I feel anxious thinking about it. I can’t tell if I’m exaggerating or if I have a problem. I personally feel I’m correct but I also don’t want to feed into my own issues.

Title: can’t sleep without doing some sort of ritual
Text:
I’ve had OCD for as long as I can remember. Lately, it’s gotten really bad. I went to a therapist about it this year but she didn’t help me at all. She wanted to try exposure therapy but, she felt like if I lost sleep that probably wouldn’t help. So, she just asked me to change the order of things and try that instead. Or just trying not doing them 🫤 I feel like I should’ve gone to someone who specialized in OCD but I digress. Anyways, I think I developed it after my mom died when I was 14. I struggled with insomnia during that time, and it was the only thing that made me relax and fall asleep was if I did things a certain way. Let’s just say I’m in my late 20s and I’ve leaned to deal with it over the years. I’m over this. I just want to be able to lay down and not do a million trillion things before bed. Lately I’ve started washing my hands more which is new and so frustrating. I really want to overcome this someday. I know that it might not ever truly go away? But I really really want to try. Does anyone have any suggestions? Also I’ve tried to not do my rituals before but I’ll wake up constantly throughout the night if I don’t. 
Rituals can take almost 2 hours sometimes. 

Also, it makes me late to work almost every day.

Title: Clogged bathroom drains are super gross AND super satisfying to fix
Text:
Being able to clean myself means occasionally sticking a plastic drain snake into the filthy waste holes of the tub and sink and pulling out all the hair and nasty black-brown-green goop that catches on the spikes. A lot of it is mushy stuff that doesn't seem like it can hold itself together well enough to block a drain.

My attempt to save water by only ever turning the faucet on low so as to not waste a bunch between rinses probably means there's never enough pressure to wash it down. I used to use a hardcore drain cleaner called Liquid Fire that tbh didn't even work that well and turns out isn't necessary. Plastic drain snakes are way cheaper and way more effective.

I did the tub drain yesterday while taking a shower and today I did the sink after cleaning my glasses (warm water and diluted dawn dish soap only) and flossing and brushing. Then I closed the drain and filled the sink with hot hot water and dish soap until it ran into the overflow holes. Then I opened the drain and hoped it was enough to flush out the remaining crap. Twice. That's probably an OCD thing. A less toxic drain cleaner I'm going to use has some kind of bacterial organisms that are supposed to eat organic matter. And I still haven't scrubbed the sink or counter which are also gross in their own ways.

Breaking things into smaller more manageable tasks instead of trying to do them in one go from start to finish is called chunking. Turns out it's a useful strategy for OCD too. I hate cleaning so much that I will avoid it for as long as possible, but there's a point where the fear of contamination feels less important than not being able to take care of my general well-being. So a few times a year I throw caution to the wind and face it head-on. It feels pretty good. And thus begins another gradual decline into filth at which point the cycle will repeat.

It's been said plenty of times before: People who don't have OCD don't understand how much of a struggle it is, not just a personality quirk.

Now that I've wasted like two hours writing this stupid yet sort of meaningful shit, I'm going to go take that shower.

Anyway, just wanted to share.

Text: i have never gotten diagnosed with ocd because i find it embarassing. i have only told 2 people in the past 2 years since i have felt like i have had ocd. i struggle with suicidal thoughts alot, and recently i find myself in class thinking about the relief of dying. i dont know how to describe it, but it feels like the ocd is a weight holding me down. im struggling to write this now without giving in to my compulsions. i want help but i struggle to ask for it even from my school counselors because i find it to make me vunerable

Title: accommodations in school?
Text:
i just recently got diagnosed with ocd after having symptoms for as long as I can remember, and I have had a really bad flair up as a result of being diagnosed that has affected my schoolwork drastically. I really struggle with doing things at times that aren't considered the right time (although there is usually never a right time) so I just haven't been doing anything and have been exhausted with how much I think all the time. this is the first time my ocd has manifested in this way and I am not sure if having a 504 or IEP would be helpful, becuase my therapist has been trying to encourage me to do things even if it isn't the right time. i want to challenge my thoughts but I also want to actually pass this year. I am a senior in high school, this is my final year, I need to have good grades because my grades have been pretty bad due to other physical/mental health issues + im currently applying to colleges. does anyone have any experience with accomodations? or think that it would be worth pursuing? i am afraid it is too late but I don't want to give up on getting extra support even if it does go against what I'm supposed to do in therapy because I know not doing well in school will also probably make my need for control worse. 

thanks so much :)

Title: Help me understand PLEASE
Text:
My boyfriend(30M) is an amazing man, and early on in our relationship was almost everything I(32F) could ask for.
We are currently in conflict. And I’m on the very precipice of not being able to do this anymore. 
He is a very busy human, and has always been. I’m aware of it, I accept it. He has hobbies, he has two jobs - one he hates and one started as a passionate hobby that now he gets paid to teach others occasionally. 

He got a semi forced promotion at the job he hates earlier this year, and his stress levels have skyrocketed. He had some travel he has had planned for a very long time,Combine that with the second job and we have not had a ton of time together lately.
 
All of those things along with the need for family time, seeing his friends, his rabid workout schedule, and his routine - our sex life has suffered, I feel our connection has suffered, and I feel neglected and as if I am not on his priority list at all. 
I have internalized ADHD, I am medicated, I am in therapy, I feel as though I have been VERY patient and understanding and have communicated my needs very clearly. 
I would like him to call me, I want to hear his voice. Texts do nothing for me, I believe I had conveyed this clearly. 
Yet he never does, not when he travels, not on his way to work or on his way home, I’ve tried to ask what the issue is. He says that he’s just getting his routine done. Why can’t he do both? 

He did tell me that he has OCD, his house is spotless but yet my pet fur filled home doesn’t seem to bother him, he told me one of his big triggers is water spots. I have religiously wiped every surface I’ve ever dripped water on, I’ve attempted to clean his house to his pattern and standard every time I’m there. I personally believe that when you love someone you make the things that are important to them, important to you. 

My asks of him are simple in my own opinion, call me and tell me you were thinking of me. Have an actual back and forth conversation(he tends to monopolize them and talk AT me and frequently forgets to ask how I am, or doesn’t ask any follow up detail questions about things I tell him, and I don’t manage to add the details cuz he’s off on another round of talking at me again), and when he is at my house i would like our time to be quality time, not tv time. 

When we have conflict conversations they go very well, he seems attentive, he seems to hear me and understand what I’m saying, it’s never a ‘fight’.
I give him the solution outright - ‘here is the actionable change I need’ and I seem to be getting lip service with no action behind it. 

He is a people pleaser by nature, and never wants to let anyone down, when asked he seems to genuinely believe he IS prioritizing me. 

I wonder if his schedule or time is his major fixation? I’m unsure about the lingo I apologize if I’m off in it. 
If it is, how do I communicate to him that this is important, and if it’s us communicating poorly back and forth I’m willing to learn together.

I also am just wholly uneducated on how OCD affects people, so if any of you wouldn’t mind educating me or linking me some resources I could learn from that would be amazing and i appreciate it.

Title: Anybody else have death OCD, and what is everyday like for you?
Text: I get horrible thoughts about me dying and my family suffering or them dying and me being miserable and all alone. The deaths I imagine are quite disturbing too, I am constantly anxious because I can’t stop my brain. I can’t afford therapy as of now and wanted to know if I’ll need okay? It feels so isolating and all alone especially when I feel like I can’t say my thoughts to people because they’re going to judge me as a person. But honestly I do not ever wish for those thoughts to come true. :(

Title: Is this really life?
Text:
I feel trapped. I hate when I think like this. Like life is pointless and it’s a constant circle till one day we just die. How can I be okay with that???

I haven’t had dinner and my bf is getting me something but I am scared if I eat it’ll trigger my other ocd anxiety in this already heightened state. I’m so tired. 

How do I relax? I look everywhere and it’s all temporary, repetition, and pointless. It’s gotten worse since I moved out alone. Is this really it??

I’m so scared for it to end one day for myself or my mom or bf and not doing a proper goodbye. Not saying or confessing everything before I can never do it again. Not saying everything I mean to say before it’s gone. It’s really scary to me. It keeps me up at night. I see images, feel their feelings. I don’t ever want them to feel alone or scared in death. 

It hurts me so much I feel like I’m in a crisis right now. How do I get through this, I feel so overwhelmed I dunno what to do with myself. I’m so restless. Help me please.

Title: Locked doors
Text: First time posting here….I just wanted to mention an issue that I’ve dealt with for a long time but has seemingly gotten worse over the past year or two. Locking doors…whenever I leave my house, it’s a huge issue. I’ll lock my door….look at it…lock it again….walk away…walk back and start the process over again. This will happen multiple times until I finally feel comfortable leaving. Once I leave or am on the road, my brain will spiral into the “what if’s”….I’ve called neighbors, friends, and even the fire dept. across the street to check…it’s always locked. I don’t know what I’m SO scared of…my cats getting out? My belongings?

Title: OCD about the way I walk
Text:
Trigger warning: intrusive thoughts


I have extreme intrusive thoughts about the way I walk and it makes me walk weird. I try to tell people it’s because of my disability but still sometimes people make fun or poke fun at it. It really sucks and idk how to stop having the intrusive thoughts.

Title: Is it OCD thought or my true self?
Text:
For context: So I'm currently in College and I just got diagnosed with OCD a few months ago. The thing is I have evidence from my diary entries that I had OCD for a long long while now like a decade long. Anyways as it seems my OCD despite my medications really flare up on mornings. It gets so bad that I get an anxiety attack if I try to ignore it. 

Now due to so many absences on one of my Morning Classes the Instructor told me to drop the class. The consequence of dropping that class? I would lose eligibility to get Latin Honors upon graduation. Right now as I proceed with the decision I didn't feel as devastated as I thought compared to what I expected. It might be naïve on me but the career that I'm after probably prefers that I pass a specific set of exams rather than looking at grades. The thing is the biggest source of my anxiety has been chasing a goal (latin honours) that I know isn't really achievable based on my personality. So now I wonder if chasing for Latin Honors is an OCD thought?

Title: Questioning my diagnosis bc I couldn’t talk about a certain obsession/theme
Text:
Hey there,
I know this is probably a lot to read but please just give me a few minutes of your time, I don’t really have anyone I can talk about this.

I‘ve recently been to a therapist and got my ocd diagnosis (I’ve suspected it for years but was too scared to actually talk to an expert about it up until recently). 
But ever since that appointment my brain keeps questioning the diagnosis and telling me that it must be wrong bc during that session I couldn’t bring myself to explicitly name the worst obsession/intrusive thoughts theme I‘m experiencing (pocd related) bc it terrifies me to speak it out loud. This specific theme was triggered by a really horrible dream I had years ago and kind of marked the „beginning“ of a period in my life in which my ocd was/is the most severe. 
During the therapy session I was, of course, honest about my situation and we talked about my many other compulsions/intrusive thoughts but like I said in the title, I couldn’t explicitly name the worst and most disturbing one of my obsessions. I tried to broadly describe it as „harming people“, or rather the fear of it (which still applies I guess) while also letting the therapist know that I can’t go into more detail with that. 

But, I am now obsessing over the fact that I didn’t explicitly mention it (and ignoring the rest of the conversation in which we discussed my symptoms) and telling myself I basically lied to them and somehow tricked them into diagnosing me because I am secretly a bad person. I feel extremely anxious and I literally can’t stop thinking about it and a big part of me I doesn’t even believe this piece of paper that has my diagnosis on it. I feel so lost and defeated right now.. has anyone any advice for me?

Title: Jenna marbles
Text: Now that i think about her whole situation it reminds me of what alot of us have fears about, cancellation and being seen as something we dont want to be. And us being on the other side of that we all knew who she was as a person and didnt think she did anything wrong, but to her it was so horrible she needed to step away from something she loved doing. Its really sad how defeated and end-game we feel about our mistakes. Sure she may have gotten flack for her past but we all know that in the end she'd still have many people beside her that wished her the best in life. Idk i saw her name come up and instantly thought of it like this.

Title: Im scared that I hurt people
Text: My ocd has many sides but one which is rapidly growing is that I hurt people. I always read online that one person was traumatized by mobbing, behavior of other people, a small event or sth similar which is still with them when they are adults. I’m scared that I accidentally did sth to someone (without realizing it) and now they are suffering because of me. I was most of the time known as nice but what if I did sth mean (especially as a child where you don’t realizes stuff sometimes and talk without thinking). I know one classmate where I know I acted bad (I think during a school trip we stole his bag but gave it back later and I think there was other stuff during 2 years (I can’t remember completely) (my dad died when I was 11 and I never really worked through it until now (23). I most of the time didn’t take active part in it but I laughed and ran away with them etc.. I apologized two times to him. One was in person when I was really drunk during graduation. The other time was a few years later. He said that he only saw it as dumb/ cringe jokes/ pranks and never saw me as an active part but more like a follower. He always had a great support system so he didn’t really care/ it was never really a topic for him. This was the only case where I knew I did sth wrong. But now I start to apologize to almost everyone in the past with long text and everybody thinks it’s random and they never had an issue with me or thought I was always nice. But now this idea that I accidentally hurt someone is driving me crazy. I need to stop but I always think what if

Title: I realised the contamination obsession is just in my head. And in order to deal with that, I realised you need to get out of your head, force yourself to replace these thoughts with more positive thoughts
Text:
For the 2 years I had this obsession that my home is contaminated, and my mattress. Why? Perfectionism, plus further stress in my life that got introduced, plus social isolation. So I started thinking about things I never thought about before. The moment I spent an entire week without talking with anyone was when I started thinking strangely. If the air quality isn't as fresh as in a forest, clearly, my home is contaminated. There has to be mold everywhere. You just can't see it. My sleep is bad. The obvious reason? My mattress is off gassing gasses, or has mold, too. I mean what else could be the reason?!

It dawned on me, however, after changing my mattress 20 times, after moving 5 times and my sleep still being bad, my air quality in my home still being perceived as bad, that the problem is in my head. There is no mold in my home. It is a newly built building, with humidity based automatic ventilation. 

There is something deeply disturbing when you consider your own home to be contaminated. It makes you feel like you have no safe space. I wish no one to have contamination OCD. Please, seek help from a professional if you have contamination related obsessions, especially if you \*know\* they don't make rational sense. The key thing, as I've realised about OCD, is that you are aware of it. Use that awareness to your advantage.

I was so obstructed in my own mind, so stubborn, that only taking SSRI for a few weeks made me realise what my problem is: My thought loops. It felt like my mind had gotten a hard reset,  started seeing them as what they were, nothing but obsessions. I realised though, that no matter SSRI or not, I still have to force my mind to think differently. So I stopped taking SSRI, as I realised I can tackle, or have to tackle, the problem with my mind regardless.

What helped was rationalizing. I am a rational human being, attracted to Maths, logics. So why didn't I use that? So I rationalized: 1. I can't see mold in my home. That is a good sign. 2. Maybe there is mold somewhere. But even if it is, humans are capable of enduring mold because mold spores are everywhere. 3. The person who lived in my home before me somehow managed to live there without any issues. Apparently, it can't be that bad. And so on. Also, talking with other helped (but, be careful to not get them to validate your obsessions! This is a fatal mistake I made multiple times in the past, I tried to get other people to validate my obsessions. This is something you should \*not\* do, at all costs. Do not get other people to validate your obsessions. This is one reason why therapy regarding OCD is often something you should not share with other people, it rarely leads to good things. It helps, however, if you try to rationalize things, talk about positive things, other things etc.).

The biggest reason for my obsessions have been social isolation, however. I realised the more I talk with other people, get out of my mind, the less I thought about the obsessions. Talk with other people. If you can't find a therapist yet, talk with friends, do sports, leave your home and do things. You \*have\* to get out of your head. There is no other way. As hard as it seems, you have to force your mind to think about something else. Think of it less as "I have to force myself to \*not\* think about the compulsion". I realised that pathologizing OCD, or any mental anomaly, is not helpful. There is a key difference between mental and physical health related issues. Health related issues can often be treated by other people only. You take a pill, the pain goes away. Easy. Mentally related issues, however, in 99% involve you having to at least try to think differently. No one can get into your mind, turn knobs, and fix your mind. Meds help. Yes. They help \*you\* to think differently. In the end, it is still you who has to do the thinking differently process. You don't have to do this alone, again, do something \*outside your head\*, especially social interaction helps with getting out of your head and thinking about something 

I realised OCD is like a broken record. But the solution to a broken record is not to replay the record again and again and again until you are so sick of the song. Focussing on one obsession leads to understimulation until your mind is filled with nothing but with the obsession, leading to further understimulation, a never-ending cycle. You have to give your mind some different stimulation, you have to escape the thought loop, by social interactions, hobbies, sports etc. Yes, it sounds like the same boring advice everyone gives. I thought the same for many years. "They don't truly understand me". They don't. They don't have to. But they were still right in that regard that doing things, getting new stimulation, your mind needs new stimulation, helps. And for most people "social interactions, sports, hobbies" is said mental stimulation. It's boring. But it works. If you find something else to spend your day with that stimulates you mentally, that gets you out of your head, great! You have to do that, in the end, though.

Title: OCD is convincing me I am developing schizophrenia
Text:
I'm 18 F and my ocd is convincing me I'm developing schizophrenia, sometimes i have terrible images pop into my mind before sleep, and right now that what happened and my OCD is telling me I'm developing schizophrenia. And bc one time I was high and thought I was hallucinating but I was just paranoid asf. Writing this out it sounds ridiculous but the things OCD can do to someone is no joke ... I wish it was being neat and tidy bc this shit isn't half of the worst I've experienced. It's so tiring to have OCD, wish I could have a new brain. 
Right now I'm trying to juggle anxiety, OCD and the depression feeling that always comes back to me , and my changing circumstances, ( 18 now so yay responsibilities....). It's so overwhelming I feel sick .

Title: Putting myself into a “loop”
Text:
I’m a small business owner, and closing my business for the day is viciously stressful. Not for any real particular reason but because I cannot, convince myself I’ve locked the doors. 

I’ve come to this term of “looping” where I will check the doors and walk to my car, or begin to drive away and turn around to then recheck the doors. They are ALWAYS locked and I know that, but my brain tells me “hey buddy fuck you the doors aren’t locked”. Sometimes I’ll leave in a hurry and make it 30 miles home and then the realization hits that there is “no way I locked the doors, I cannot remember doing it”and my happy ass will drive all the way back out there to find the doors are in fact locked, but then I at least get a sigh of relief. 

I have resorted to recording myself pulling and pushing on all the doors at my business to prove to myself that they’re locked, but even that doesn’t help most of the time. 

That is my current biggest “loop” but I also have a problem with having to “redrive” paths I’ve taken to make sure I didn’t miss the fact I ran something over or hit a curb or something. 

Anyone have a successful tip they use to break these loop cycles? Seems like they cause the rest of my day to be shitty every time I get in one.

Title: can anyone else not take criticism?
Text: hi! i was talking to my therapist today about avoidance and she noted that i use avoidance to deal with guilt. i brought up my dad (also has ocd) and how no one can criticize him or point out anything to him without him taking it incredibly personally, and i’ve realized i do the same. we ended up talking about not being able to deal with my own flaws because of guilt. with ocd, everything’s either good or bad. so if my friend says i’m manipulative sometimes, i freak out because that’s my worst fear (not to her, later). i can’t take the criticism of “oh, i might be manipulative sometimes without really realizing” and work to change without freaking out and obsessing over every interaction to see if i’m manipulative. essentially, i can’t take criticism well. does anyone else struggle with this?

Title: Nothing is going to happen
Text:
So I suffer from pretty bad contamination OCD, and I have for the past 20-30 years. Exposure therapy rarely worked for me, as it never really stopped the intrusive contamination thoughts. Sometimes I felt like it made the thoughts worse. 

So, I’ve been doing something else lately. I practice ‘acceptance’ and mix it with telling myself ‘nothing is going to happen’. I mean, hell…this is essentially what everyone else does in life. No one gets in a car and tells themselves “sure there’s a risk here, and I’ll handle it if I get injured in a car accident.” No…they play dumb and assume nothing is going to happen. Ignorance is bliss, right? 

So, with that said…I’m trying to appeal more to ignorance than I have before. I know this goes against everything ocd therapy says…but no offense to traditional ocd therapy, it really wasn’t helping my intrusive thoughts. That and I smoke a lot of weed to help me just not care about things. 

Either way…I’ve improved. I’m never gonna cure myself of intrusive contamination thoughts…but if I can “not give a shit” about them more than I have in the past, then all the better.

Title: Keep bleaching my hands after touching animal products
Text:
So I am a vegan , converted from vegetarianism about a week ago, and am making little steps of change to this . However, as I live in a family of five siblings who are all meat eaters , whenever I touch any sort of meat or anything that could be contaminated , I have to bleach my hands four times. It makes me feel safe but my hands are getting pretty bad they are dry and red and cracking. I can’t really avoid the situation because I’m the only one helping my mom cook and clean at night and day so I’m unsure of what to do , are there any safer alternatives to bleach because it’s not good long term .
Any help would be appreciated

Title: About the obsession to start anew every day, week, year etc.
Text:
I just realised that I am obsessed with starting anew. I have to move constantly because my old home is "cursed", "infected" by my former compulsions I did there. That if I finally move to a new location, that I will finally be happy, that I can finally call this place my home. I need new friends because my old friends got "stale".

This also applies to online things, social media accounts. The moment I comment something, the account is "infected", "exposed", so I need to start a new account, or delete all my comments, posts, everything.

I have come to the realiziation this behaviour is unhelpful. I'm 21. I've "started anew" for the past 5 years. I realised if I continue starting anew every day, every week, month, year, I will have achieved nothing by the end of life.

Interestingly enough, I've noticed the structure of working days/weekends encourages this behaviour of starting anew. Every monday I get this insane burst of motivation, for no apparent reason, encouraging this behaviour of wanting to start fresh.

I don't know a definite solution, however I acknowledge this behaviour.

Title: Dentist
Text:
My tooth chipped a bit a few days ago -- it was a milk tooth that never fell out. Turns out it has a cavity in it, and will likely need to be removed after consultation with an orthodontist that will have the final say as I'll probably need braces. Turns out, that the tooth behind it (both are molars) had a tiny cavity. So, the dentist got rid of it.

Problem solved! Not quite. Well, the *actual* problem is. My brain keeps thinking that the filling is too big. This happened before with fillings I've had during my last visit (This post makes my teeth sound bad. I promise they're not, I'm just mentioning the bad stuff </3) where my brain just keeps going "OH! ONE PART OF THE FILLING THAN THE OTHER! YOUR MOUTH ISN'T FULLY CLOSING! YOUR SPEECH WILL BE AFFECTED!" and I just can't tell the reality from delusion anymore. Its distressing.  
  
I absolutely hate it, no one else obsesses over their teeth like this for days on end. It's exhausting. I'm trying my best to quell the anxiety, but there's not even a compulsion for this -- unless you count redoing it all myself as one. Which I can't do. I'm just tired.

\*MINI DISCLAIMER, I'm not formally diagnosed with OCD. I am currently looking into getting diagnosed. I feel I need to specify this because I'll feel like a fraud if I don't.

Title: Existential OCD?
Text: Is anyone else’s mind occupied by the thought of death and life 24/7? This leads to endless questions cycling through my head and intrusive images of myself dying. Nearly every positive moment in my day to day life is quickly ruined when I’m reminded that everything will be gone one day. Has anyone else had issues with this?

Title: following actors on social media
Text:
I don't need anyone to tell me it's okay, but does anyone else have this issue? 

Sometimes when I'm watching a show I'll think one of the actors is cool and attractive and follow them on social media. Logically I know this is a "normal" thing to do, people follow celebrities all the time, but I feel bad that my motivation is being attracted to them. It makes me feel like I only value people I think are attractive and that's the only thing I care about (it's not) 

I also worry other people will see who I follow and judge me based on that, knowing it's just because I think they're attractive. Ugh.

Title: The book that made me realize there were more people like me
Text:
I used to be obsessed about rain. I was afraid of thunderstorms and thought God sent them to punish me. I had a specific prayer that I would recite everyday, that lasted more than an hour.

One day when I was about 12 there was a huge thunderstorm and I was hiding in the bathroom pressing my hands against my ears and trying to read a book to calm my panic.

The book was The Slow Regard of Silent Things, a story about a young woman who lives in an abandoned underground plumbing system. I related to so much of what was going on in her head, to the point I suspect the author has OCD himself, though I never found confirmation of this.

She even had a symptom that I had experienced but till this day have only seen mentioned one time regarding OCD, which is to think inanimate objects have conscience and feelings. 

It's a pretty short book, about 100 pages, and it has beautiful illustrations. I have both the version in English and the one in my native language. If anyone has read it or had a similar experience please share me your story.

Title: What caused/triggered your OCD?
Text:

Mine was childhood trauma, I guess it is my way of trying to be in control?? I don’t know much about my ocd but that I don’t have control over it ‘lol’.

Title: New theme happening
Text: I just had a cat scan of my organs and everything looks normal except I have some fat on my liver, which is normal for overweight people and the dr said I’m fine. I want to lose this weight but I’m so damn tired all the time, and I have a food addiction… but I feel I have ruined my body by this disgusting weight gain and I am equally overwhelmed by the foods I have to cut out. This feels like a new theme. What if I eat something I shouldn’t on accident? What if what I’m doing isn’t good enough? there’s a part of me that just wants to starve myself. I’m so tired. I fear all foods now; there is now anxiety around it. Ocd is telling me I’m being punished for gaining all this weight in college…

Title: Found a medication that works for me!!!
Text:
Hello all, I just wanted to say after years with debilitating OCD, I finally found a medication that takes away almost 95% of my intrusive thoughts. I take Abilify 5MG, and although I was terrified to go on an antipsychotic/mood stabilizer, holy CRAP! I wish I would have sooner. 

Beforehand I was on fluoxetine and it would work here and there, but nothing like Abilify. Just wanted to come on here and share my results because I understand what it’s like to have crippling OCD. Been on it for 2 months now, no side effects other than feeling restless when I initially started taking it!

Title: Excessive hand washing
Text: As the title says, constantly washing hands is one of the things my ocd makes me do, im at the point where my hands/chuckles are just covered in open wounds and cuts that water gives me.How do i train myself to not do it as often??. My psychologist has offered many advices but nothing seemed to work. Has anyone dealed with this before? And if so what helped u calm it down?

Title: Seeking advice on how to deal with a friend who I suspect has OCD but is in denial about it
Text:
I have a friend I have been talking to for quite a few years now. Most of our talks is me being a sounding wall for her issues so I guess it's also questionable whether I'm a friend or more of a therapist, but I digress. Anyway, I recently suggested that she'd seek out an OCD assessment. I can't quite remember why I thought she could have OCD, but the more I think about it, the more I am certain she has it. Anyway, she started to visit this clinic and has been there two times and they immediately told her she had OCD, but she's extremely adamant to accept that she could have it. 

Firstly, she says that she doesn't want any diagnosis on the records which I can understand, but secondly, she questions the assessors' credibility to diagnose OCD to the point I think it's unrealistic. The clinic she went to is a specialized clinic, and she just rebuffs everything the assessors say that she has OCD as just not accurate for her. She intentionally looks at every pigeonhole she can find to prove that they are overlooking details and she doesn't have OCD, at the same time she feels she's not herself qualified to tell whether she fits the diagnosis or not. The only other diagnosis I think would be possible for her would be GAD, but the more I read up on OCD vs. GAD, the more I feel OCD just describes her so well I can't imagine how it could be GAD, at least not as a standalone diagnosis without OCD. For the record, I'm autistic and while I don't have OCD myself, I guess I do the typical autistic thing where I just nosedive deep into anything I want to understand better just like I did with autism prior to my own diagnosis. I don't want to make myself seem like an expert because I'm not and I still don't quite fully understand the thinking style differences between GAD and OCD, but every example I see of OCD or advice provided for OCD, I just feel describes my friend to a T. 

The thing about my friend is that she will create these extremely outlandish scenarios that I find are very unrealistic about real life events she's going through. When I started getting to know her, she was fixated on bodily experiences and was certain anything off was the potential sign of a terrible disease. She would frequently go to the doctor to the point you'd think she would be a hypochondriac. Come COVID-19, she was obsessed with not contracting COVID-19, would intentionally avoid all people whenever possible and felt extreme stress whenever she knew she was exposed to someone who was sick even if it wasn't COVID-19. It should be added that she's a generally healthy gen Z woman with no other known health problems that could be exacerbated by COVID-19 and she's not been sick in years. 

During more recent times, her focus has been more on work performance and her personal relationships. She was half-dating a guy for a while and he said he had done terrible things he didn't dare to tell her about and she assumed he was a murderer or something like that, and she became extremely anxious around him as she feared for her own safety. This is without ever knowing what horrible thing he believed he had done and having shown no interest in truly harming her. They were also in completely separate countries as she lives in Australia and he lives in the USA, so the likelihood of him tracking her in real life and attempt to harm her were extremely slim.

After they broke off and she started a new job, she's extremely anxious about her work performance. She will blow up any error she makes out of proportion but not necessarily in the sense that she fears she will be terminated, but in the sense that it will harm the organization she works at or the people she's assisting through her job. An example includes how she realized it was wrong to film her computer screen during a training session, and after she realized she immediately deleted it. However, she was certain that a malicious app could gain access to the video during the short time frame it was on her phone, though she of course could not name which app that would be (she's also extremely concerned about cybersecurity in general, I should add), and from there, they could hack her organization's data files and gain access to personal customer information. I kept telling her how unrealistic this scenario was, especially because a) it takes time for an app to upload a video file due to their size and format; b) because it is a video, it requires a human to interpret the information, which also takes a lot of time. She said she couldn't tell that it was unrealistic, and I would say she has extremely poor insight in this regard, which is why I also feel she's in denial about it being caused by OCD, because she feels her thinking is realistic because it's based on *realistic events*. She keeps coming back to this as an argument why it can't be OCD, because OCD is that stereotypical thing you do like tapping your foot, counting numbers and the like, and she's not like that. She also says she doesn't make up scenarios that couldn't possibly be because all of this could happen and it could happen to *real people*, though I feel this isn't quite true, as per the potential data breach example. 

I think she thinks she has GAD and not OCD, possibly because she feels OCD is much more stigmatized, but I can't say for sure. She even said she can't have OCD because people with OCD suffer a lot from it, but I have been around her long enough to say she suffers a lot from her OCD. It can make it difficult for her to sleep or eat or focus on important tasks. In fact, I was the one who pushed her to seek help because I was concerned that she was going go through life this way and never find any support when she totally deserves it. It pains me to see how her quality of life and life prospects in general are limited just because of her OCD and the anxiety that comes with it. No one deserves to have to only experience that. 

I should add that another aspect which I don't at all think fits GAD is how extremely punitive she is towards herself. She constantly feels she must atone for wrongdoings even when they're extremely minor. Examples could include that she forgot to double-check something at work and even though she is not solely responsible for what happened she thinks she's a horrible person for letting these mistakes affect other people, and she places a lot of emphasis on the suffering it causes others without being able to move on from it. I should add that the potential suffering he actions cause could vary from something that to me seems extremely minor or annoying to something more serious e.g. having to re-post important paperwork or something like that, to something which could potentially lead to legal problems. 

She keeps saying she must improve to be a better person because she's constantly acting selfish even when I tell her that no, the fact she worries so much about other people and feel this extreme pain to the point she must take on all responsibility for errors she is not solely responsible for, is a sign of great empathy. It makes her engage in behavior that is extremely inconvenient to her because of how she goes out of her way to act in a way she feels atones for what she's done, mostly by creating all these rituals at work to ensure no mistake ever slips through. She also often seems to feel she must confess to a person of authority, usually her team leader, to tell them what horrible thing she did, but she also fears doing so because she fears being terminated. Here I suppose I can see a potential intersection with GAD and OCD. 

I try to tell her that the majority of her issues are management issues as in it is the management whether it's her team leader or their boss, who need to create a clear work structure, and from what she's told me, a lot of her colleagues are slacking off A LOT, especially compared to her. Which makes sense insofar that she's always extremely hypervigilant about mistakes and they're not, because to them the job is just a job and mistakes are not the end of the world, whereas to her, they are. I say that if they don't care about these things then it's totally fine for her not to either, but she can't see it that way. She must always validate her own feelings about whatever she's done. I tell her to try to practice more self-love and that these mistakes are ok but I don't think she fully understands what this means, because in this self-righteous mindset, she can't see how anything she does can be neutral or good. Either she's totally good or totally bad, and she's firmly placed herself in the totally bad camp. It's made her a bit obsessed with the idea of self-work as well, where she must constantly be doing something to better herself and her character, even if it's only in spirit, and any failure results in this extreme self-punishment. 

Now she even questions if she should continue see the assessors because they were so quick to label her as having OCD and she doesn't believe them because how do they know? She feels they haven't done their job at doing a proper differential diagnosis even when I told her that maybe she's such an obvious case no such thing is needed as it was for me with autism. In the last session the psychologist or whatever their title is, even wrote down the thinking style of OCD to her on a whiteboard and explained how her thinking fits that pattern and how it looks like in non-OCD people. She also feels it was too easy and cheap to say the reason she's questioning the OCD diagnosis even if it's premature, is because she is compelled to do so because of her OCD. I tell her if it looks like a duck, quacks like a duck and walks like a duck it is likely a duck, but I think in her mind she really decided she was never OCD and it was just GAD and she's looking for any confirmation it is GAD or no diagnosis at all. 

I understand that it can be difficult to receive a mental health diagnosis that may stick with you for the rest of your life as an adult, I definitely had mixed feelings after my autism diagnosis even though I was certain at that point I was autistic simply because it is considered a disability and that just didn't immediately gel with my self-image, but I have this gut feeling that if she doesn't do this now, she will just go back to keep suffering and won't seek out help in a long time because it couldn't be OCD, and I'd hate to see that. I want to see her get the help she deserves so she can improve and live the life she actually dreams of. 

I'm sorry this became such a text wall though I'd say that's partially to blame on the 'tism as I've always been verbose in this way, and I am not quite sure what I'm looking for with this post, but maybe just some help or advice on how I can support my friend. I hope this doesn't break any rules as it said to not describe thinking in too much detail but I also don't know how to communicate why I think my friend is OCD without providing examples of why I think her thinking is so outlandish. 

I also want to say that I could of course be wrong about the OCD diagnosis, but I also feel that if the assessors said it was OCD in the first meeting she had and I feel everything I read about OCD just describes her so well, I don't see what else it would be. And I figured you guys in here probably know better what would work for you in her situation, as I don't have any issues with anxiety.

Text:

Anyways so it was cause i stupidly did full on boxing sparring with my friend and from that day onward i promised myself i would take extra good care of my head.

Well today at the gym i was benching and when re racking the bar my left arm missed it and the bar hit the top of my head but not even hard. Wasn’t even painful. Also i have just started getting very consistent in the gym and my ocd is telling me to take a break for a week or 2 even though i have hit my head harder in the past in a car and this time really wasnt hard. Down or something. Any tips?

Title: I really need to get rid of reassurance from ChatGPT
Text:
I used ChatGPT to make sure for so many things. Every time I send out a message I will ask it if my message is not offensive or impolite. If it gives me correction, I’ll re-edit my message and ask it again, and do this for many times to send simply one message. 

Besides, if I said sth during discussion or did sth in my daily life, I’ll also ask it if I was right. I overthink about every word I said during every chat but now I overthink about them much more.

It wastes me so much time, but it’s hard to get rid of it. If I don’t ask it, I’ll feel uneasy and can’t send out any message or email at all. But this makes my social problem even more terrible. I hesitate more when I need to say sth in real life.

Title: How to deal with boyfriend's OCD
Text:
I love my boyfriend and can see a future with him but I'm having a hard time accepting his mental illness. He has OCD and BPD. I have bipolar and anxiety disorders. I've been stable, medicated, and seeing a therapist for five years now. We've been together for three years. 

It seems that if things are not perfect he freaks out. Mostly yelling and slamming doors. A lot of the anger stems from cleaning. I do not clean the house when he is home because he gets anxious if I'm walking around while he sits, the noise from doing dishes irritates him, he cannot stand the sounds of the washer/dryer and dishwasher, and he watches me the entire time I'm cleaning and without fail will seek out something I did wrong. 

I was a professional cleaner for some time and I like to keep a clean home. I know what I'm doing when it comes to cleaning the apartment. However, somehow I always "clean wrong" in his opinion. For example, he doesn't believe I wipe the crumbs on a counter into a paper towel, he thinks I brush it all to the ground. As soon as I wipe the counter he goes back and runs his hand over the counter and looks for crumbs on the floor. Somehow he always finds a crumb but throws it away without showing me. 

The other night he said the kitchen floor was filthy with crusty food and I needed to clean it ASAP. This was one day after I vacuumed and I had not cooked in the kitchen yet. I went to the kitchen with a flashlight and saw a single crumb (which I picked up). I ran my feet along the ground to see if I could feel what he was referring to and I didn't feel anything. 

I mostly clean when he is at work and I have the day off. I honestly dread him coming home on those days. It feels like I'm going to throw up leading up to the time his shift ends. I know he is going to see the place looking clean and find something I did wrong. When he points something out he will wipe down everything again not just the "mistake" he saw. He will argue and freak out for an hour before going to his room, not speaking to me. All I do during this time is apologize for not doing it how he wants so he'll stop yelling. 

I have trauma about aggressive outbursts from men so I just totally shut down and start crying when he yells. Then he gets even more angry. He says I just sit in silence when he is trying to get through to me and I'm not giving him any reason to trust me with cleaning. He thinks I'm not cleaning right on purpose to force him to do everything. 

Eventually, when he calms down he apologizes for his reaction but it never changes. It has gotten to the point that I'm so anxious about cleaning that I simply don't want to do it. He gets mad that I don't clean enough or take initiative to clean and he says he has to do everything. I respond by explaining the reasons I can't clean when he is home and he says I should just ask his permission when I want to clean. Whenever I ask permission to clean he says I can do it later so he can go to his room with his headphones. Later rolls around and he either forgets to give me permission or I ask again and he gets angry that I'm rushing him. 

He is on depression medication but has not seen a therapist in years. I've asked him to see a therapist in the past and he says it doesn't work for him. I don't want to leave him because I believe he loves me more than anyone ever could. He doesn't judge me for anything, he supports me when I'm having a hard time, I love hanging out with him when he isn't angry, we have so much in common. What do I do?

Title: Anyone take Adderall and Wellbutrin?
Text:
I have really bad OCD, which causes anxiety, which causes depression. I've taken Wellbutrin 450 for years-- definitely helps my depression. I also take Seroquel ("off label", I suppose you'd call it) for OCD and Anxiety. This has also been great. 

The past few months I've been really down, and OCD/intrusive thoughts are at an all time high, which makes my depression worse. 

My doctor recommended adding a very low dose of adderall to 1.) help the depression and 2.) help with the OCD

I'm not really excited about the idea of taking adderall with welbutrin since they're both stimulants. But if it works, I guess what harm could it be?

Would love to hear your experiences.

Title: i managed to fight the urge to check
Text:
last night i was spiraling over an intrusive thought/false memory after i checked a post. i was literally crashing out. i decided to check if it was true but in the same time i was literally crying rivers

my first intention was to check, but because my mind was all over the place, my mind wandered off to whatever i was sad about. it honestly felt really comforting to just cry and let it out. after about 5-10 minutes i said “no, im not going to check because im going to feel bad” and then i went on with my night routine

my cat was with me and i had him on my lap and i was honestly crying over him. he came next to me and sat on my arm and looked at me concerned lol 😭 he stayed with me the whole time and after i got up i took him back to his place. im kind of fighting the thought that i did end up checking, but it honestly has no way of being true because i was crying and i wanted to stay with my cat because he makes me feel better, not because of my intrusive thought

i feel okay, im still kind of bothered, but it’s okay for now

Title: Fed up with it all
Text:
I am writing this to try and convey my mindset and how it affects my life. I don’t know why I have OCD and this mindset, but it is what it is. Most people as far as I am aware will have a fleeting worry and then go on about their lives. They might think ‘oh I hit my head, I hope that didn’t cause brain damage haha’ but to me such worries become incredibly real and debilitating. I will genuinely believe that something I am thinking about or have done will come true, it is not even a question of if but when. This can seem extremely illogical to outsiders, and this is links back to what I said earlier. Most people do not experience this, their thoughts come and go with no real weight to them. For me this isn’t the case, all of my worries invoke a sense of doom and existential dread.

This can make life incredibly challenging; most people work with a future in mind, but now I believe a future for myself is non-existent. I feel that I will die or develop a neurodegenerative disease. And thus, what is the point in doing anything that would improve my life in the long-term. If you knew that you had a few years left to live you would not care nearly as much about how your present actions will impact your future. This is how I feel almost constantly, there a brief moment where I feel that everything will be OK but those are few and far between. Now I have recognized this pattern, there will be moments where I will focus on the things typical people worry about; how much money will I make, will I get a girlfriend, have kids etc… But I know this is fleeting and I simply accept that it will eventually come to an end and I will go back to worrying about what I was worrying about before. To me my thoughts are reality, I cannot dissociate from them. I’ve tried CBT, and all the other bullshit, nothing helps. You cannot convince me that I have not caused neurological damage to myself through self-injurious behaviours, no amount of CBT (copium) will change the FACTS. If I had driven a nail through my hand in an accident you could not CBT me out of believing there is a nail driven through my hand.

I’m just so fed up, it’s endless. One things after another. I’ve been stuck on this ‘obsession’ for a year now and it isn’t going away, it’s only getting worse. Tried numerous psychologists, books, pregabalin, anti-psychotics, SSRIs, at what point do you say enough is enough.

Title: Contamination OCD

I still feel as though my house is covered in third hand smoke though, even though he did it outside. I’m washing my hands so often that they are cracked and bleeding. I don’t hug my partner or sit with him as I still think of him as contaminated. I cringe when he holds the baby even though I know he hasn’t smoked and his clothes and hands are clean. I am working with a therapist but i am still struggling.

Title: Off meds and OCD is raging
Text: Total rookie move- I know… I stopped my meds (cymbalta aka duloxetine 20mg/ day) a couple weeks ago. The first week I was fine. This last week- back to cycling migraines and headaches and my ocd ticks are so utterly apparent it’s embarrassing. I’m not currently enrolled with any psychiatrist, my primary has been managing my script for the last year. Should I just start back up taking them? Maybe it’s time for a reevaluation? Im 34 and was officially diagnosed at 32 after a severe episode. I thought I was going to be fine after feeling stable for the last year once finding cymbalta- 100% not fine off of it. I cried for two hours this morning in pure rage because my husband didn’t do the laundry the way I need it done (bless his heart). This is ridiculous. Shouldn’t feel like my world is going to end or I am going to die because a spoon is in the wrong spot, or my work files got out of order. I made such good progress with meds combined with exposure therapy and CBT but it’s not proving helpful right now at all with my physical responses to my internal stressors. Thinking I should start my script back up and seek another evaluation? Is it common to have to reevaluate? I really thought I had a good grip on things but I messed up cutting off my meds. If I’m being honest- I just got tired of taking them everyday but I’m realizing how crucial they are for me. Any input appreciated.

Title: OCD is about to cost me my job... again.
Text:
I can never last at any job for longer than a year because the OCD builds up too much & takes over. And I mean *any* job; I was lucky enough to once have a WFH job with zero deadlines and I still cracked under the pressure of my own thoughts. If I'm being quite honest, the OCD doesn't even feel like just intrusive thoughts anymore, but rather a separate identity with its own personality and interpretation of memories. I've suffered from this crap since childhood, so I have no doubt it's screwed up my mental development to that extent.

I started a part-time retail job last December, and I've been enjoying the opportunity to work with a product that I like (computers). What I haven't been enjoying is the absolutely toxic working environment. So much pressure from higher-ups to upsell meaningless bullcrap. So much micromanaging and attempts to get me in trouble from coworkers trying to suck up. And of course, the occasional problematic customer, although I've honestly found these to be the least stressful of the bunch. I'm not a violent person whatsoever, but my disdain for this working environment has resulted in harm OCD festering in the back of my mind. And this past week, after experiencing a string of triggering events both in and out of the store, the OCD overtook me. I was working my shift, and I could feel my body tense up in response to the unwanted thoughts of hurting those around me. It felt like I could involuntarily strike at any moment. So I left. Said I wasn't feeling well, haven't been back since.

The OCD personality is still in control, and it wants me to self-sabotage. I was offered a generous holiday attendance bonus, and I've likely lost that now, so why not throw everything else away while we're at it? There's no way I can handle the upcoming Black Friday traffic, so I should just quit now. Or get them to fire me. Or whatever. I don't care anymore. I can still access the thoughts and memories of my non-OCD half while it's taking a backseat, and it actually agrees: why should I keep trying to save money for a future that's not worth fighting for? A future where I'm constantly fluctuating between these 2 emotional states until it finally kills me? No thanks. I don't fight battles I can't win.

Title: Is There A Cure-Medicine for OCD ?
Text:
Hi friend.

I have OCD since my childhood, it's quite possibly genetical (associated with the genes of my genetic disease - sickle cell anemia) (here is the link for it : https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/j.1440-1819.2012.02382.x)

  
My OCD has never been at life blocking level but, the more I had bad experiences in my life, the more my OCD increased. Traumas increased it.

My OCD is like this : I can't use something containing the numbers of my age, I think something bad will happen to me. I can't buy items containing the letters of my beloved people, I think something bad will happen to them... etc. Usually it is like this, "If I do this / buy this, I will be distracted and something bad will happen to my beloved people or to me."    And also, I am not a religious person but, I can't do what my religion prohibits. Again, I think something bad will happen to my beloved people.

  
My OCD is kind of magical thinking. I saw a psychologist about this and he said there is no cure, I need to have anti depressants. He also applied EMDR therapy on me but it didn't work.

Is there a cure - medicine for it ? It started to block my life. Thank you.

Title: Is this apart of my OCD?
Text:
I'm recently diagnosed with OCD and since became hyper aware of what I'm doing which leads me to the question.
This is more prevalent when I'm leaving to go to work, that I'm constantly checking myself, my pockets, my zips etc. I get this thought that I've forgotten something and this will lead me to becoming useless at work. But it'll also include me checking that my zipper on my bag (worried about losing something) and jeans (worried about exposing myself) are done up, and that I've put my shoes are on. 
I'm just wondering if this is actually apart of my OCD, or if I'm just hyper careful? Sorry, I'm not sure if this is against the rules or not

Title: My personality changes as soon I change my haircut
Text:
First of all what the fuck did I realize

I (M27) noticed that the longer my hair is (sides especially) the more depressed, anxious and introspective I feel, instead the other way round if I get the haircut I used to have in my early 20s (faded sides, curly hair on top) the more extroverted, sure of myself and legitimately quick witted, sharp and present I am.

I noticed that my depression and my antidepressants treatment (started around July 2023) happened after I started letting my hair grow more.

Then I didn't think about it too much, but I noticed that whenever I got a haircut the first week I'd feel amazing like if I basically didn't have any mental issue.

The same happened yesterday, from two weeks ago I started feeling really down (last haircut: one month ago) but as soon as I got one yesterday today I feel amazing again.

I'm pretty sure I have OCD over my hair since I got "traumatized" when I was a kid.

I used to straighten them before: once when I was around 12 I didn't and I went outside, met a girl I liked and she told me (she didn't see me with my natural hair before) what the fuck was that hair I had (I don't know man it's ridiculous even writing it down but still it affected me

Could it be I'm so obsessed with it that this led me to feel depressed whenever I have a haircut I don't really like that much?

Before I used to cut them like once every week and half (and felt good), after June 2023 I started letting them grow and cut them once a month/month and a half

Title: Told my psychiatrist I wanted to ween off all meds
Text: 2022 trauma therapy unfolded a lot of internal pain I harnessed.  2023 realized I had an alcohol problem as it allowed me to somewhat navigate and enjoy life. Addiction treatment.  2024 the most humbling year of my life. Realized losing my business, catching a DWI, relapsing, going to jail, being homeless, living in shelter, beginning work again and being content with who I am, where I am, and what I have. Experiencing a spiritual moment when I realized after two years of quitting alcohol that the message finally got through. The obsession is lifted!2025 the accumulation year, starting clinical trials as a means to save money do the right thing with it.  Taking trades jobs in between studies. Continuation working the steps, waning off meds complete.  And having my inner child leave back, I don’t need anyone’s approval anymore.

Title: It’s been over a year and I don’t know how to move past this
Text:
TRIGGER WARNING: existential OCD

FWIW I’ve been diagnosed for 7/8 years and I know my OCD and how it works very well - something the psychiatrist commented on during my diagnosis even back then. I usually have a great grasp on why it’s important to at least delay compulsions, reassurance seeking being detrimental, etc. But this theme gets me stuck. This theme is the main underlying one that has come and gone throughout my life since OCD became prominent in my teens, but it’s been over a year and it hasn’t really changed. Sometimes my OCD would go into ‘remission’ for a while, or be there but pretty bearable, and I miss how much I’d appreciate those times.

I don’t understand what the first step to make is (putting aside counselling because no free time and very very long waiting list for someone likely not very helpful in my experience. And putting aside medication for now as need to sort out a new dr as the current one made a mistake with my last meds and I no longer trust her) - like in my head, what should be my next steps?

I tend to get close to a person/people, then get stuck with thoughts about their inevitable deaths. If I’m not currently fixated on a friend’s death, it’s my own. Not in the way that I’m scared leaving the house in case something kills me - but the fact it will happen one day so what’s the point in life? That my friends will die too, so what’s the point and how will I cope? The compulsions to deal with this are saying things to myself in my head - usually I’ll have a thought that makes me feel better about it, my brain will latch onto that, and it gets repeated word for word, over and over until I get the ‘just right’ feeling. If I’m alone I might whisper the words aloud instead. I’ll write down these thoughts too, and compulsively read over them.

I don’t know the right next move… surely not allowing these thoughts in is avoidance and making things worse? Plus I can only keep it up for a while, usually at work as I have to. But I don’t know how to allow these thoughts in and/or accept them when existence is such a strange and uncertain concept. Allowing the thoughts in means getting stuck in rituals. The goal of going over and over the thoughts is to feel okay and happy and fine again (at least in OCD’s ironic way) but it gets hard to think straight. And the more I get that ‘just right’ feeling from a compulsion, the more tempting it gets to do the compulsion again, and I get stuck in a cycle. I’m not sure where to go from here and my thoughts feel very jumbled so I’m sorry if this is hard to read.

I’d really appreciate any advice please!

Title: Ocd comes in waves
Text:
My ocd comes and goes in waves. Sometimes an obsession can last a month and then it starts to fade or sometimes It gets bad at some point during the day and like 20 minute later i feel better

I just feel crazy sometimes. Does this happen to you too?

Title: Differentiating false memories from real memories?
Text:
I really need better advice, my “false memories” have unbearable over the last few months ajd I’m running out of affective coping mechanisms.

What I do now is ask myself

“Did I do it?”

“Yes I did.”

“What did you do? Explain what you did”

“I don’t know”

It was affective in the start, but it’s been less affective now, I don’t want to get into a cycle of going through years of texts everyday just to disprove a false memory, I can’t do it, I just can’t do it.

I need help, I really really really need help

Title: Is anyone's pareidolia this bad?
Text:
A couple of people here have mentioned that they suffer from this condition and that it happens when they fixate on it. In my case it started late last year with a couple of brief episodes after months of severe anxiety. Fast foward 6 months later after my anxiety worsened even further and I started seeing no longer only the brief complex faces that would appear in my vision for a split second but rather also sustained patterns of simple faces. By simple I mean that my brain automatically sees a face in something as simple as groups of three dots arranged in the shape of a triangle. I see a face in it immediately and cannot unsee it once noticed. This happens dozens of times in a day and what frustrates me the most is that it's not getting any better. Does anyone or has anyone had it this bad from just OCD? 

Thanks for reading

Title: What do normal people like. Think about lol
Text: One of the things I realized pretty quickly after my OCD diagnosis is that those ruminations certainly be ruminating. I’ve spent a lifetime disassociating and replaying thoughts over and over again (pure O babey!) It’s been weird to realize how much of me has been taken up by this for so long. I know to truly feel whole I need to be able to separate myself from obsessive thoughts - but what do people usually think about?? I know hobbies are a great way of thinking about other stuff, but what about the in between? Shower thoughts, nighttime thoughts, bored to death at work thoughts - that kind of stuff.

Title: How hard is it for you to keep the mean thoughts away on slow days at work?
Text:
I have nothing to do. I mean NOTHING! I work in shipping and receiving but I can't do either because my employer is being audited and they've been recounting and trying to get inventory done FOR TWO MONTHS!!! Amazing, isn't it?

As much as I know I'll miss these days getting paid to browse reddit while my company goes out of business, if I'm not distracted, I start thinking and there's no telling which way my day will go. Most of the time, I just fixate on an idea for later but sometimes I get introspective and mean. These past two days have been hell. I had one email yesterday and I spent the rest of time picking my interactions apart, obsessing over how many things are wrong with me, and feeling even more hopeless than usual. 

Obviously, I can occupy the time browsing indeed, trying to find stable employment but other than that? What do people do to occupy themselves so they look busy at work? I could always bring in a book, I guess.

Title: Cured from ocd for years now. A tip I forgot to tell about when doing exposure therapy + zoloft.
Text:
I have been cured for a long time now thanks to exposure therapy and zoloft. Just came back now since I remembered a very important part of my journey to remission.

Ocd feeds off uncertainty. You tell yourself before a compulsion, despite knowing it is ridiculous, that "better safe than sorry"

Uncertainty is a great weapon to use against ocd itself.

When your ocd tells you to for example, touch the door a certain way to save your family, you simply ask, what if touching the door this certain way is what will hurt my family instead of helping it? Make that thought feel more real. 

Now your emotions and fears are UNCERTAIN about what to do, touch the door a certain way or DONT touch the door a certain way. What now? Well your brain will give up and suddenly the compulsion loses a lot of meaning, making it easier to face.

After all, how do you know that touching the door a certain way will hurt or save your family? Both a equally as likely statistically speaking. And the previous time you did the ritual and nothing happened? Well maybe you family actually was hurt or still about to get hurt, you just dont know it yet. You have no proof to prove otherwise.

This way of thinking takes a way a lot of strength from ocd thoughts and makes exposure therapy way more effective.

Title: FREE AT LASSTT (I finally got medicated)
Text:
Holy moly I forgot how bad it felt to be unmedicated. I had been steadily on my Zoloft for two years (150 mg) and when I lost my health insurance and then my access to medication I was terrified. I didn't know what to do, I was in medical debt so I didn't think I could get help through a mental hospital like I had done in the past. I also was struggling with fear of my adoptive parents thinking I'm too much and kicking me out so I tried to manage on my own (epic fail). I tapered off my meds but it didn't really soften the landing as much as I would have liked.

Almost instantly my cotards delusion was so back so bad I could no longer get myself out of it. Had devastating effects I dropped to 77 pounds and I barely had the energy to walk. I went in patient after I realized that there was no way I could stabilize myself and I was really really sick and needed help. It felt my alarms bells going off in my head over a series of days and I had a conversation with my momma and she said something about it being terrifying and I was so shocked she could see how scary it was. It really shook me up I felt seen in a way I've never felt before.

One trip to the psych ward and I'm finally freakin back. Never again, I would rather suck on dirty toes then exist in my unmedicated mind. And the best part? My symptoms from OCD are nearly unnoticable!! 

Let this be your reminder to not stop your medication, your meds aren't meant to make your symptoms completely disappear , there would be no way to measure progress if they did. Going off your meds will ALWAYS be worse than reaching out for help from a doctor or health clinic.

Title: Anyone else kinda fixated on all the food recalls lately (US)?
Text:
(F22, diagnosed OCD/paranoia)

As many know, there has been so many recalls lately with food due to possible listeria and other things. For those who don’t know, the US has been recalling food products left and right for possible listeria contamination. From salad kits to frozen lunches to many brands of frozen waffles. This has made me super cautious of almost everything now. Which it’s not necessarily a HORRIBLE thing to be cautious of that kind of stuff but it’s getting so bad. For dinner last night, I had frozen Tyson chicken nuggets & all I could think was “what if this ends up getting recalled, what if i get sick now”. I’ve been avoiding every fast food place (again that’s not a terrible thing but) and certain products in stores i usually like cause i’m scared something is going to be recalled. That’s just all i’ve been thinking about with almost all sorts of foods & it’s just not good cause I don’t want to make myself by not eating much. Those “what ifs” are just the worst.

Title: How should I tell my friends I’m suspecting OCD symptoms?
Text:
I hope this is okay to post here because I’m not 100% certain that I have OCD, just that for the past few months I’ve been doing a ton of research into the condition and slowly realising that a lot of the behaviours I’ve done for a long time line up with these experiences, especially moral scrupulosity and relationship OCD (affecting how I interact with my friend group specifically). Yesterday I finally told my partner everything, it was the first time I’d told anyone about any of this and he was really understanding, helped me put lots of things in context and also said that I’d probably feel better if I had the support of my friend group. I want to tell them all about this but I’m nervous to because it feels like just baring a huge part of my soul, I’d feel really exposed, and also because of the possible relationship OCD - I basically obsess over whether I’m going to be found out as being secretly a bad friend, or if I’m talking too much or being annoying, or if I’ve accidentally said something offensive (and I look back at messages, look up words and replay interactions in my head to make sure I haven’t) and will socially withdraw when that obsession makes me feel anxious and guilty, until I start feeling lonely and begin socialising again. I feel like if I tell my friends all that, I don’t want them to think of me differently or feel like they have to change how they talk to me so I feel stuck on how much I should mention or if I should even say anything.

If I do decide to tell them, I want to maybe have some pointers ready on how to give support just in case they don’t know how, but I haven’t gotten that far in my research (apart from topics like reassurance). I will probably do a search right after I post this but if anybody has some suggestions for supporting people with OCD for me to add to my research document I would really appreciate it!
