Title: how to deal with free time?
Text:
exams are over for me, which I know is supposed to be good, but I cant help but feel really numb and empty. I'm also terrified because studying has always been a distraction for me, so now that I'm completely free and theres nothing to do, a lot of my intrusive thoughts have resurfaced. It also sucks more because I've always had obsessions around a specific family member and now without school I'm literally around this person 24/7. I've tried going back to old hobbies (reading, watching tv, writing), and done constructive things like cleaning my room but I just feel detached and lost. 

I skipped out on my school's prom, and instead agreed to meet up with some friends tomorrow. But with my current headspace I dont think I'll be much fun to be around and I feel like I should give this a miss too. I dont know how to get over this weird feeling. Has anyone felt like this after getting lots of free time? How have you found ways to distract yourself?

Title: Is it normal for ocd to forget stuff?
Text: Like forgetting what I was thinking or what I was going to do

Title: Has anyone experienced the OCD theme of “memory contamination”?
Text: At least that’s what I’ve always called it as I’ve never encountered another OCD sufferer with this particular theme. I’ve dealt with more common themes, such as scrupulosity, magical, thinking, touching door knobs to prevent a catastrophic event, etc. However, about 10 years ago, when I was listening to one of my favorite songs, I found it really interesting how music can seemingly transport you back into a particularly fond memory from when you were previously listening to that song. I.e. I listened to this track while I was lying in a hammock on vacation, now whenever I hear that song it feels like I’m back in that hammock. Then the thought occurred to me: what if this can happen with bad and/or disgusting memories? What if I listened to an album I was really looking forward to, but in the middle of a great song I saw or thought about something gross, and then forever more when I tried listening to that song, I would be reminded of said gross thing. Since then, this theme has exploded into endless scenarios, severely fucking up my life since I was a teenager. I deliberately avoid potentially impactful moments in my life because I’m terrified that somehow the memories of these moments can be forever tainted by any number of disturbing thoughts/images. I can go on forever. Main question is just if anyone has experienced this theme before?

Title: My girlfriend’s gonna break up with me over this. What do I do
Text:
First of all it’s not her fault, all of our conversations are about me feeling sick and im practically just being selfish now. But every time i get a symptom i GENUINELY believe i’m going to die. I dont even know what to do.

About 10 weeks ago, I woke up with a weird triangular bite on my chest. It didn’t itch at all, which made it feel even stranger. We’ve had bats get into our house a couple of times in the past, and my sister recently mentioned seeing a lot of bats in the area. Then, two weeks later, my neighbor told me they actually found a bat in their house. I can’t shake the fear that this bite might be from a bat.

Fast forward to 5 weeks after the bite—I actually saw a bat in my room. That sent me straight to get the Rabipur shots, but they didn’t give me rabies immunoglobulin. Worse, they gave me the first shot in the back of my thigh while I was standing up. I didn’t even feel it, and I read in the leaflet that the shot is supposed to go in the deltoid. I’ve been terrified that this mistake could mean the shot won’t work. My other doses were in the deltoid, but the schedule was day 0, 4, 7, and then day 24 instead of day 21.

Lately, I’ve been feeling awful—headaches, nausea, one episode of vomiting, and on-and-off fever-like symptoms. I know it could be anxiety, but I can’t shake the thought that these are symptoms of something worse.

I also have OCD, and this whole situation is making me spiral. The bite has been itching, burning, and hurting constantly for weeks now. I’m desperate for advice from anyone who’s gone through something similar or knows if these shot issues could be a real problem

Text: I want to die

Title: I feel pathetic
Text: I feel so pathetic, I've tried everything to stop the compulsions, I did things I NEVER thought I would do just to stop the compulsions and I still do them, I'm actually going insane, I'm filled with fear and doing the compulsions makes me even more scared but I can't stop, I just want the thoughts out of my mind, I feel so pathetic

Title: OCD constant checking for herpes
Text: I've been struggling for a few years now with constant skin checking that I have genital herpes. It's so difficult because the vagina has so many natural bumps and grooves that I constantly look at and then I end of irritating myself and making myself sore which then convinces me that I do indeed have something down there. I have had some actual scares but I've gone to my gyno each time and have been swabbed and they come back negative. I know it's not normal to be looking down there every day or feeling like every single itch is that. I'm dealing with this new lower back cramping now and I'm convinced it's because I have herpes and I don't know it. It's become so bad that I've thought about taking the antivirals just to ease my mind.

Text: I think the worst thing about OCD Is the Meta part of it. Like to question whether you really have OCD. The feeling of being a fraud. I just today got a thought of potentially liking my OCD and potentially don’t wanting it gone. I haven’t had a good day in 4 months. How do I like it? How do ya’ll handle Meta OCD, especially in therapy, because I imagine it to be quite hard to accept tips or methods, if you question you having the disorder itself. I am very curious.

Title: My therapist said I should *really* look into OCD
Text:
But she didn’t really give any tips beyond that. Where do I start?

DETAILS: So here’s the deal. After a few sessions where I discussed discomfort with intrusive thoughts while doing my job (teaching in a high school), repeated compulsive behaviour in my adolescence, and paying a surgical amount of attention to the greater meaning behind my own wants/desires, I noticed my therapist nudging me more and more towards language that I associated with OCD. Finally, I asked her if she thought I should look into OCD, and she said “uh. YEAH.”

Obviously, there’s no “right” place to start exploring how you might connect to a new network of support… and maybe it’s another nail in the coffin to say that I want to make sure I start “the right way” 😂 

Point is, I’m new to this. If anyone has any tips as to how to productively engage with this kind of “self-research” (and, possibly, how NOT to), I would be extremely grateful.
Thank you, and wishing you all the best ♥️

(ps. Reading all of the “sharing a win” posts in this community is SUCH a relief, and they all fill my heart to the absolute brim 🥰 I’m so grateful for humans just like you.)

Title: hate being alone?
Text: does anyone else get very anxious and uneasy when alone? I’m alone for half the nights out of the week and I absolutely dread when they come. if I have at least one person around me it’s much easier but when it’s just me it’s horrible. it keeps me up all night on those nights too so it ends up messing up the next day :( I’m mostly wondering if anyone goes through this?

Title: i feel like a bad person for my thinking.
Text:
i’m not sure what type of OCD this is. but i get so much guilt just having my mindset. i don’t eat off of other people because i don’t want to “contract” anything. i can’t share the same drink/straw with a sibling, parent or even my bf because i have this mindset where im going to get mono. i haven’t been intimate with my bf in months because i fear i’ll get an STD/STI even though he’s never been with anyone else. i can’t hold babies, i start to freak out because i would think to myself “what if i touched it in a wrong way without realizing?” “what if i held it in a way where it damaged a bone in its body?” “what if i drop it?” “what if it’s crying cause it’s in pain cause of me?” i can’t touch peoples faces or hair which saddens me because i want to be a cosmetologist and that’s part of the job. i just feel like i’ll contract something or give them something even though i KNOW i have nothing. 
i remember when i was at an antique store and i breathed near a lamp from the 1800s i told my bf “what if i breathed in some dust from that lamp and i contracted the plague and its going to my brain as we speak” and he reassures me thats not how that works. and typically when i think like that he understands. but i feel so bad. why do i think like this? am i a bad person? my brother has OCD and i usually talk to him about my intrusive thoughts n such but idk. i feel bad. i refuse to go on medication again because ironically enough due to medication i have medication anxiety. i can’t even take vitamins or simple allergy medications. 

shit sucks.

Title: I just feel like life is so bleak and meaningless with all this anxiety and paranoia
Text:
I can’t date because my OCD tells me that every girl I meet is going to somehow conspire against me or girls I’ve dated in the past will come out of nowhere and say horrible things about me that aren’t true. 

I feel like I’m going to be arrested and accused of life ruining crimes even though I literally don’t do anything illegal, I live life as straight and narrow as they come. 

Sure I’ve done my fair share of stupid stuff but nothing that crosses any ethical or legal line. 

I think a lot of this stems from my abusive ex girlfriend telling me multiple times if I left her she would call the police and leverage accusations about me that weren’t true to get me arrested. She would message girls I dated after we broke up and make up stuff about me. 

This alongside my health anxiety (guess they don’t call it hypochondria anymore) 
And my paranoid delusions that people are going to poison me or drug me makes life so unbearable that I don’t see a point. 
I could never actually **ll myself because death is my biggest fear.

Title: I hate cleaning days
Text:
This is mostly just me rambling about how nobody understands how disgusting and freaky the world is, so if you're tired and need happy things please move on. I recommend poetry.

I hate public places. Hate them. The more people, the worse it is. And there is one particular place for me that gives me the icks in a way no other place has managed to do. As in, every time I come back from there I immediately wash my hands with castile soap, several times, divest myself of any personal items that may be in pockets (carefully holding open said pocket with one hand while gingerly plucking out my phone and buds and wallet with the other), strip, and shower for an hour. Everything I use there gets sprayed with ethanol before use, and I spray my hands after, as well as the bottle because I touched it with my hands. Ew.

So. I got stuck with cleaning duty today. I can do anything EXCEPT cleaning. I cannot clean my workplace, I just can't. It's fifty years old and dusty and disgusting, people throw up all the time and it's just a mess. And this was an unused room without proper ventilation or a supervisor, so it was DISGUSTING. There were documents from 2016 in one desk! Eight years ago!

Anyway, I had to clean with seven other people. Look, usually I'm all for tough love and forcing slackers to work. I'm usually the one pulling more weight than I should because, well, I obsess over the tiniest things. But I cannot, simply cannot touch decades-old brooms and dustpans. Or mops. God, those mops. Gives me the worst headache just thinking about it. You can probably tell where this is going. One person who shall not be named shoved a broom at me and told me I could choose between that and sponging the walls. I did sweep, but only with my right hand because I needed my left for carrying my things. I just - why? I know these people, they know me. I don't consider them friends by any means but they're people I have to see on a daily basis. They know I can't share uniform vests during team building exercises and work without. They know I use a gigantic carry file just so my papers don't have to touch surfaces. They know I sanitize everything and have panic attacks when I forget my spray bottles. And yet they laughed. Asked me if I was going to spritz the broom handle. (Why bother, I'd rather hold my hand away from me for thirty minutes, walk home, and scrub my hand for an hour. Those old sticks are beyond cleaning.) All I wanted was a little bit of understanding. Maybe delegate the annoying little tasks to me, like straightening and taking out wobbly desks. That's annoying, brutal, but at least I would be dealing with a lesser demon. Nope. Apparently I had to sweep. The dust...it's been three hours, I scrubbed every inch of my body, gargled five times, sanitised, and showered again. I still feel it in the back of my throat. I have a special kind of loathing for cleaning my 'ick' places, and this one takes the cake.

If you actually read all that, thank you and I'm sorry. Have a better day than I did, okay?

Title: Need medication advice
Text: I have never taken any type of medication for my ocd/anxiety. I have always been afraid of side effects etc. However, I am getting to a point where I can barely function. I cannot deal with my day it is all too much. Can anybody who has taken medication for ocd please advise me? Does it help? Are there any serious side effects etc? I also obsess about the potential negative side effects but I cannot handle living like this anymore. I currently have no therapy or medication.

Title: Took a big step today!
Text:
Ever since 8th grade, I’ve convinced myself that a certain song is “cursed”- it’s the song I was listening to when something bad happened, and before the COVID pandemic, we learned the song in my choir and I became convinced nothing good would ever happen if I listened to it. This really sucked because I loved the song. 
Well today it popped up in a playlist Spotify made me, and I listened to it all the way through. I’m still nervous, but I just keep reminding myself it’s not a guarantee anything will happen, and my thinking is all in my head. Feeling proud!

Title: Fear that loved ones will do/have done something bad that I don’t know about
Text:
I’m terrified that my loved ones, especially friends and people I admire (including celebrities), will do/have done something terrible that I don’t know about. I feel that I’m the only person that is allowed to be flawed.

I’m extremely attached to my music, but I struggle to truly enjoy it because I worry that the artist might have done something bad that I don’t know about, even when they’re universally loved and unproblematic. It sends me on enormous deep dives trying to find anything to confirm my irrational suspicions.

Title: Obsessions and perfectionism.Well, I am really tired of it and it really prevents me to progress in my life.
Text:
I’ve been hesitant to talk about this for a while, thinking that sooner or later, I’d somehow get better, that I could overcome my OCD on my own, or maybe I’d feel better over time once my financial situation improved and I could afford things I enjoy. But it has only gotten worse. I should mention that there are two reasons I'm writing this: First, to listen to others who are going through similar experiences in communities like this and learn what they have done. Second, even if it’s not as effective as clinical treatment, I want to know if there’s anything others have done that has at least helped ease their situation somewhat. And yes, I know this isn’t the place to seek a definitive treatment.If I'M not wrong OCD is something that can’t exactly be “cured.” But right now, as a Turkish university student, I’m going through one of the hardest times of my life both psychologically and financially, and having OCD only makes this period more challenging. Ever since my parents divorced, my father has completely disappeared from my life, and financial support from him is the least of his concerns. I’m not mentioning these details to get sympathy. The main point I’m trying to convey is that even though I really want to see a therapist, I’m not entirely sure if I can afford it.

My obsession mostly revolves around perfectionism. And this didn’t just develop over a few years—it’s been growing over time, reaching a level I can’t tolerate anymore. I think it started back in middle school, where my drive and anxiety over getting high grades began. Now, it’s reached a point where the incident that made me first suspect I had OCD gave me such a terrible headache that it felt like my brain was going to explode, and it even messed up my stomach and intestines. In my final year of high school, I barely attended school for the first half of the term. Currently, my issue is not about grades. My problem is that whenever I make a mistake, I get stuck on it and can’t let go. Ironically, most of the time, these “mistakes” aren’t even my fault. And even when they are, it’s ridiculous that I let it bother me so much to the point of depressing myself. What I often consider “my mistakes” are generally related to getting spoiled about shows, movies, and games I love or having negative memories about them. No matter how much I tell myself that these things don’t matter, it’s not something I can solve just by saying it. I can’t get these moments out of my head. I end up getting stuck on something I should have already forgotten about. Every time the thought comes to mind, I clench my teeth in multiples of even numbers (especially 4 and 8). Or I hold my breath, close my eyes, and force myself to remember that moment over and over again. These actions are really just hurting myself, and I know it. I’m only wearing myself out. In my mind, I’m marking those memories on an imaginary calendar, and it feels like the days before those moments were heaven, while now I’m in the depths of hell. I find myself wishing hundreds of times that I could go back to the time before that moment.

If I were to compare this feeling to something, it’s like being a jockey leading an exciting race, only to suddenly fall off the horse due to a wrong move, or maybe tripping on something, or—even if I won the race—saying the wrong thing in the post-race interview and being humiliated. Even when I experience something I love exactly how I want, even the tiniest thing that could ruin that experience makes me feel this way. I feel like I’m defective, and I feel sad knowing I can’t go back and fix it. I start feeling intense headaches and deep depression because of myself and my compulsions. But one of the main reasons for this perfectionism and obsession is also me. I kept feeding it by continuing rituals like taking a shower and shaving before watching or reading something. Since September, when I get anxious because of this obsession, I’ve also started pulling out the hair on my hand and fingers with my teeth or tweezers. In short, my situation is terrible. At this rate, I’m going to be too afraid to even do my favorite hobbies.

Sorry for a text this long but I really had to completely explain my situation with giving the full context.If you have any advices that at least I can try it on my own you can share with [me.At](http://me.At) least I want to be in a little bit better situation until I can afford a therapist.

Title: I would like some advice for my first therapy session please
Text:
Hello, everyone- This is my first time posting here. I've been scrolling this subreddit for a while and have found out some good information and advice about OCD here. 

For the past few months I have truly been struggling with intrusive thoughts and what I know understand to be rumination. When I first began struggling with my thoughts, I was so scared to tell anyone because I thought they reflected who I was. However, through my own research I have since learnt of what OCD is and have since booked an appointment for myself for psychiatry tomorrow to get an official diagnosis and begin treatment.

Here in lies the problem- I'm really f-ing terrified about my appointment tomorrow. Whilst I have explained to those closest to me that I have begun to struggle with intrusive thoughts, I've never really explained them to anyone before given the occasionally graphic nature of my thoughts, fears of becoming an abuser and p*rv like my father. I'm really scared that tomorrow, I'll go in and be told I don't have OCD, that my Intrusive thoughts are wrong, and that I'm a bad person.

I realise this is likely negative ruminating or something, however I've heard of bad experiences individuals with OCD have had with psychiatry/therapy and don't want to find myself in a similar situation. There aren't a lot of therapy options in the country I live, and of the few even fewer are affordable. 

This is a longer post than I intended, but I'd really appreciate some advice on red and green flags in therapy, advice for things I should do, etc. ahead of my appointment tomorrow. Thank you so much 💗 

J

Now he is currently searching for PhD opportunities in diff universities as he already got his bachelor degree and currently unemployed. He Doesn't tell anything and says that he will be fine.  I really want to help him & make him feel better. I Don't know how to do it or what to say. Any advises will be appreciated.  TIA

Title: Anyone experienced their OCD getting worse with nicotine withdrawal?
Text: I have been suffering from OCD but it was in an okay level for a long time. Then, I took so much nicotine on October and stopped taking them all of a sudden. I also went through something that made me effected so badly. And somehow this made my OCD so bad until I literally couldn't live my life as usual anymore. Now after 2-3 weeks, it is calming down so I actually started to think maybe it was the nicotine withdrawal made it so much worse?

Title: Any advice on how to enjoy life again
Text:

I hate my hair, I hate my skin

Title: Scared of writing down future plans
Text:

Does anyone else every feel this way? And or how did you overcome it?

Title: I (23F) desperately need some input regarding my actions after a breakup with my bf (27M)
Text:
I broke up with my boyfriend yesterday. 
And I understand the jumping to reddit right away isn't the best option but I I feel like I can't talk to anyone about this and I truly need some unbiased input.

I have had quite a few intimate experiences with other men before i met my partner and they didn't go well romantically. Ive had a hard time processing and accepting this, thus interfering with my current relationship. 

I'm currently seeking professional psychological help. I think I've developed OCD the pure O kind which is triggered by my anxiety of messing things up in the relationship. 
Constantly sacred of finding other people attractive, cheating thoughts etc.
My compulsion is to confess, but since we broke up, this won't be happening as frequently anymore. 

Ive had this itch for the past few months of seeing the area on google maps where one of my past hookups befor i met my boyfriend was.
 
I don't think it's because i necessarily want to cheat, i was just curious what area of the city that was. I let my boyfriend know that i want to look it up, while we were still together at that time, but i felt bad so i just did it roughly an in the end i still didn't know. 

Most times when I open Google Maps I think about this thought of wanting to see what area that was. Like an itch.

I think i just wanted to know out of curiosity if it was close to where i lived with my boyfriend... 
maybe out of the risk of running into them. Or i don't know, i just wanted to know.

this past hookup was kind of a manipulative person, he looked good and the intimate relation was also good, fulfilling my fantasies, so maybe there is something in me that can't process as to why that person was so shitty to me, especially over text.. in person he was ok...
I just feel like I hadn't digested it, but Im also quite sure that I won't start anything after my breakup with my boyfriend, who was great to me.

On the evening we broke up, we have been having a rough time the past few month due to me Compulsive confessing about my sexual thoughts and other messed up stuff. I am currently getting professional help.

But on that evening after the break up and some hours passed, and i was lookin at google maps for the location of my psychiatrist appointment and i felt like it was close to the place of my brief encounter with the man before I had met my boyfriend. So I looked at the subway map and picked out the station that i think i got out at at that time, not sure if it was 100% that, but i typed it into google maps and got a more detailed area of where that person was living.

I felt like finally after months my itch had finally disappeared.
Of course when i open google maps now i will be having a short thought about the area, but now i know where it was and i feel relieved?

But i feel like confessing me looking it up to my boyfriend. We just broke up yesterday, and i will see him again when i come to pick up my stuff. 

I don't think i did it under the intention to want to go to that place and hook up with this one-night guy. 
I was just curious. 
Ive had this itch some during my relationship and now after.

It would be helpful if you guys could give me some insight...
did I maybe do it for closure? Or just curiosity? Or am I really just planning on going there and sleeping with him right away? (I don't think I am but my brain likes to flip things into the worst scenario about me)
Or is this normal and am I just overthinking?
But maybe there is more to that, which i will discuss with my therapist.

My brain at the moment often flips my thoughts into something negative, it makes me doubt myself and my intentions so I'm overthinking now.
Also i have a fear of being manipulative.

Especially because i am scared of falling back into toxic situationships and hookups after my great relationship. It has happened before, after my previous relationship.

I don't want to, but I am scared that I will, because that has been my comfort zone, probably due to my low self worth and lack of boundaries. 

But i do want to change for real this time, I just doubt myself and am scared that I won't pull through.

I just don't know if this is normal, that i looked that place up.

I would love to get some input ot theories, while I wait out my next appointment with my therapist .

Title: Does anybody else feel forced to observe themselves from a third person view?
Text: I sometimes ask my brain where I stand on certain things, and often it tells me opinions that I completely despise. Acting out of character makes my skin crawl, especially when it feels like it's in a negative way, so I feel like I have to ignore my thoughts and consistently study my actions while living in previous situations just to keep myself in check and act like "myself". *This dosent apply to things like opinions or actions changing due to maturing. I have no trouble accepting those thoughts because they seem inherently good*

It only lasts for a minute or two but it’s a super unpleasant two minutes and I think that maybe it should stop 😀💅

Title: Who else know they won't be able to sleep tonight?
Text: Vent if needed.

Title: How Do I Know if I Have OCD?
Text:
All of my life I had this noticeable tendency to be obsessive, I would replay bad memories in my head constantly, and constantly cringe at events that didn't happen despite the fact they are in my head. And recently it has gotten worse, I don't know why but all of a sudden I had thoughts I am a pedophile, and now gay? It's now like both sides are attacking me and I have to constantly debunk them. I would say I know I am not gay but I feel like that is making it worse. It's likely I like women, I have never really thought about marrying a dude. Anytime I thought of a partner, it would be a woman. Now I am worried that I am gay and also a pedophile to the point where I feel weird playing with my little brother. 

I get a...you know what and sometimes I get a flash of a dude and I can feel my hard-on shrink and yet that isn't enough. It's like masturbating and watching porn only make the ideas even worse, same thing with talking to people about it to get reassure. This process started during the summer, I had something happen and had a major change within my life. What can I do to stop this? I want to able to live life without these thoughts controlling me.

Title: I don’t wanna self-diagnose, but I’ve been showing signs of OCD.
Text:
I’m probably about to go on a rant, so I’d be surprised if you read the whole thing. This might also go all over the place, so stick with me.

So I’ve been really depressed recently, to the point where I’ve hurt myself multiple times, and my parents said if I hurt myself again, I couldn’t be left alone. This made me feel like a monster, and it made me scared of hurting myself the rest of the day. My girlfriend has OCD, and she said she was insanely scared of hurting herself (to the point where she didn’t want to move) about a week before she was diagnosed, although she never actually hurt herself. This happened to her about just under two years ago, and my parents told me this about a week ago.

Fast forward to tonight, where I was calling her. She has mentioned many bad experiences she has had in the past, and has told me a lot more before tonight. I was thinking about it, and then it hit me. My life has been going way too well compared to many people I know (especially her). I feel like I’m just waiting for something bad to happen now. A “what if,” if you may. I’ve researched the condition a lot in the past when I learned she had it, and many people who have the condition have said they had a lot of bad “what ifs” before and after they were diagnosed. And then it gave me another “what if.” I thought there was no way in hell we both have OCD. What if I was just faking my depression? I know I certainly haven’t been, but part of me says I am.

We talked about this a little, and I’ve also went to the doctor to talk about my depression. I’ve never had an official diagnosis, but I think my parents are trying to find a therapist for me, and I believe that would be when I get one? But I don’t know. I just wanted to tell a community that gets it because it’s been eating on my mind the last 45 minutes. Thanks if you’ve read this far

Title: Doing rituals without the "trigger"?
Text:
I feel embarrassed to talk about this and I struggle to describe what I'm feeling properly. I've had OCD to checking my electronics mostly and some other things for a while now, it usually gets worse at random times, either in times of severe stress or boredom. I'm a bit worried and confused my OCD might be spreading or warping in some way, and I don't understand it. I feel like I have some strange bizarre type of OCD my friends don't even have and it makes me worried nobody will have advice for it :( I know its all the same brand of OCD just different for different people.

I got into this habit of checking my computers "computer" folder, I became convinced if I didn't check it the folders would vanish or cease to exist or something similar even though I know that's not likely to actually happen. I used to do it once in a while, click on it and verify there was still the same number of folders and they hadn't vanished or became more. I didn't feel like it was a burden or annoying and it didn't hamper me at all. I would click it once, look and then go about my way, it took not even a full second.

Then it progressed to me doing it once a day. The first click was to actually look and verify the folders, the second one was "just cause" for some reason I didn't understand. Maybe because I have OCD to uneven numbers and the idea I did it only once and not twice "felt bad". Now I'm clicking each of these four times a day and screenshotting them multiple times while I do it too.:(

Now my issue currently is the "just cause" part of that. It started to hamper me. It started with just checking the computer folder, then I had to check my computers updates to check if any updates had been installed without my permission(it is set to update only when I click so). Then its progressed to checking my Cloud Storage on two accounts. Then it's progressed to checking my unlisted YouTube videos of deceased pets despite having them backed up on 9 separate USBS now. All of these things were annoying and hampering me seriously on their OWN but they didn't take more than 3 minutes of my day usually of just clicking and looking.

But now I've begun doing these entirely randomly it seems. I got over my worry about several of these: the Cloud storage, the pet videos and the updates for example. They stopped bothering me, which frequently happens with my OCD, it will get bored and go find something else.

Yet I'm still checking them, is my issue. I don't want too and I don't care to check them. But I've gotten into this strange thing, where I check them and I'm not even looking at them? I will click them, screenshot them and not even glance at it. I don't understand it on that part. It's like OCD without the OCD somehow? I'm not worried about the updates folder for example but I still click it every night. Multiple times.

It's gotten so bad I've spent three solid hours. Three actual hours doing this every day for two weeks now. And its worse: I've done this MULTIPLE TIMES A DAY every day now. Each time around three hours. It feels less like "I wonder what I'm gonna do today" and more like "I wonder why I'm gonna have to go spend the next three hours clicking buttons I'm not even engaging with".

I can't seem to stop myself. I used to do these because I was really worried, but now I continue to do them with no worry. I've never heard of this weird type of OCD and I don't have any ideas on tips to try. I  know about exposure therapy and its not helping so much right now. My only theory is I used to do these things because I would feel safe once I verified things were fine, but none of it makes me feel safe anymore. I keep repeating these actions expecting to feel safe.

it doesn't matter what it is, I feel if I repeat a repetitive hand motion or click on a certain button it will make me feel "safe" again. I don't even care what it it's about, I will click the button in some vain attempt I will feel safe. I don't even see what I click. This doesn't help me one random things either, I tried it :/ I'm not really sure what to do, I feel so miserable and trapped. It feels like every day I "have" to do this now. I used to be able to avoid something randomly triggering me at times but now there is no trigger its just always there, and my OCD seems to be looking for some ritual to do, but I'm not even invested in the ritual I just do it automatically. I feel ashamed and disgusted and embarrassed I do this.  
I usually do it when I come in around 8:30 but then I'll start it again randomly around 9-10. Suddenly it's 12 and now it's 2:30 like it is here and I spent around 2hrs now doing this over and over again. This is my nights the last two weeks. Doing this and then going to bed. I even do it during the day now. I don't know what type of OCD it is where I don't even worry about the "cause" but keep doing the movements. I don't understand anymore.:( I feel sick.

Title: OCD related eating disorders?
Text: My eating habits are disordered, but I think it could just be a manifestation of OCD. I’ve seen plenty of posts in here about this topic, and I’m kinda just curious to hear if anyone else has struggled with this. No, I’m not asking what kind of ocd I have, don’t attack me.

Title: Medication destroying my sex drive
Text:
As the title says, the medication I’m on is destroying my sex drive.

A couple years back, I was diagnosed with ocd and tried a medication, called Zoloft, but felt absolutely nauseous. So I was on and off for a while then completely stopped taking until almost a year back I got into contact with my psychiatrist and was then put on fluoxetine. It worked amazingly, barely any symptoms except my sex drive have plummeted badly and it’s causing issues in my relationship. I have severe trouble getting in the mood. Sometimes going 2 whole weeks without any action and it’s driving both my boyfriend and I crazy. 

Just, have anyone else gone through this? What did you take that helped with the issue? Do I need to take a different medication?

Title: Need help/advice for my daughter
Text:
Hello all, I am new to the subreddit and I have been putting off joining because I am struggling facing my daughters OCD. She was diagnosed this past May, but has been showing tendencies for a few years now. She is currently in therapy and sees a psychiatrist as well for medication. We have been doing our best to support her but it has been difficult on our family. 

The advice I need is with one of her biggest challenges in an avoidance OCD and it’s with her brother. She can no longer be in the same room as him and whenever he walks by her room or even mentions her she’ll scream “stop it”. When we try to have a family dinner together she’ll sit at the same table as him for a few minutes but she won’t face him and she eats as quickly as possible to leave the table ASAP. She won’t even eat the same foods as him now, for instance if I buy the kids a bag of Doritos she won’t eat from the same bag if he’s the one who opened it. 

As you can tell this is having a negative impact on our family and it has shown no signs of getting better.  My son is a sweet kid and has never done anything to hurt his sister, he understands that she’s not in control of her OCD thoughts, but I can tell it hurts his feelings. It’s difficult to be there for both of them and keep the peace in our home. Can anyone offer me some advice? I want to help my daughter and I want my family back together. 

TLDR: My daughter has a severe avoidance of her brother and it’s hurting our family.

Title: do you also get dreams of your obsessions / intrusive thoughts?
Text: i just woke up from a heinous dream that centres around one of my longest-lasting obsessions. and im curious if anyone else has the same thing!

Title: Has anyone gotten an official diagnosis of Pure O OCD?
Text: Every therapist I’ve talked to has said that pure O doesn’t really exist and there has to be compulsions, but I’ve seen a lot of things online that say it does exist and I’m pretty sure I have it. Has anyone been able to find a therapist who believes in and understands pure O?

Title: Drinking to cope with ocd
Text: Does alcohol help with ocd. I know it is not a productive thing to do whatsoever. But will it help my obsessions and symptoms. Thinking of having it maybe once a week or several days to cope as I genuinely don’t know what to do. Therapy waiting list in my country is going to be several weeks & I have nothing else to cope. I have sensorimotor ocd. Now my obsession is my breathing. It is 7 am and I haven’t slept. I don’t know what to do. I know alcohol is bad (& I don’t even drink) but I am Soooo incredibly desperate for a moment of a break. I have work on Wednesday and feel totally incapable to take calls and deal with customers. I just don’t know what to do or in the meantime how to cope. How would I deal with this breathing ocd??

Title: Getting ocd obsessions just by reading or hearing about them
Text:
Am I the only one who can get a new obsession just by reading or hearing about it? For example, my ex (who also likely had OCD) told about a very specific obsession of hers about numbers and ever since then it's become one my strongest obsessions.

For this reason I don't read posts about specific obsessions/symptoms, I skip them

Title: Manual breathing and blinking
Text:
Genuinely I'm posting this as a last resort because I think I might actually be going crazy.

For the past like 5 months every day, all I can think about is my breathing and blinking. I genuinely don't blink if I don't do it manually, unless if I'm not thinking about it. Breathing is a little bit easier, but still it's very difficult to breathe when I think about it.

I physically can't not think about it, so I'm just forced to do it manually every day. I've tried distraction techniques, facing the thought, accepting it, even giving up, but none of it works. Life just doesn't seem worth it if I can't enjoy anything because I have to make myself blink or breathe. 

Anyone have a solution?

Title: Depression-like symptoms in OCD
Text:
I am diagnosed with OCD since I was a child, but as far as I remember all my symptoms were related to anxiety and anguish.

Since last year, my OCD got real worse (I still don't know why). Now, sometimes, when a really bad tought comes, my mind acts as if I had done something really wrong, and I feel what I call "depression-like symptoms". Lots of guilt, the sensation (which looks scarely real) that I had ruined my life and that my destiny is doomed.

Does anybody with OCD here also feel these stuff? It's one of the worst sensations in life, sometimes - I must confess - some suicidal thoughts appear in these moments.

Title: Is crying easily a part of the disorder?
Text: I'm 18, diagnosed with the disorder at 16 and my OCD symptoms fluctuate heavily nowadays.... Apart from the typical symptoms of OCD like anxiety, intrusive thoughts and ruminating for hours... (They are in control though from some weeks).. I was curious if crying easily is related to OCD in some way? Like someone would yell at me and I can't reply without crying and its embarassing.... Some scenes like a simple ad SOMETIMES make me feel so emotional and kind of nostalgic even though that ad was released yesterday, or being obsessed with some photo or footage from history... Anyways I was wondering if there is a way or something I can do to atleast not cry first if someone is being speaking in a strict tone to me irl.... Also till elementary school, I was known throughout the school only for crying everyday (this almost stopped with time though) .. for a simple diagreement with a classmate or   sometimes because I didn't like the environment of school....Then  I had minor syptoms like touching something a certain no. of times till it feels 'even' but they hardly took a few minutes then....Sorry for any grammatical errors in case... Any similar experiences or advice welcome :)

Title: Do I excuse my friend with OCD for usually never staying in touch while he's in school?
Text:
Some reality checkers in mind. this is a friend group, we're all adults. we are all friend group online working on music and bettering our lives, and on occasion, watch anime every now and then. 

I have genetic adhd/ocd within my family. this friend of ours has told us that he has ocd, but we don't know much else. he's in school for something unrelated. when he goes back to school, he tries to say he'll stay in touch, but it's more like 4 months from now, he'll have little time, and goes away. I have very little awareness or experience with others of the other ways OCD manifests in someone's life. He's usually very friendly, open-minded, and charismatic, but then he disappears again. he has assured me before that it's not that he hates us or anything, and I get that. 
but my imagination is struggling to imagine because I don't have experience with disappearances for this kind of reason at least.

does anyone else disappear like this? can you explain your circumstances? is this something we get used to? could it get better after he's done with college?

Title: guilt - can anyone relate?
Text: i don’t really know what to title this post. i guess i was just wondering does anyone else have periods where they’re experiencing less ocd symptoms than usual and are able to function a bit better (however i tend to feel more depressed than anxious during these periods) ? i have these periods occasionally and then i feel guilty and it makes me think maybe i don’t have ocd at all. even though im still constantly having intrusive thoughts, im able to talk myself out of them quicker before i fall down a huge spiral. and that makes me feel like ive been faking it the whole time. even though i know the spiral will happen eventually again.

Title: Major death OCD symptoms
Text:
These past few days haven’t easy at all for me, we recently had a death in the family on Halloween. It was a distant uncle of mine that I was barely close with but yet his death hit everyone myself included pretty hard, especially considering the fact that he was so young and seemed perfectly fine and healthy and all the sudden he just passed away. I was fairly fine until the viewing when I saw his corpse and it haunted me and now I can’t stop questioning my own mortality. 

These past few days I’ve been feeling absolutely terrible, I’ve been having anxiety attacks every day since the viewing, sometimes I feel like I can’t breathe, I feel like I’m dying, my heart racing, and feeling cold. I don’t wanna live like this, I’m well aware death is just nature taking its course but it’s mysterious nature is what’s really bothering me? What happens after death? Is there truly an afterlife? I don’t wanna die out of nowhere, I don’t want my family to mourn me and be sad for me, I don’t want them to suffer.

My hope is that I die from natural causes because of old age but I just can’t shake this feeling off that I can die at any second of the day. Please help me, I just started my first high-paying job today and I really don’t wanna lose it because of this. Any help and advice is greatly appreciated.

Title: Fear Is My Constant Companion
Text:
Fear is my perpetual obsession. If I feel insulted or intimidated anywhere I walk away angry at myself for not retaliating. Then, I decide I must find the bully who intimidated me. Then the fear sets in. I’m afraid to try and find this stranger because it’s not known what will happen. 
Possibly we’ll have a nice conversation but he may also tell me to fuck off. I am not violent so than what? But, if I don’t find him I’ll live with the fear of the consequences of finding him and the situation getting compounded. It has many times.
Plus, it’s all within me to resolve the issue but I have had a brutal time releasing fear thru therapy, writing, talking, pills. I know this is me, me, me.
I’m not violent so the retribution comes from being bullied and knowing that if I stand up for myself or don’t stand up for myself the fear will always come back.
So, everyone has something that seems worse than everyone else’s stuff.

Title: An updated model of OCD treatment?
Text:
Hey all! Dr. Sam Greenblatt here with another OCD article that folks might find useful!

*If you or a loved one struggles with Obsessive Compulsive Disorder (OCD), you’ve likely heard of Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP). This treatment is known as the gold standard and has been shown through ample research to be a highly effective treatment (e.g. Song et al., 2022). What you may be unaware of, however, is that there has been an innovation in the application of ERP that may enhance its effectiveness. In this article we’ll compare this innovation, called the Inhibitory Learning Theory (ILT), to the older model of ERP, namely Emotion Processing Theory (EPT).*

**Is Habituation Central to ERP?**

Initially, ERP was thought to work through a process called habituation. Habituation is a process in which repeated exposure to a stimulus decreases a subject’s responses to that stimulus.. A model called the Emotion Processing Theory (EPT) claimed that habituation is the central component to ERP: that repeatedly exposing a patient to their fear, while preventing the client from escaping that fear, would gradually reduce the patient’s physiological responses to said fear (Foa & Kozak, 1986). However, much research since then has questioned whether habituation is actually central to successful outcomes in exposure therapy. Many researchers have found no relationship between habituation within a given session and treatment outcomes (Baker et al., 2010, Jaycox, Foa, & Morral, 1998; Kozak, Foa, & Steketee, 1988; Meuret, Seidel, Rosenfield, Hofmann, & Rosenfield, 2012). Researchers have also discovered that treatment results can be gained in the absence of habituation (e.g., Rachman, Craske, Tallman, & Solyom, 1986; Rowe & Craske, 1998b; Tsao & Craske, 2000).

**Introducing Inhibitory Learning Theory (ILT)**

This leaves us with an important question. If habituation is not a central component of ERP, but ERP is still effective, what is *actually* causing the change? Inhibitory learning theory (ILT) offers a new and perhaps more accurate perspective on ERP. Rather than focusing solely on reducing anxiety during exposures, ILT emphasizes creating new learning experiences that override old fear-based associations. When a client has OCD, they often have expectations that facing their fear without protective measures such as reassurance or other compulsions will result in disaster: either literally or in the form of intolerable heightened anxiety. When we utilize an ILT approach, we challenge these expectations in a variety of ways, to help the client learn that they can handle their anxiety much better than they might have anticipated (Kim et al., 2020, Jacoby & Abramowitz, 2016).

**What are the strengths of an ILT approach?**

One central issue with the EPT ERP is that patients often relapse (e.g., Franklin & Foa, 1998). Researchers have begun to propose that ILT ERP may be more effective in providing lasting results. For example, a study by Elsner et al. (2022) found that habituation (reduction in fear during exposure) predicted short-term improvement, but something called “expectancy violation” (a key component of ILT) was more predictive of long-term success after treatment. Similarly, Bautista and Teng (2022) argue that an ILT approach utilizes tools that can prevent relapse more effectively than the traditional habituation method. This may be because through an ILT model, clients learn a generalizable set of skills to handle anxiety which can help them even if their OCD switches themes. Conversely, habituating to one OCD theme may not help clients to the same extent later on if their OCD takes on a different theme.

It is important to note, as can be seen from a quick glance at the dates of the studies referenced here, that this research is still very new. However, in our clinic at OCD and Anxiety Specialists, we can attest to a bevy of anecdotal data. We frequently treat folks who report having had been to therapy before or even seen an OCD specialist before and did not receive the results they were looking for. Perhaps during therapy, the client struggled to habituate to their theme, and each exposure was as challenging and unhelpful as the one before it. Perhaps the client developed “meta-OCD” and began obsessing about the treatment itself, which interfered with treatment results. Perhaps in the moment they felt that therapy was “working,” or the therapy helped them achieve relief from their current OCD theme, but the results did not last over time. Perhaps the client did achieve enduring results for their specific OCD theme, but when the theme switched after therapy was over, the client had no idea how to manage it. In these situations and more, we have frequently found the ILT approach to be helpful where the EPT approach fell short.

**Conclusion**

Whether you are just learning about OCD or have been in treatment for a while, understanding these different approaches can provide valuable insight into your treatment. Both the habituation model and ILT offer powerful tools for treating anxiety and OCD, and knowing how they work can help you feel more confident and engaged in your treatment journey. We believe that there are many advantages to undergoing treatment based on a more modern and updated understanding of the processes of ERP.

 

References:

Adams, T. G., Cisler, J. M., Kelmendi, B., George, J. R., Kichuk, S. A., Averill, C. L., ... & Pittenger, C. (2021). Transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) targeting the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC) modulates functional connectivity and enhances inhibitory safety learning in obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). *medRxiv*, 2021-02.

Baker, A., Mystkowski, J., Culver, N., Yi, R., Mortazavi, A., & Craske, M. G. (2010). Does habituation matter? Emotional processing theory and exposure therapy for acrophobia. *Behaviour research and therapy*, *48*(11), 1139-1143.

Bautista, C. L., & Teng, E. J. (2022). Merging our understanding of anxiety and exposure: Using inhibitory learning to target anxiety sensitivity in exposure therapy. *Behavior Modification*, *46*(4), 819-833.Elsner, B., Jacobi, T., Kischkel, E., Schulze, D., & Reuter, B. (2022). Mechanisms of exposure and response prevention in obsessive-compulsive disorder: effects of habituation and expectancy violation on short-term outcome in cognitive behavioral therapy. *BMC psychiatry*, *22*(1), 66.

Foa, E. B., & Kozak, M. J. (1986). Emotional processing of fear: exposure to corrective information. *Psychological bulletin*, *99*(1), 20.

Jacoby, R. J., & Abramowitz, J. S. (2016). Inhibitory learning approaches to exposure therapy: A critical review and translation to obsessive-compulsive disorder. *Clinical Psychology Review*, *49*, 28-40.

Kim, J. W., Kang, H. J., Lee, J. Y., Kim, S. W., Shin, I. S., & Kim, J. M. (2020). Advanced cognitive-behavioral treatment model with exposure-response prevention for treating obsessive-compulsive disorder. *Psychiatry Investigation*, *17*(11), 1060.

Title: Driving anxiety/ intrusive thoughts
Text: Does anyone else struggle with severe anxiety and intrusive thoughts while driving? I constantly think that I’m going to mess up and cause a crash. Pedestrians and bikers TERRIFY me. I’m convinced I’m gonna swerve and hit someone. I’m also scared that I’m going to directly crash into a semi truck in the opposite lane. I feel like I’m going to hurt a family member or a stranger really badly someday and it’s taking a huge toll on me. I keep having panic attacks because I can’t stop worrying and picturing a horrible collision in my head.

Title: Suicidal thoughts/ideation vs suicide ocd
Text:
So I was wondering what others experiences were, when it comes to suicidal thoughts/ideation and suicide ocd. 
I know I definitely have suicidal thoughts that mean I genuinely do not want to be here anymore, but at other times I feel like the suicidal thoughts/images can be intrusive and they scare me, and I don’t really feel suicidal and want to be alive. Other times I just cannot cope with my mental health / disabilities and want it all to stop, which can come across as suicidal, but it isn’t always. 
I was just wondering how others experienced this, how to cope with it and how to make sense of it all??? 
I feel like I’m completely losing it.

Title: the substance movie triggered a horrible existential ocd episode
Text: hi everyone! i’m 28 and have suffered with ocd since I was as young as 5 and was in and out of childhood erp for it. i’ve had every theme under the sun but recently i’ve been hit with the joys of existential ocd and it’s potentially the worst my ocd has been since my last big episode which was years ago and was POCD, which at the time was insanely traumatising but now I’d kill to have that one back instead of existential. I have had some existential obsessions as a child and again last year but I watched the substance the week I turned 28 and it sent me into an absolute panic attack and I’ve been having horrible existential obsessions ever since. I’m struggling to be present or enjoy anything without ruminating on how pointless life is and how i’m going to die anyway and have to watch others I love die and despite having had SO much intensive erp and other therapies for my ocd in my life, I’m really struggling and really thought I could handle my episodes better by now but this really feels like my ocd’s final boss, like the final thing that’s going to ruin my mental health forever. it’s so hard to challenge and I have no idea how to get out of this one as death is inevitable and so is aging :( has anyone else struggled with this subtype and please tell me you came out on the other end :( i’m in the trenches. and also did anyone else get triggered by the substance? it messed me up despite being very good and having an important message (though those tend to be the films that mess us ocders up…the joys of thinking so deeply about everything) thanks all x

Title: Idea I had today about rumination
Text:
Today I had a realization: “all thoughts are in the past”

And likewise “all rumination is in the past”

In other words the split second the brain finishes each word/sentence they are history and not “in the present”. They can be repeated/ruminated but even those are instantly in the past the split second after.

This observation may not be helpful in the moment but something about it takes the edge off. 

——-

PS: I am going through a super stressful issue right now, so I am thinking a lot about how to manage the mental/emotional side.

Other things that have helped:
- Inhale deep for 1-2 seconds, exhale 5-10 seconds
- Grounding technique: Inventory each of the 5 senses. I see a table, I hear cars, etc.
- Neuro doodles
- Calling 988 just to talk to someone

Title: Um... Hi everyone, I think I'm dealing with classic/cliche OCD symptoms...
Text:
I seriously hope this doesn't sound fake, but I'm almost 100% sure that I'm dealing with classic/cliche OCD symptoms...  I've been dealing with stress from various sources for a few years now and I believe that I'm dealing with a form of OCD now because of it. I'm not asking for medical advice, but I would appreciate some advice till I can see a professional about my situation.

For context I should mention that my suspected OCD is primarily hygiene focused... Because of that I'll try not to describe anything too graphically.

Ugh, where should I start... Okay, well to start with just about everything related to using the toilet REALLY bothers me. I practically panic if I even suspect that I've come in contact with anything from going #1 or #2... Even a tiny spec of toilet paper on my pants the size of a pen tip seriously bothers me. It's gotten bad enough that I'll if something like I just described happens I'll literally freeze up and not move while both my heart and mind races till someone notices that I've been in the bathroom for 40mins or longer. If that wasn't enough, I have to make sure everything is clean as possible... I'll wipe down the toilets where I've before I'll even consider using the porcelain throne. To top things off I live with someone who's personal hygiene isn't the greatest by normal standards... So I'm extremely hesitant to touch basically anything that they handle regularly. The skin on my hands is constantly cracking from the frequent hand washing and exposure to cleaning chemicals... I honestly have no idea what to do.

I know I'm not supposed to ask for medical advice and I'll refrain from doing that. I would though greatly appreciate any advice anyone might be able to give till I can afford to see a professional about this. I wasn't expecting mental health chat services to be so freaking expensive.

Title: Health OCD
Text:
I was diagnosed with OCD a few years ago. I am 33. I am constantly going into thought spirals thinking I have a terminal illness and I’m going to die. It’s exhausting. The first time I remember it happening I was about 11. 

It got worse after I had kids, because if I die- I leave them. This month alone I have convinced myself I have ALS due to muscle twitches, various cancers due to benign things, and Early onset Alzheimer’s because I forgot a word. 

It gets to the point where I have a hard time focusing on anything other than the illness I am fixated on. I guess I was just wondering if anyone experiences this and if anyone has any advice? Thank you.

Title: I hate my "good numbers"
Text:
A lot of us with counting or superstitious obsessions/compulsions etc. have their own good numbers or lucky numbers and naturally also bad numbers. However my "good numbers" (in my case 4 and multiples of it), while staying the number i do nearly all of my counting compulsions in and that brings me the short boost of comfort in those moments, is deeply fucking annoying! I (obviously) cant stand having to chew and walk in rythms of 4 or checking everything 4,8,12,16 so on times etc., I HATE my good numbers!!!  
Maybe thats just me because my good number isnt even really my lucky number? I just found the contradiction quite irritating when thinking about it more thoroughly.

Title: My symptoms of TOCD
Text:
Hi everyone. I have been researching and exploring people's experiences for some time now. I have been diagnosed with OCD and been prscribed anti depressants (of which I no longer take), but even my doctor told me they hadn't heard a case like mine. I have tried to explore OCD communities on Reddit and social medi but I could not relate to anything. I have felt so alone. Until I came across some research and discussions about TOCD. It has completely changed my outlook on life knowing there are people going through the same things as me!

Anyway, I thought I'd share some compulsions/ tic / feelings I have felt since childhood, in the hopes that someone can relate and feel a little less alone.

(I'm sorry if they are hard to understand, they can be so hard to describe)

1. If I step on a snail, I have to say (out loud), " sorry Mr snail, sorry Mrs. Snail, sorry Mrs snail, sorry Mr. Snail". And then repeat this, but inverting it to start with Mrs, snail. This normally isn't enough so I will start again, but starting with Mrs. Snail and invering it like before. If this int enough, I normally have to repeat the whole process backwards and forward until I have created an equilibrium in my mind.


2. If I look over my shoulder at something, I look over my other shoulder and try to match the feeling/ angle/ whatever that I did over the first shoulder. If that didn't feel right in one swift movement, I will repeat my actions backwards (starting with the second shoulder then returning to the first) HOWEVER it can be really bad and if my eye doesn't catch the same place/ thing I looked at the first time. I repeat until Ive done EXACTLY what I did/ saw the first time around.

3. Moving my fingers over my phone/ laptop screen. Even the slightest movement can feel wrong. I will move my fingers over the screen (either toughing it or just in the air) until it feels right. I'm trying to perfectly retrace my steps. But I get so stressed and I can not breath when this takes place. It's actually happening as I type this.

Do you find that your tics get very aggressive when you talk about them?

4. I feel overwhelmed that I can not breath in enough OR that I can open my eyes wide enough. I will sit there breathing in as much as possible and trying to open my eyes further an further. And I get so much stress when this is not physically possible.

5. Somtimes I get a flash of panic/ thought of death/ a bad memory and I will say abusive things to myself or just really weird things that I can't help saying and I keep repeating them until I feeling goes away

There are other things but I will leave it there for now.

I do not feel like something specifically bad is going to happen when I can't complete my tasks or find the 'just right' feeling. I feel an immense sense of dread, stress, pain in my chest, a crushing/ suffocating feeling in my thought. Severely tense and unsettled.

I hope this post wasn't completely dull, I just wanted to share some of my experiences and see if there's anyone who can relate.

There really needs to be more research into this condition. And we need to be heard and made to feel like we're not 'weird' for the way we feel and act!

Title: DAE have academic dishonesty based obsessions?
Text:
Hey guys,

I (F19) have been a college student for three semesters now. I really have been struggling with my morality based obsessions lately. Recently those obsessions have infiltrated into my school work. Despite never cheating, always following the rules, and caring more about academic dishonesty than the average student, I am always worried about getting “caught” for academic dishonesty. Sometimes I worry that I’ll do too well on an exam and I’ll be flagged for cheating. Sometimes I worry about sharing notes and study materials with other classmates, even though that is allowed. I’m just wondering if anyone else has these types of obsessions. Please, let me feel less crazy! Thank you all :)

Title: My OCD, the depression and anxiety, it's winning.
Text:
I'm not doing well in some of my classes at school, I haven't been running or working out nearly as much as I'd like, and I've been out of work for over two months. I'm also not involved at school like I was starting to be last semester. I'm back home right now because I've been feeling suicidal. My friends and family have been here for me, and I love them, but I can just barely function right now. I've been missing my ex, but she's doing so well and we couldn't be together anyway.

I've been off my medication, and I only just scheduled an appointment with my psychiatrist. I haven't been following my OCD schedule, but that also means I've gotten next to nothing done this semester. I ran away from CBT. I've been comparing myself to everyone my age (I'm 20, 21 in two months), and everyone seems to be doing so well. They're succeededing in school, being active physically and in clubs... They're going out with friends and you can just tell they're gonna look back on this as an amazing experience.

I'm paralyzed with fear about doing anything without resetting my schedule, but I don't have the motivation to do that (it's a lot of tedious work). I'm trying to hold on, but I feel so guilty. I feel like less of a man and more of a child, even though everyone has been so supportive. I can't do this anymore. I'm at a breaking point and I just want to disappear.

Text:
I get stuck in these cycles of fearing that there is something structurally wrong with my frontal lobe and that it’s the reason why my harm ocd/urges are so strong. Why would my own brain torture me against my will unless there was something knocked outta place up there?

I mean Aaron Hernandez had brain damage that went undetected and we see how that ended. I don’t want to become a killer because my brain is damaged and begins causing me to do things against my will.

Title: Helping son
Text:
My son (12M), has Autism, anxiety and OCD. His OCD is affecting him more and more and it’s getting hard to go anywhere. He has a lot of intrusive thoughts and worries about people’s reactions to him saying inappropriate things. The worry about that, though, makes him say them when he’s in new places. 

Most recently, he has obsessive worries over saying a racial slur and he has done it several times when going new places, like in Disney, getting a haircut, at an amusement park, etc. It makes him so upset because he is not racist at all and cares a lot about social justice and civil rights. We have been to several therapists, all of whom have no idea how to help him. Once he says it and nobody notices, he seems fine in the new place. He can’t seem to be calm and relaxed until it is said though. 

Just wondering if anyone has any ideas. Thanks!

I think the anxiety is so great that it's starting to hurt when it happens and yesterday he put it on and I started crying, he stopped right away and helped me with the thoughts and started apologizing 😪 I feel like I'm disturbing the relationship with these thoughts, Having sex now makes me anxious because I'm afraid of bad thoughts... Title: My partner has OCD
Text:
I (29M) have been with my girlfriend (31F) for about 2 1/2 years now, and we’ve been living together for about 1 1/2 years. 
She has contamination OCD. 

Her OCD has its ups and downs. One minute she’s got it under control and the next minute she panics because I took out the garbage and didn’t immediately take a shower. 


Anyway, she and I have built a good life together. There’s very little we disagree with. However, I’m slowly realizing that I’ve been walking on eggshells around her the entire time we’ve been together. I didn’t notice it initially because I was happy to make little accommodations to help her feel comfortable. For instance, showering at night before bed instead of in the morning like I used too. A very tiny change in my own life that actually made sense. Other things that made slightly less sense were things like not touching the trashcan unless I planned on sanitizing my hands with rubbing alcohol or taking a shower afterwards. 

I made these accommodations because I was in love with her and it seemed like a fair enough trade. 


Also just FYI she was able to minimize her OCD a lot when we first got together. It slowly got worse the following months after we were dating. 


Now, it’s gotten to the point where if I do one thing that her OCD hates, it’ll ruin the whole day for both of us. She gets upset at me because of OCD, and then I get upset because she’s upset. 


Anyway, we’ve tried talking about it many times and we’ve tried different things like me specifically not accommodating her. (Which doesn’t work because then she just ends up hating me). 


On top of the OCD which is by far the biggest factor, there are other little things about her that have bothered me that I’ve always known but now I’m seriously thinking about it more. (Things like she’s a bit of a hoarder and has extreme procrastination on certain things). Those small things in and of themselves don’t make me consider ending the relationship. But the OCD causing so much emotion and stress plus all the other stuff plus the stress of recent politics have really brought the status of our relationship to the forefront of both of our minds. 

We’ve talked about it of course we want to make it work. We love eachother a lot + we have 2 cats together. 



But I am starting to have my doubts. Do you guys have any advice for me? 

Feel free to direct me to any other sub btw. This one just seemed most applicable.

Title: Found a good way to manage real event ocd
Text:
I only recently learned I have ocd but have been trying to fix my brain for the last year and I found a good trick to manage the uncertain guilt from random memories. I try to separate myself from the events by imagining the person doing the action is not me but an identical clone of me. Same memories, experience, medicals issues, trauma, thought pattern etc.

Been doing this for a year and it's helped a ton since it's as simple as if it's fine for your identical clone then why is it not fine for you? Not a cure but shoving that in your brains face takes away a bit of its power. 

Also told my friend about it and it has been helping him with his non ocd guilt problems a lot as well.

Title: Does ERP not account for mental compulsions?
Text: So usually with my ocd the trigger is feeling off, the obsession will be wanting to do something in the right way then the compulsion will be doing something until it feels right. I would expose myself by triggering the fear of feeling off by doing something wrong then not reassuring myself or doing any mental compulsions I feel sufficiently anxious then it passes and I feel good it feels like im doing erp and its awesome. But I cant just stop mental compulsions very rarely im able to stop doing mental compulsions enough to where i can actually do erp and ive never been able to stop fully. The point of erp is to expose yourself without doing the compulsions but are you just screwed if your mental compulsions are bad enough that they interfere with the exposure?

Title: Is it too far fetched to say that ‘forced watching’ is basically what OCD is?
Text:
By forced watching I mean the torture method of showing someone unpleasant/gory videos and images repeatedly which inflect great discomfort and trauma on the tortured person. I couldn’t find the precise name for it but I hope you get what I mean. 

When I first heard of it, it instantly reminded me of how my OCD affects me. It feels like my brain is forcing me to watch unwanted sexual acts of people I care about and don’t want that stuff to happen at all costs. It feels like not only am I being forced to watch but the images and videos are TAILORED to me specifically to maximise the amount of discomfort, frustration and desperation to escape.

Now I know that things like this shouldn’t be compared, both are horrible and unpleasant to experience and I do not intend to downplay either one. However is it too far fetched to say that intrusive thoughts and obsessions in OCD are somewhat like being exposed to ‘forced watching’?

Title: Anyone else have diagnosed OCD that isn’t linked to cleaning?
Text:
I have had a diagnosis of OCD since I was young. Unlike the stereotypical portrayal of OCD, mine doesn’t present as an obsession with cleaning. Instead I have to be in the vicinity of a ‘safe adult’. I realise that this is the strangest concept for anyone else to contemplate but for me it’s life. I also clock watch a lot and have found out that the two are linked. Before anyone gets on their high horse and tells me to ‘push past the compulsions’ or ‘challenge the behaviour’, I would like to point out that my brain is wired this way, it isn’t changing and it’s likely that I know my own limits when it comes to how far I can push myself. I take medication for my OCD and this means that I can pretty much live life as ‘normal’ but I still have evenings like this evening. 

I am currently staying in a hotel due to being away with work and I am finding it incredibly hard to settle. My OCD has decided to take the reins which is also making it extremely hard to get to sleep. Tonight the only way that I could get it to settle was by driving to the hospital carpark and sitting there and working. I realise this probably seems extremely strange but to fill in some gaps, I have had two really bad cases of pneumonia where I have been hospitalised and the routine and regimental side of hospitals now seem to calm me - odd right? 

So I’m sat here wondering if anyone else lives in the same strange OCD bubble and if they have ever needed a ‘break’ so have gone to a ‘safe place’ or done a certain routine that may seem ridiculous to anyone else but that works for them?

Title: Reading about OCD makes me feel so seen that I cry nearly every time (not diagnosed)
Text:
Long time mental illness sufferer, I've been diagnosed with Bipolar, PTSD, and GAD in the past and have been on an array of medication but lately have been med free. I've noticed some ocd style thinking in my anxiety in the past, but my bipolar disorder was always way more severe so I put all of my effort into handling that and not really focusing on how to curb my anxiety. However, the last 5 or 6 months, my bipolar symptoms have taken a backseat and I have been experiencing what seems like some pretty intense OCD symptoms. I have always kinda felt like there is a little bit of something else going on, and have had psychiatrists tell me I seem like i have BPD and ADHD traits but never enough to be diagnosed/tested subclinical on those assessments. I know bipolar is very tricky and can come with a wide variety of symptoms so I have just been kinda lumping in these OCD symptoms with bipolar, but at this point they have started to seem a lot more distinct, and causing me issues with falling into obsessions and compulsions for like 4+ hours on end. I have a couple friends with OCD who have been in OCD bootcamps lately who have been a lot more open about their struggles with OCD and it has made me feel more comfortable talking to them about my struggles. They have all individually said that it seems to them like I have OCD, which has led me to research OCD a lot more and let me tell you, reading descriptions of moral scrupulosity plus your guys' descriptions of your experiences with  other OCD themes has made me feel seen in a way that I have never felt before and I find myself crying every time something resonates with me. There are so many things that I deal with that I cannot put into words with friends or with therapists that i have wound up keeping to myself that I have finally seen described by OCD, and I feel honestly less confused and worried than I used to. My current therapist is an ACSW who, bless her heart, doesn't know much about bipolar or OCD but it is all I can afford right now, but I am scheduling an appointment with a psychiatrist soon to reevaluate getting back on bipolar meds and I will definitely be bringing up the likelihood of OCD.  Tagging this as a win because if I do end up having OCD, figuring this out is definitely a win

TLDR: this subreddit has made me feel so seen, and i will be talking to a doctor about OCD because never have i before related to anything as much as i have related to your experiences with OCD

Title: OCD and a fiance that doesn't understand. - Rant / Help request
Text:
Hey all, thanks for stopping by.  I have a very sweet and caring Fiance who I love dearly.  However, I've been through the wringer in more ways than one.

1) I've suffered from relatively severe OCD since about 2005.

2) Nine years ago I slipped and fell down stairs at work.  My TH11 vertibrae broke + was compressed leading to severe back pain.  Especially when lifting.

3) In mid 2023 I had a brain surgery to remove a big aneurysm that couldn't be treated with a coiling.  This lead to a small stroke which resulted in epilepsy.  While we're not sure if the epilepsy will go away or not, I am on medication for it.

  
The medication I'm on heightens my anxiety pretty severely.  Thanks to the higher anxiety my OCD flares up.  I was told today that when I have to stop in the middle of a store or somewhere to deal with it she tells me it's embarrassing.

Then about 2-3 years ago her son fell (who is disabled), nothing serious.  It was in the parking lot and I have severe issues bending over and picking things up from the ground, much less a child at 90lbs or so.  So an older man came over and helped out.  She said this was so embarrassing because a "man twice my age could bend over and help him (the son) up".

She claims that she sees these issues and wants to help, which I believe.  But on the other hand she tells me she's just used to the "man being able to be strong" blah blah blah.  

I'm not completely disabled, I get her wheelchair in and out of the car which weighs 20lbs numerous times a day at times.  I go through a storage unit and move heavy boxes from one side to another etc.  But because I'm unable to pick up her child from the ground and another had to help I'm suddenly weak.

It's making me depressed.  I feel like she has no faith in me what-so-ever.  And at times either knowingly or not she'll throw some jabs in there.  And when I get upset at it I'm either "too sensitive" or have anger issues.

At times I feel like just breaking the engagement off and saying screw it.  Rant over, now how should I deal with this? I am only human and I have pretty thick skin.  But it's different when the woman who you love does it.

Thanks for reading.
