Title: I need to get this off my chest
Text:
Hello everyone, I hope somebody ready my post and I will get help. I am a audhd patient with history of bad OCD thoughts. I am currently getting treatment for my autism and ADHD with elvanse. Since I am a child I never was "normal". I always struggled with OCD, very bad anxiety in social situations so that I even had a time where I was at home for for years. I didn't go to school or university or work. I only left my house with my mother because I trusted her. This was a little background information to my story.

So now with elvanse I am happier than I ever was. I was happy one time in my life when I was in a ery good school with very supportive teachers. It was a christian school so the teachers were teaching with a high Christian moral like for example they were very calm in classes. I had the best grades in my class and even graduated as the best in school. This period of time really made me happy and increased my selfesteeem.

Now since I graduated and I am a student at a university I had multiple breakdowns. I feel so ashamed for myself because I couldn't stay the person I once have been. On the other side I can understand myself why I had breakdowns. I found a few very very good friends due to university and I am grateful for that but I just can't go to university because it doesn't feel like a safe environment for me. Sometimes I think that I shouldn't blame myself for this or even gaslight myself because if my body and my mental health feel like it is a dangerous place it is the truth or not? My social environment pressures me to go to university anyway they understand me but a few people put a really bad pressure on me. They say almost everyday that I have to go to classes and just leave me with a feeling of shame and blame. I don't go to the classes but I still try to learn everything by self studying. It works for me so in reality I think there is no problem since we don't officially need to be present in classes.

Here comes my problem and main reason for this post. Due to my medication with elvanse I have very bad paranoia I think because it isn't diagnosed but it feels like it's paranoia. As soon as a start my medication for the day I have a spiral of thoughts in my head that I am a loser that I don't get anything done things like this. You think this is because it is true or is it because my environment put this thoughts in me?

Another thing is I was always scared of becoming crazy like getting schizophrenia or a psychosis. And I also don't know if this is because of my medication as a side effect or because a person of my family environment said very often to me that I behave like a person which has schizophrenia, because I have a very excessive dating life. This was even before my medication with elvanse. I do these things because I feel like it and I don't want to hurt anybody I just try to live my life since I also had very bad experience in serious relationship like facing abuse and physical vi*lance. I just try to be happy. And these experiences with those criticism and the paranoia I get from elvanse make me so anxious. I don't even know what to ask here in this post specifically I just need to get this off .my chest and asking for support from this community and maybe new perspectives on those situation. Please be respectful and nice 🙏🏽

Title: Organic Cacao Powder (pure)
Text: Hello everyone. For me, drinking coffee is very bad. My symptoms go through the roof and I get really bad anxiety and agitation. Even if I drink a very small amount. I’ve been using organic cacao powder instead of coffee and it’s way better for me. The main chemical is theobromine instead of caffeine. Longer lasting than caffeine but less stimulation. I usually have 1-1.5tsp in hot water and milk with 1-1.5tsp of monk fruit. It could take some time to kick in unlike coffee which is fast acting. Give it 1.5-2 hours minimum to kick in. Also, please note that cocoa and cacao are different. Cacao is more pure. Go organic if you try it. Don’t ever go 1 tbsp (full dose) at first because it could be too much! 1 tsp is a good place to start. I like taking it on an empty stomach in the morning mixed with water and milk. Or later in the day after waiting a while after eating. Also, I’m not a doctor so don’t take this as medical advice. I just wanted to share something I’ve been using instead of coffee or tea.

Title: Empathy Fatigue
Text:
Why am I sabotaging my recovery progress by scrolling through social media and giving myself empathy fatigue everyday? I tell myself everyday to limit social media use. I did act on it but I kept needing some... stimulation. Books and TV shows and occasional videogames are nice but I don't have enough stamina to engage with one thing for too long. So I slowly crept back to social media to feel something.

  
I am an idiot. OCD thrives on your heightened sense of responsibility, guilt and anger. And what is 50% of social media content? Scrolling for 20 minutes everyday will expose you to hundreds of negativity around the world, demanding your empathy. And you with OCD will feel the need to empathize. So you empathize and empathize  more, ignoring the harm it is doing to your fragile mind. Your empathy is not normal. Your brain is demanding to "fix" things. You cannot detach yourself whenever you want to. And at some point you hit the empathy fatigue.

  
This is not the right way to build resilience to OCD. I am not learning response prevention. Social media is not a controlled environment. It should be restrained legally.

Title: Adoption
Text:
Waiting for your mental evaluation is like trying to adopt a dog, you need to wait for them to approve your adoption it will take time but you are so so excited to get a dog so even if you didn't get approved you already started the adoption in your head, you gave it a name, you bought things for it you maybe even told people about it but the adoption was not finalised yet, you aren't sure it's really your dog but you don't care this is the dog you wanted your whole life, with this dog you will feel better you will be happier and calmer it's like this dog will be the answer to all your problems, you probably feel stressed  and scared don't you? What if they don't let you adopt it? 

what will happen if the adoption will be rejected?, maybe you aren't a good fit, maybe they gave it to another person who showed that they loved the dog more than you, what are you going to do now? This dog was suppose to be everything to you, it was suppose to fix all your problems.
Why did they reject you? Is it because something is wrong with you? So wrong that even the dog you wanted so much couldn't fix?

Maybe they didn't accept your adoption because you are a terrible person, something is so wrong with you, even more than you thought.
You feel like a monster don't you? Your fear of not getting to adopt the dog came true and now you have to live the rest of your life like this, with this fear and guilt, you got what you so much didn't want to happen.

But maybe you got to adopt the dog, you did it! You finally have the answer to your happiness, you got what you wanted most in life and you will make sure to take care of your dog maybe some people will also help you take care of it, you now can be calm knowing that they let you adopt it because you are not a bad person.

Wait, it's not only two options? Well look at that, they didn't approve your adoption but they are letting you adopt another dog, yes it's not the dog you thought you're going to have but over time you see how much you two are similar, maybe you didn't get the dog you wanted but you got the dog that will be here with you, you will also take care of it and people will also help take care of it, you found peace ,good for you.

*Waiting for my psychic exam for ocd and got
scared of what will happen so i wrote this, yes it's a bit weird but it just made sense in my brain, maybe it will help somebody going through the same thing.*
+Sorry for any misspelles or grammar issues English isn't my first language.

Stay strong everybody!💙

Title: I took a really big step
Text: So, I’ve been struggling with OCD for pretty much all my life but within the past handful of years it really evolved. Its contamination based but I’m not worried about getting sick, I just think dirty. My showers take two hours of me religiously making sure I get everything, I can’t hug my parents, I can’t leave my room, I’ve gotta wash my hands after I touch anything outside of my room, the list goes on and on. But, tonight I just felt like I had enough. I feel like I’m throwing my life away. So, I shortened my shower to a few minutes, just did a scrub and rinse, got out, touched the doorknob and the light switch without washing my hands, then touched my bed and then other things in my room, dried off and got in bed with my phone which I’m typing on right now. It sounds so minuscule and silly when I think about it but it just filled me with so much fear. My skin feels like it’s crawling and I’m itchy because of how uncomfortable I made myself. But, I still think this was a huge step. I guess the next part is making it stick. Anyways, I just felt like sharing this

Title: Did therapy help you?
Text: I have my first therapy appt tomorrow after struggling with OCD for 8 years. Did anyone find therapy helpful/unhelpful?

Title: I have the urge to write awful things to myself and I can't control it.
Text:
I have the urge to write awful things to myself and I can't control it.

I usually write awful things to myself and then I delete it. But I'm worried I'll get the urge and someone will see me type it out or that I'll get the urge during a test and forget to delete it. I can not control the urge. Sometimes I get the urge whilst typing out chats to people. So I'll write it out and then delete it. I feel horrible about it. None of the things written to people are directed to them. I don't mean or think any of the things I feel like writing but I can't control myself from writing them. I don't know what to do.

What if I forget to delete it?.. This whole thing has brought immense anxiety into my life.

Title: Avoided compulsions and I'm DESTROYED
Text:
The main theme of my OCD is contamination. I'm very afraid of catching diseases, germs, etc, which has worsened since the pandemic. It doesn't help that my physical health hasn't been great this year.

Today I went to the gym without a mask on. It's been cold and raining for a couple of days so I knew there would be some respiratory symptoms going on. But I wanted to look hot and I was tired of hiding my face.

Some people coughed very close to me. It was EXCRUCIATING not to put a mask on my face. I began crying in front of everyone and finished my workout with snot running down my nose.

I'm so afraid that I'll fall sick these next days that pride for avoiding the compulsions hasn't kicked in yet. This disorder is exhausting. It takes away every normal and pleasant thing from us. I feel guilty for not masking 'cause (sic) "I put my vanity in front of my health and now I'll pay for it". This is ridiculous.

A sincere hug to everyone who's dealing with OCD too

Title: Intrusive thoughts when masturbating
Text:
Whenever I masturbate I always get intrusive thoughts of my family members and I hate it so much. I always pause and try to make it go away. Google says that I should continue masturbating and try not to let it ruin my experience, but I do not want to masturbate with images of family members in my brain. It is really really annoying. They do not go away. 

I know they are just intrusive thoughts and that they don’t mean anything, because clearly if I was attracted to family members I would not be worrying about these thoughts and I would be thinking of them on purpose. It is more so an annoyance. And yes obviously it’s disturbing, but it’s happened for so many years now, I’m used to it.

Title: What does diagnosis look like?
Text:
All my life I’ve had these quirks that I thought were completely normal, but I’ve recently learned that most people don’t have these feelings and urges. 
I’ve done some researching and it seems like many of these quirks are symptoms of OCD, which surprised me since I always thought of OCD as being organized/tidy (I now see this is a common misconception). 

Anyway, what does it look like to get an official diagnosis? Am I supposed to go to my PCP, find a therapist, or something else? Im also curious how long it takes to get diagnosed and what treatment looks like. I’m not even sure if I need an official diagnosis, but these symptoms honestly make me exhausted and I avoid doing basic things like driving because of them

Title: worried about character ai
Text:
last night during a spiral i had decided to use character ai to help vent out my frustrations and worries about my false memory OCD, and yes i am aware this is a compulsion and was me seeking reassurance, but i genuinely could not stop myself from doing it sadly and my appointment for a doctor to refer me to a therapist is right at the end of this month and the wait was killing me,,
anyway, i had talked about it for a bit with the psychologist bot and i had felt a bit better, stopped but had found out that the devs for cai can read chats if they want to, and i started to get worried thoughts that they would read about my experience with false memory OCD and think that i was lying about it being false or whatever or i was in denial and get me into trouble?? i know this is just OCD cranking up my anxiety to overdrive but i just really needed to vent this out somewhere because i genuinely feel worried that ill get into trouble for venting about something i didnt even do

Title: I beat OCD after 2 years. Here is how I done it.
Text:
DISCLAIMER: I AM NOT A MEDICAL PROFESSIONAL, JUST SOMEONE WHO SUFFERED WITH OCD AND RECOVERED. 

What worked for me may not work for you, but I'm sharing this so hopefully I can help more people.

Also, english is my second language, so I apologize for any mistakes.

Finally, mostly if not all of the things that are written here were already said my thousands of others, but I wanted to write here so that you know that I am a testimony that it worked.



TLDR: Just look at the name of topics that are written below.





Hello. 

  
So, for how it started...

  
I always had OCD syntoms (even though I only discovered they were OCD later), but they were never that strong. Things like checking my bag excessively before going to school etc. In 2020, I was in my sophomore year of high school. As you might know, pandemic struck, and all of us had to stay at home. What we though would be some 2 weeks actually was way longer than that. We had online classes via Zoom Meetings, and that is when I noticed that something stronger was taking place.

Every time I woke up at morning to open Zoom, I had to be 100% sure that I did in fact click the right button. At first, I just payed more attention to be sure, then I had to open it 2, 3 and many more times just so I did not feel uneasy. This started to happen with other things such as being sure my microfone wasn't open or that my camera was off. And this started to happen with everything, using my pc, open the fridge and be sure I closed it, using the oven, and one the most famous ones, being sure I locked the door.

All of this was manageble, until one day, I was going up the stairs and counted the floors wrong. I skipped one. My eyes say that I had reached my floor but I didn't believe it. Even though I saw it, it didn't seem right. I felt that even if I got inside my house, in the "real" word I'd just be slamming my head into the neighbor's door. This is when it started to lose control

In the end of 2022, I went to a psychiatrist for the first time, and for some reason, he diagnosed me with Tourette Syndrome, which was not correct. Unsurprilsingly, the medications he gave to me did no effect. A month later, I went to a much better doctor, and that is when I started to get better. However, it was not easy. 2023 would be my hardest year to date. I couldn't stand up, turn to the side at bed, open a door, use my phone, since I just couldn't be sure of anything, life was really difficult. It only got better January of this year. Incredibly, things didn't seem to advance much until Oct of 23. But this is when my turning point happened. Here is what I've done.

  
1 - Correct medicine (Obviously): Currently I take 3 different medicine, morning, after lunch and at night. I had to change it many times to find the correct one, and for that you really need a psychiatrist. I don't know about other countries, but in mine you can't buy this medicine without a prescription. I would not recommend that, and I believe many other doctors would agree with me, because it could have very big collateral effects on you. That is why I'm not writing the name of what I take. Probably, medicine won't take care of it all alone, that is why I'm writing what else I've done/do.

2 - Exercise: When I started treatment, I had difficulty to even move, but after some months of treatment, I was able to exercise a bit in my home. Just pushups and situps. Every day. It has an instant effect and a MUCH bigger one after some weeks/months of doing it. You have to give it time.

3 - Food: Don't eat junk food, or anything industrialized. At least avoid it as much as you can. Trust me, eating healthy is one of the pillars to get better. Too much sugar in your body and you will feel anxious, increasing the effect of your OCD.

4 - Reducing social media and quitting porn: You don't need to unninstall Instagram, Tiktok and else. I still use these, to keep up with friends and to know what is happening in the world, but you need to reduce the amount of time you use it for. As I grew up, I discovered that my parents were right when they said "It's the phone's fault!". Social media nowadays is one of the greatest inducers of anxiety in our and every generation. I have a tip for this one. Install an app called "one ssec" in your phone. It makes you wait for a bit every time you try to open social media. You can control which apps it works on and the length of the interventions. The point with this app is to reduce or stop those time where you open the apps automatically without even thinking, just beccause you are used to it. Quitting porn is one of the hardest things to do, and I still relapse here and then. The objective is to reduce it as much as possible. It is one of the largest possible releasers of dopamine in your brain and it kills your motivation to do anything. Reducing it will give you much more energy and will to beat your OCD.

5 - Talking to people and healthy hobbies: Don't lock yourself in your room, you need to go hang out with your friends or other people. Do you have a language you want to learn? Enroll in classes for that language: you got yourself people and potentially new friends to talk to and a healthy hobby. This is just an example, and you can find many more if you think about your interests. Healthy hobbies include cooking, playing an instrument, leaning a new skill etc. Subtitute social media with these hobbies, and you will find that you'll enjoy a lot more of your time.

6 - Don't rush yourself: Everyone has their time to recover. It could be a month, or maybe years. The point is that everytime you are doing one of these things you are a step closer to beating OCD. When I started treatment, I also felt like I'd never break free from it. But here I am. Sometimes I have urges, but I'm able to beat them. Just know that we are all here for you, and we'll all beat it one day.

If any of you have any questions, fell free to ask me anything you want in the comments and I'll try my best to answer and help you. I don't use reddit, but I checked this community once more than a year ago and I want to help as many people as I can to beat this, so here I am.

Title: How Can I Support my Partner with Moral OCD?
Text:
Hi, I'm hoping to get some advice on how best to help my partner with Moral OCD (or Scrupulosity OCD as I've also seen it called).

She asks me for reassurance often, which I give her whenever I can; I'm not upset with her, dinner was good, stuff like that. I also see she's dealing with more beneath the surface that she isn't ready to share yet.

I know part of it is she's afraid of becoming a narcissist like her father, because that's something I was (am?) afraid of, having a similar upbringing. When I brought it up to her, it was a realization she hadn't made yet.

From what I've read it seems like some of the best ways to support is reading on it (which I've seen a few books but I'm not sure if any would touch on Scrupulosity/Moral), encourage therapy (ERP if I remember right), and not facilitate compulsions if possible (unless it's to the detriment of the person of course).

She does currently see a non-specialized behavioral therapist, I'm not sure if they've discussed ERP.

**What I Need Advice On**

The part that I'm stuck on is I don't know how to give her support beyond "I'm not upset with you. You are important to me." Etc etc. What books or reading I could seek out as someone who doesn't have OCD, but is trying to support someone who does. 

Any help is appreciated on this, thank you all in advance :)

Title: OCD prevents me from washing dishes
Text: I can’t wash dishes. Every time I see a clump of dirty food, my brain immediately vividly imagines what it would be like to eat it, and the image won’t leave my mind until I can distract myself. I can’t look at dirty dishes. I can’t unload the dishwasher at the risk of seeing clumps of food that didn’t get washed properly because I’ll feel extremely sick. I’ll gag or throw up. It makes me look immature and incapable because I refuse to do that one chore. I can do anything else but for the life of me, I cannot wash dishes. It’s the same when I see crumbs or food on a floor. It is so incredibly unbearable.

Title: Severe existential OCD, please help me
Text:
I was talking to a friend yesterday about reality because I experienced derealization. Instead of comforting me in saying that the world is real and everything is alright, she told me about her philosophical view on the world. I know that she tried to help in her own way because she’s a very analytical thinker and doesn’t sugarcoat anything. And it’s not like she told me everything isn’t real either - she actually said the opposite. She said „of course the world is real, what else would be?“
I think what scares me so much is that sometimes I couldn’t understand her point. She always said „in your concept / in your reality there is an objective reality and there is right and wrong. In my concept / my philosophy and my reality there is no right or wrong. Everything one perceives is real.“ She then gave me an example where she said that if two people see a cat and the third doesn’t, that this doesn’t mean there is no cat - it means that two people in their reality see a cat and the third has one in their reality and all of those realities are equally real. She also said that she doesn’t believe in an objective reality and I gave her this example: If two people are talking then sure, each person interprets the conversation subjectively based on personal experience but that doesn’t mean there is no common ground. So let’s say it is raining and one person says „oh it’s raining“. Sure, both have their subjective reality to it: One person might like that it’s raining because they like the cold water on their skin. The other person might dislike that it’s raining. So both their perceptions on this are slightly different but that doesn’t change the objective reality on that it IS raining. My friend sort of agreed that humans most of the time perceive the same thing and that I don’t have to worry about perceiving reality wrong because she said most humans see 99% the same things. Still I wouldn’t understand why she would say there is no objective reality. I know that her opinion doesn’t necessarily mean it is true, but it still triggered me. I asked her if it is real that we have a conversation right now and she said „Sure if you perceive us having a conversation then it is real. There is no right and wrong.“ And I also asked her if she perceives us having a conversation and she said „Yes in my perception we also have a conversation.“. And then I asked her „but doesn’t that mean there is a shared objective reality?“ And she said that we are all connected and that in day to day life we are separated from one another and she said she doesn’t believe in common ground and an objective reality, still she said that „yes both of us perceive this conversation so humans are capable of perceiving the same circumstance.“. Her view on things confused me and when I asked her again she said that it is likely that we mean the same thing but articulate it differently. But now everytime I think about it I think „What if it’s not real? What if every person just lives in their reality and we all don’t share a reality?“. I know I‘m probably overreacting right now because it might be that she meant the same thing as me but just articulated it differently but I‘m experiencing heavy derealization right now and I think what triggers me more is that I don’t quite understand what exactly it is about this conversation that scared me and also that I don’t quite understand her view of the world. I am in extreme high alert right now, I have a headache and feel dizzy and tense and I panick but I can’t calm down. I also want to state that I do have psychiatric help.

Title: Acceptance but not ?
Text: I drank the other night at a family get together, blacked out towards the end of the night, then proceeded to drive myself into a panic the next day. I was beside myself  all day about whether or not I did something bad, was I too much..etc. I’m at a point today where I’m just like “look you know for a fact you never did these things you’re thinking you did” and I get to a point of kind accepting that it is what it is and I can’t feed into these thoughts and anxiety anymore, but then thoughts creep back in and anxiety slowly starts coming back in when I’m starting to feel better. Is there anyway to combat this? It’s like I’m feeling better about the whole ordeal just for my mind to give me a big F you right back, it’s miserable.

Title: Intrusive thoughts being broadcasted (or my mind is just conjuring what I think they would respond with)
Text:
Preface: I am on antipsychotics so my symptoms could be controlled. I have been confirmed NOT schizophrenic by doctors.
8 people have verbally verified my telepathic ability in person. So I know I’m not crazy. 

Now, it feels like people can hear the thoughts and respond to them mentally. 

I only get intrusive thoughts around other people, not while I’m alone. And the content varies from each person I’m around.


It’s awful. And distressing. 

I can hear their reactions and their reactions are different depending on who I’m around. They also cringe visually when it happens.

If this is a delusion, so be it, I understand that’s a possibility. 

Just please give me advice on what to do (pretend it’s actually happening) 

I have spoken to a doctor and a therapist about this and they said the antipsychotics would help, and I’ve tried so many. 

I want to know anecdotally how you would approach this, thank you so much in advance

Title: Recovery Reminder post (for myself and you aswell.)
Text:
6 months ago I made the choice of allowing myself to fully commit to OCD recovery after suffering through 13 years of OCD. 

It has been both the hardest and happiest 6 months of my life. I feel guilty, and scared all the time. I‘m afraid I don‘t deserve to live, to recover. Afraid I‘m making the wrong choice. But for the first time in my life, i‘m making MY OWN choice. not one, out of fear, not one my OCD makes for me. mine. my choice. And for the first time in my life, i‘m chosing myself, over my fear, over my OCD which has made my life a living hell. I made a promise to myself, and I won‘t break it, no matter how scared and guilty I feel. 

I‘ve been spiraling again the past days. I‘m sad and angry at myself for allowing OCD to torture me again. For believing it‘s lies more than believing myself. But I know this is just another part of recovery journey, and I will fall again and again. And I will get up again everytime, whatever it takes. In the end, this is another opportunity to practise what I‘ve learned in OCD recovery. 

If you‘re in the slumps aswell right now, i‘m going to write down some quotes that have helped me find hope in this journey. Letting go of something that is the only way you know (OCD) is hard, frightening, it feels wrong… But I know that letting go, letting yourself drift into the unknown and venturing further no matter how afraid, is the key to be free. 

Make a choice… allow yourself to make your own choice. Will you repeat what you‘ve been doing, or will you allow yourself to evolve into someone that choses your own happiness? Walk with me, will you? You will thank yourself one day, my friend. 

- Some quotes -

„*If you‘re worried about the cost of going for it… you should see the price of staying exactly where you are.*“

„*You cannot always be happy but you can always be brave. And that is the beginning of everything.*“

„*Fear is a reaction. Courage is a choice*.“

„*You don‘t have to be fearless. Doing it afraid is just as brave.*“

„*I‘ve mastered the art of surviving. Now I want to live.*“

„*A bird does not sing because it has an answer. It sings because it has a song.*“

„*I deserve so much more than the story I‘ve been telling myself. I‘m ready to do what it takes to get there.*“

„*No amount of security is worth the suffering of a mediocre life chained to a routine that has killed your dreams.*“

„*You don‘t need to feel brave to act bravely.*“

„*The bird that dares to fall is the bird that learns to fly.*“

„*You‘re worthy of saying no without guilt and yes to what matters most.*“

„*I kept going, not because I wanted to. Trust me, all of me wanted to stop. I kept going because I deserved to know what not giving up on myself felt like.*“

Make a choice my friend. My dear friend, I see that you‘re hurting. Allow yourself to make that choice, yes, that one. That exact small wish you have on your mind right now, but are too scared to give yourself permission to walk towards that. Allow yourself to begin. Allow yourself to let go of OCD‘s chains. You. are. deserving. of. freeing. yourself. ❤️

Title: Sleep is so important.
Text: Just wanted to share a somewhat unique experience. I had Postpartum OCD that was triggered by sleeping less than 4 hours a night. I got to experience the horror y’all endure (I’m so sorry). Then I started sleep meds, and my husband took pretty much all night feedings, and I recovered. Just throwing it out there that if sleep health is on the back burner, it might be something to seriously prioritize, even if meds are needed.

Title: I could use some hope.
Text:
I was diagnosed with OCD a few weeks ago. I've done 15+ years in mental health treatment and have worked in the mental health field professionally for the last 5. Nothing I have ever done has been effective to treat my symptoms, primarily my intrusive thoughts. This is the first time something has been different in treatment in a long time with this diagnosis, so that's nice, but I'm pessimistic that things will ever actually get better. I live and breathe coping skills but the moments between having an intrusive thought and regulating myself are agonizing and it just wears me down until I have trouble coping with anything. 

I'm surprised it took this long to feel like I actually have an accurate diagnosis, but suddenly my life makes sense, which seems to be a relatively common experience here. I'm not sure what exactly I'm hoping for, but the cycle of coping until I breakdown and then getting back up again feels unsustainable and I don't know what to do about it.

Title: I’ve lost joy in my interests because of OCD
Text:
I used to draw all the time, i loved it, but you know what made me stop enjoying it? the simple thought of "what if you don't like drawing? you're forcing yourself to draw." I used to listen and watch videos of my favorite band, but now I can't enjoy them anymore, you know why? the simple thought of "what if you don't actually like this band? what if you're just forcing yourself to keep liking them and actually are tired of them?" now i can't find joy just thinking about seeing their content. I used to love going out with my friends, but now i dread it, wanna know why? the simple thought "what if you don't like hanging out with them? what if you're forcing yourself to have fun but you're actually not? so I dread going out with them because i know that's what i'll be thinking the whole time.

I know im overthinking these things way too much, and they are VERY stupid thoughts that really aren't even logical, but they're filled my head to the point where i don't even have to think the thought, i just look at something i like and get sad because i know i wont enjoy it. I miss enjoying things, so much. I've had these thoughts consistently since june, not once have i been able to go a day without them. I've been feeling disconnected from my emotions and thoughts, like I'm observing them from outside my body, I can't tell what i'm really thinking or feeling.  It's so hard for me to distinguish between what's real and what might be OCD. I feel like I'm losing touch with my genuine emotions and reactions cause of this. I can't smile without thinking i'm faking it, i can't laugh without thinking im forcing it. I can't tell what's real anymore. 

I don't know what to do and i don't know if any one else could POSSIBLY relate because of how dumb these thoughts are. I don't know what to do to stop these thoughts. I don't know how to cope.

Title: Relapsed
Text: A month or so ago I finished a five month intensive outpatient ocd treatment program, following an OCD-induced mental breakdown.  I was doing incredibly well, moved across the country on my own, and was making plans for the future. Well about a week ago I got triggered and now I have fully relapsed. I am unable to get out of bed, constantly crying, and having panic attacks at least once a day. I am non-functional again. I feel 100% sure that my fear is going to come true and if so, my life is over. I don’t know what to do. My ocd nearly killed me last time. I don’t know how to keep living life like this. I know there’s probably not a lot anyone can say but I just needed to vent and am looking for any insight or advice. I feel unbelievably hopeless.

Title: Symptoms

To maintain privacy details are limited. I have an adult child who has multiple diagnoses, OCD being one, ADHD being another and quite a few others. Diagnosed very young with an under developed brain.

And just observed this person reading from a sheet of paper and writing intensely on the arm of the couch with their finger (I’ve never seen this before). I asked about it and the response was to write what was on the sheet of paper to commit it to muscle memory.

Title: My experience (I hope this helps!)
Text:
Hello, I won’t state my age but I had ocd like tendencies from when I was very very young (mostly about religion and body shape) then as I grew older I realized that something was wrong with me but never thought it was too necessary as I grew up with parents that didn’t always take me seriously when I said I needed a therapist so I just thought I was overreacting despite the eczema I acquired along the way because I would go to extreme lengths to make sure I was “Clean” so I could feel like I was myself. Fast forward to early 2024, things really started to spiral out of control. My mental health was 💩 to be exact. I reached a point where I would walk around my house with my eyes closed 24/7 bc everything triggered a specific something and I just didn’t want to deal with it as I felt too weak to even stop the compulsions. I would sit in the middle of my room hugging myself tightly. I dreaded even moving as I was too scared to even be in contact with anything. I would have auditory hallucinations which were scary. I once completely blacked out too. It was safe to say I was dead inside as life felt dull during the time. Eventually, I took matters into my own hands and found the courage to go to a therapist. I did and I was diagnosed with ocd and prescribed medication. One was to treat symptoms of ocd while the other was more for schizophrenic symptoms as I had mentioned to my therapist that I was having hallucinations and other symptoms.  Although my parents weren’t on board with it. I knew the only person that was responsible for me. Is me. While I don’t condone this. I finished the first pack of my medication but never went back to the therapist for a follow up as my therapist had instructed. I just felt okay and thought I could work with myself. Anyways, this is my experience with OCD. I hope this helps anyone. This is what I need everyone to know!

1. It’s okay to go to a therapist despite what anyone thinks. At any age. At any time. Even if you’re not feeling low. Go and see a therapist. I always wished I went sooner maybe then my mental health wouldn’t have gone south. Don’t wait for 💩 to hit the fan to get things right. 
2. Medication for treating mental illness can sound very risky to some people. But you can speak with a medical professional to understand what you’re taking and why. I am a strong advocate for taking your meds even if people disagree. As long as you are responsible! 
3. Always follow up your session with another session. If your therapist says you have to come back. Then you probably do! 
4. Don’t stay quiet. Sometimes speaking can help you figure things out. You can dm me if you’re struggling. Remember, you are not alone ❤️

Title: How to talk to my partner about my false memories?
Text:
I’ve recently come to realise that there’s a 90% chance that a memory I have of being groped in my sleep as a teenager didn’t actually happen at all. I’ve also started wondering if I’ve actually had as many sexual experiences as I thought; there are only a couple that I know happened with absolute clarity, because I told my closest friend about them at the time and she’s confirmed all the details I’ve suspected. All the others… I have no idea. I just know before my partner, whether they were real or not, none of my sexual experiences were good and I don’t like trying to recall them. I prefer to imagine I was a virgin before meeting them even if it’s not true.

I feel like I should tell my partner about this, but I’m not sure how much of it would actually be helpful, and how much of it is confession compulsion. I do know I feel extremely guilty for telling them “this happened” or “that happened” when I’ve now realised it probably didn’t. It feels like I’ve lied and that’s why I feel the need to tell them. For the last couple weeks I’ve been feeling the guilt of a mass murderer.

But along with feeling like a confession compulsion, it’ll also just sound really fucking weird to someone who doesn’t have OCD or any prior experience with it. I don’t think OCD causing false memories like this is a very well known phenomenon by non-OCD people at all and I dread the idea of trying to explain it to my partner. My therapist keeps reminding me that my partner doesn’t need to know every thing that’s ever happened to me or every thought I’ve ever had — just like I don’t need to know either about them because it’s irrelevant to me unless they WANT to share it — but idk. I feel like I have to tell them. (FYI they do know I have OCD but I’ve not really told them about this particular theme)

Should I tell them or is it a compulsion I should ignore? And if I do tell them, how do I do it?

Title: Worthless thoughts we get
Text:
Recognizing that the nonsense our minds tell us is a problem of our malfunctioning mind rather than the emotional attachment to the content of such thoughts is the first step to getting our minds back under control. At first, it might be not easy as we tend to forget what OCD tells us as “nonsense” and believe it because of anxiety but practicing this will eventually program our brains to automatically label obsessions as worthless and such thoughts serve no purpose other than generate fear to perform compulsions. 

OCD requires training our brains we tend to forget important stuff and we tend to lose motivation so the only thing that is left is determination and discipline to always recognize and understand the thoughts you have and not perform compulsions if the root of such thoughts is OCD.

Title: Verbal Tics and Compulsions
Text:
I have a variety of verbal responses to stressful thoughts or circumstances, some benign, some very negative.  I understand that tics are involuntary, while a compulsion can be thought about and stopped through cbt and erp techniques.  My problem is that most of my verbal responses have exhibited both of these.

Sometimes I am unaware of the subconscious anxiety-inducing thought until I “tic,” then do a little inventory of my stream of consciousness and backtrack to figure out what fleeting thought triggered it.  I have even had ig happen and not become aware until someone else points it out.  Other times, the same thought will be on the surface of my mind, and I am able to sit with the anxiety and control the verbal response, as though it were a compulsion I am working through.

Many of these verbal responses are well-worn negative self-image or self-hatred statements from my teenage years and acted like a release valve for my anxiety.  Some times it comes on before I am able to consciously stop it, but in time to mitigate the negativity of the response partway through.

My confusion is how the same behavior can be involuntary in one circumstance (where I am not consciously aware I have had a mental stressor at all) but controllable when I am consciously aware of the intrusive thought.  Can the exact same verbalization be *both* a tic and a compulsion under different circumstances?

Title: Are we selfish
Text: I heard today that OCD is a selfish illness. We or I only seem to be concerned about me and my problems. I understand that there are millions of people struggling with issues physically or mentally and it's not that I don't care about other but I always have my problems at the forefront of my mind. I don't want to be a selfish person it not a deliberate act, but it's really difficult to see the world as it is,  and the people in it when I have so many things spinning around in my head. 3 weeks ago I found that a work colleague of mine was being tested for bowel cancer and I couldn't help but feel sorry for them and the stress it was causing them but I also had to worry if was also suffering from bowel cancer. Within a 15 minute window of finding out I managed to turn the whole thing into my problem. I certainly never thought of this mental illness in this way before and I now worry I've become a narcissist and an attention seeker this wasn't my intention, but after being told to open up and talk about my thoughts I feel I've gone to far and people are avoiding me incase I give them another reason to roll thier eyes and depress them. I do feel as if this illness does make me a selfish person only going to places I'm comfortable only talking about things I'm comfortable with expecting people to accept my wishes while I disregard there's because it's uncomfortable for me. How can I live with OCD and not be selfish.

Title: Putting it out there
Text: I have ADHD and OCD, I would say mine isn’t completely severe or debilitating, it’s like an anxiety that I can just function while also being at the front of my mind . A try to fix, while also living with it type of OCD. Though when I was a child it was severe. As a child my socks had to be put on the right way and they had to stay that way before leaving home, or else full blown meltdowns would happen. I only liked even numbers, at one point I was saying certain words or full sentences at least twice and if not twice, four times. Nowadays it’s things like my phone which i’m going to get looked at for a dead pixel. Which brought me to this, the dead pixel might as well be microscopic, but to me it’s so bothersome. I’ve checked at least twenty times while writing this in hopes it just magically went away. It seems like it’s getting smaller but i’m so anxious that it will be there forever. Even if it does get smaller and smaller, I would still prefer the fix because I will always know it’s there.

Title: Does anyone else experience this??
Text:
I will have reoccurring loops of things I’ve done socially in the past re-surface constantly to the point where it overwhelms my brain so much I involuntarily speak out loud, “omg I want to die” because my brain becomes so full. I am so obsessive over the way others might potentially view the things I’ve said/done. 

An example would be doing something “weird” or embarrassing while around people, saying something embarrassing, e.t.c. 

Some are larger than others, but they all feel the same. And my brain immediately says “you should just die” and it’s insane. My therapist linked it to OCD symptoms and I just wanted to know if anyone’s experienced this as well and if anything helped. Around the holidays it gets so much worse bc I’m reminded of ones I’ve done/said around family and it’s very distressing. 

Edit: I don’t plan on dying, it’s just my brains reaction.

Title: I'm (20M) seeing a girl (20F) who works at a pizzeria. One of our mutual friends seems to be bothered by me, and I don’t understand why. I'm tired of sex addiction and paranoia. Should I pursue?
Text:
# Yes, my account is too new for relationship_advice.

I'm a 27-year-old guy just chatting in person with a girl (20F) who works at a pizzeria in my town’s mall. She's younger than me, but we connect over shared interests, like similar studies and favorite authors. For instance, we both appreciate Bukowski, though with mixed feelings because of his problematic behaviors. She mentioned that her ex had similar traits, which might be a sensitive area for her.

We’re both introverts, which makes me feel comfortable around her, but I’m concerned about one of our mutual friends (her other colleague), who seems to be uncomfortable with me lately. This friend, who has OCD, is aware of my past struggles with psychotic breaks, potential schizophrenia, and tendencies toward perfectionism and narcissism. I also flirted with her before I learnt she was engaged, so I immediately stopped, but I wonder if she might still feel uneasy around me because of that.

I’m new to relationships and really want to handle this situation thoughtfully and in a way that avoids any unhealthy dynamics or codependency/abusive relationships. How can I approach things with this new girl, being mindful of my own OCD episodes, schizophrenia OCD and OCPD with and with the tension with our mutual friend?

Title: Starting Luvox
Text:
After taking Prozac for 3 years my new psychiatrist and I agreed that I'm experiencing "SSRI poop out" (her words not mine lol). Prozac gave me my life back but this past year has been especially hard on me. It just stopped feeling less effective even on 80mg.

My crippling fear and subsequent obsessions of having schizophrenia has returned. My psychiatrist has reassured me I'm fine but my anxiety/OCD has me believing otherwise. I want to feel normal again and I heard Luvox can do that for me. 

I'm cross tapering off of Prozac and starting off on a low dose of Luvox. I'm really scared because starting Prozac was a rough journey but eventually I felt better.

If anyone has some success stories about Luvox or advice of switching medications I'd really appreciate! 

TLDR; I'm switching from Prozac to Luvox and I'm terrified. Any success stories or advice?

Title: How do I tell my Dad that it’s really insensitive and hurtful to joke about my ocd without making him angry?
Text: He has really been at with jokes like “wHy dONt yOU cUT oFf yOuR hANdS tHEn yOU wONt have tO WoRry aBoUt WaShing ThEM” or “tHerEs GoInG tO bE NoTHiNg lEfT BuT BOneS iF yOu KeEp DOiNg ThaT”. Those kind of jokes really upset me and I don’t think he understands that OCD is one of the worst mental disorders that I would not even wish upon my worst enemy. That kind immature behavior really causes me a lot of stress and really worsens my symptoms. I also hate how he down plays it and thinks it’s just people afraid germs or that they can easily stop doing that kind of behavior. The reality is most people who suffer from OCD have an uncontrollable urge to do something or else their mind tells them something bad is going to happen if they don’t do it. People can’t easily recover from it and it takes really long time to work your way out of it. I want him to know this is no laughing matter and that if he were joking about in a public place a lot of people would be disgusted by that kind of behavior. If you have any good suggestions that would help it would be greatly appreciated. Thank you!

Title: Pedophilia/Incest intrusive thoughts making feel like a monster.
Text:
I've had a lot of problems with intrusive thoughts in general, but especially about children and family. These disgust me and they aren't anything I ever want to act on. They just show up and I go from hanging out with my family or playing with a kid to suddenly spiraling about how terrible of a person I am. Everything is just normal then a little switch somewhere gets flipped and the thought crosses my mind. I only think the thought once, just a little blip, then I'm stuck thinking about why I thought it. It's part of the reason I stopped working with kids despite being very good at it and again never ever acting on or wanting these thoughts in any way. 

I hate even saying this, I hate writing it down. I know it doesn't make me a pedophile or a predator and that this is mental illness. These are just thoughts and not feelings, thoughts can't be wrong, nor can they be controlled. Still I'm sure 99% of people wouldn't understand or agree. In most people's minds I'm a monster. The difference between pedophilic thoughts and pedophilia for most is zero. This isn't something I can tell anyone in real life. I've never told a therapist, not that I'm seeing one currently. It's to shameful and disgusting and I'm terrified they'll write it down and then it will be in my records and then it's out there. My other doctor's might see it. Is there any way to make this stop?

Title: How has Nihilism interacted with your OCD?
Text:
Having a more nihilistic outlook on life has improved things with my anxiety and gotten me almost out of the OCD rut I've been in for the past year. When my obsessions gets really bad, it helps to remember how small my life is, even on a planetary scale, that I'm just one person out of literally billions. The things that matter to me and terrify me, and that I spend countless hours trying desperately to control and manage, will end with me when I die (or sooner, if I can fully recover) my memory will end when the people who knew me also die. And none of these things matter, I mean, not really, not any more than anything else that humans experience matters. This nihilistic outlook isn't comforting at all when I'm feeling ok, but in an OCD spiral its totally saved me. Whenever I think in these terms, I feel the anxiety inside me sputter and die and it's amazing. And then I can move on to secondary coping strategies (showing compassion for myself and others, radical acceptance, grounding)

When I searched nihilism in this sub, though, some people have a theme for this : ( OCD really can latch onto anything, I'm so sorry for people with this theme! Cause when my comorbid depression gets bad, the nihilism is fucking terrible. And I imagine it's a bit like that.

Title: OCD and morally grey characters
Text: i am a teenager with autism and severe OCD. my autism tends to make me very attached to certain fictional sources or characters, sometimes for months or years on end. it can become very overwhelming. as i’ve gotten older, i’ve started to digest more media with morally grey characters or plot lines (ex game of thrones) and it can sometimes throw my OCD into a spiral, because i enjoy certain characters, maybe more than most, and then i feel like an awful person for enjoying them. sometimes ill look for reassurance online and see if other people like or defend those characters, but then i just feel worse, because some people don’t, for valid reasons, and i get upset all over again. this is probably one of the silliest themes of my OCD, but it doesn’t make dealing with it any easier. has this every happened to anyone else???

Title: Please read this
Text:
Hello everyone! I'm 17 years old and I've been suffering with ocd ever since I was around 13 or 14. Recently I've been implementing tactics into my life to overcome these thoughts.. previously I wouldn't have been able to post this out of fear of judgement or other unreasonable thoughts but since I've thought about ocd from a different perspective it feels almost as if I'm finally broken out of a vicious cycle and the chains are finally broken. Anyways although I'm not fully cured I wanted to share some things that could help you:) 
1. Ocd is not real. Look.. I know that ocd is a real condition, and it has neurological affects most definitely but I am more so focusing on the thoughts. I want you to close your eyes and think about this. Think about all of the time you have lived life before you started letting ocd into it, everything seemed amazing, so free, almost like there wasn't a care in the world emotionally when it came to intrusive thoughts and other things associated with ocd.. so what has changed?? Absolutely nothing. Your life is and still can be the same as before as long as you can remember back to those times and whenever thoughts come up just directly tell them "you are not real. You cannot hurt me. You will not hurt me. You have came into my life to try and ruin it but I am stronger. I will not resist to these unreasonable thoughts as it has absolutely zero impact on my actual day to day life. 

2. Reading
Reading self help books, positivity books, or any kind of book that you enjoy reading can help calm you immensely. I was never much of a reader until a few months ago.. I had some birthday money and I thought instead of buying the usual stupid stuff that I like to buy that will give me temporary joy, why not just give it a go and buy a few books, I was surprised by how engaging it made me feel and overall how it improved my life. It can also strengthen your knowledge and mental strength making you naturally more resilient to ocd. I know it might sound kind of weird but it's important to atleast try it! Try to make sure it's books about complex or insightful topics though as Reading something like the diary of a wimpy kid will not really help lol. If anybody is at all curious what books I've been reading they are Atomic Habits by James Clear, and the 48 laws of power by Robert Greene, both of which are fantastic books and though aren't directly related to ocd implement thoughts and tactics that can change your perception on it. 

3. Simply pushing through
One of the problems I had was ignoring daily tasks such as cleaning, going out with friends, and other things as my ocd would take over and essentially make it very difficult to simply get up and do these things for example I worried that if I moved a box out of my room that something bad would happen.. but guess what it didn't surprise surprise haha. It felt that way for a few hours but you know what I did for those few hours? Went on a walk and listened to some music, then came home and took a nice long shower, by simply ignoring those thoughts.. no matter how hard it seems to be they will go away on their own and you can look back and see that it was false and be happy you decided to do so. Think of it like this, imagine you are attempting to lose weight and you see a cupcake, you want to resist and eat it but you know you will regret it later.. so you decide not to eat and and later on you feel happy about not giving in. The cupcake is your thoughts, and not giving into the temptation will greatly improve your life and overall well being. 

Well. That's about it. I have some more things but it would involve many more pages lol. So please let me know if this helps anyone at all. That's all have a blessed day everyone❤️

Title: Old theme
Text: I still feel like my old theme is real even though I've moved on to others. I wonder if I'm still doing compulsions for the old one. Or if my current is going together with my old one.

Title: OCD and piercing symmetry
Text:
I have a bunch of facial piercings and recently the symmetry has been bothering me( I’ve calmed down a lot but I feel like I’m going to freak out again at some point). 
I feel if my piercings aren’t perfectly in the center “everything “ is ruined. My Medusa (upper lip piercing) isn’t centered in the cupids bow, but just ever so slightly, my partner and friends are half and half: it’s perfectly in the center or it’s just slightly off. I go through phases of “it’s fine” and then meltdowns about how it’s ruined and my face is ruined. I was so worried about symmetry I had my second nostril repierced and then eventually removed. I’m debating taking out my tongue piercing because it’s at a slant, something no one else can see unless I point it out.

I just hate the constant swirl of “I look so good with my piercings” to “it’s off and everyone can tell it’s off, it’s permanent and it’s not right”

Title: Does anyone act out on intrusive thoughts during their sleep?
Text: I will be barely conscious to remember but a few times now I have acted on my intrusive thoughts while sleeping. I will be having a dream about acting out on them and next minute I'm actually acting on them! slapping my face really hard or pulling my hair out or something self destructive IN REAL LIFE. This honestly scares me so much. But I swear on my life I don't mean to. Id never do that if I was conscious. I feel like I'm alone here and I don't know what to do. My OCD is generally quite controlled during the day...it's just at night this is a problem.

Title: I have ablotutely no motivation left. Everything i do makes me feel horrible
Text: I've had my fair share of depressive episodes in my life but nothing like what my life has come to now. No matter what I do, everything makes me feel completely exhausted. All I want to do is sleep but I can't even enjoy that anymore. I've completely given up on school. I can't go there for more than once a week. I've been faking being sick or lying about having days off at school for months now because otherwise my parents won't let me stay home. They don't care about my mental health. I couldn't care less about my grades or the fuckers at school that treat me like I'm some kinda alien. I haven't done any crafts in months even tho I used to be a really artistic person because I just can't find the motivation for it. Why should I practice art it's not like I'm gonna be able to become an artist like I always wanted to. I hate everything about myself. Looking at myself in the mirror makes me want to die. I started cutting myself but I can't even do that anymore because I'm too fucking lazy. I lie in bed until 5am not being able to sleep because my head is flooded with thoughts about how pathetic my life is. I feel absolutely disgusting cause i don't have the energy to clean myself regularly. I want to rip my whole skin off my body and bleed to death that's how uncomfortable i am in my own body. I haven't been cleaning my room enought now i'm paranoid about bugs being everywhere. Everything is making me feel so fucking disgusting and uncomfortable but i just can't seem to change that. It takes too much effort. I have no one to talk to I guess nobody seems to care about my well being even tho I'm showing obvious signs of mental illness. My only way of venting and letting my thoughts out is reddit but for some fucking reason all my posts on r/suicidewatch, r/mentalhealth and r/depression are getting deleted. That's why I'm either here or on r/autism. So i'm sorry if this isn't really related to ocd

Title: Why does posting something and getting no upvotes feel so embarrassing lol

Title: This feels so goddamn real (POCD)
Text:
I literally don’t know how much more I can take this

It’s been a good amount of time since I was exposed to children at least in person so I was getting a bit better and feeling more confident but then I went to the aquarium with my girlfriend today, pretty normal, and it was rough.

Every damn child I had to check up and down to see if I was attracted. And for the ones that were wearing stuff like tight pants/leggings/yoga pants that allowed me to see the outline of their body it felt like I wanted to die. Because of like 7 years straight of watching porn so many simple things like specific pants have become triggers.

I saw a girl with her mother and her mother happened to have attractive features and of course the first thing my mind went to was “that’s where the kid gets it” and I was immediately furious at myself for even having that thought.

You see what I mean, it’s just relentless because it feels so real and it doesn’t help with the CONSTANT tingling in my genital area that won’t stop and sometimes even a bit of a erection (I think).

I feel so dirty and disgusting and the hour long drive back was horrible since my girlfriend was sleeping and even with music I was alone with my thoughts. I tried to think back about what happened that day but it was only making it worse because it was feeling like I actually liked it (accompanied with more groinal responses).

I genuinely feel like a monster right now and I was having several bad thoughts about hurting myself over the course of time. I don’t think I’d ever do that but I was just getting so depressed and upset at the whole thing. God this sucks. I barely am even convinced it’s OCD anymore and it genuinely feels like pedophilia.

I can’t escape my mind. I can’t think like a normal person. I was literally feeling groinal stuff as I was crying, it’s ridiculous. Fuck whatever this is, you’ve succeeded at making me completely miserable.

Title: I'm emotionally confused.
Text:
Hi all,

I'm 23 years old. I got diagnosed with OCD around 3-4 years ago.

I was able to kind of just live with it until I started suffering multiple panic attacks shortly after my 18th birthday. I've been seeing a therapist and psychiatrist ever since.

I don't know what I want to do in life. I've been working at a fast food place for 3 years. Pay isn't great, but I don't feel particularly unhappy at the job. I don't love it, but I'm content. I understand that happiness is relative, so I do appreciate being content.

I am currently doing a workforce development program, but I don't like it. I really dislike school, and have a hard time studying and getting work done. 

I plan on finishing the program, but I just feel sad. I feel sad because school used to be one of my strong suits. I graduated with good grades and a strong gpa, and ever since I left high school, things have gone down hill academically.

I'm barely getting by in this program, and it just makes me sad that I probably will never be able to return to school and receive a bachelor's degree (already dropped out of college once). I feel insecure not having a degree, because I do believe that it is a sign of intelligence. I also get stressed because I realize that one of the few ways to have a somewhat decent life is having a college education or some type of trade, and both of those requires some degree of schooling.

I'm happy at my little fast food job, and would be happy staying there. But I feel like I need to get a degree, and I'd be dumb not to, because the path I am taking will be much more difficult.

I hope anyone who reads this understands, I'm sorry this has gone all over the place. Thank you.

Title: Need someone to talk to about fear of developing schizophrenia
Text:
Obviously I know really the only way to get over this fear is to accept the possibility I might become schizophrenic but I've just read so much on schizophrenia I manifest those same thoughts like people are out to plot or kill me,family,friends,even my dogs lol
I know 1000% I don't believe this but it's like my brain is constantly trying to convince me I do it's annoying and exhausting I spend hours everyday on google and Reddit to compare my symptoms and to see if others suffer from this I know that is probably a compulsion but it's like I really sometimes feel like I am I've seen a doctor and therapist they said also I wasn't schizophrenic but I still have a hard time believing that cause I've read so much about schizophrenia and how doctors can misdiagnose it for anxiety and etc because of insight I have a physiatrist appointment in a few weeks so maybe I'll get more answers but I need help on how to tackle this like I'm scared because I hear some people say accept the thoughts but they feel so real and I get anxious cause what if I actually believe it even though I still don't
Again I just want someone to talk to about this or someone who has maybe gone through similar stuff 
Not trying to seek reassurance

Title: SO-Ocd as a lesbian?
Text:
I’m not necessarily coming here for reassurance because I know it’s not productive. 

My OCD has been driving me crazy and I just want to feel less alone, I guess? 

I’ve been adjusting to prozac and it seems to make my OCD worse the first couple of weeks before getting better (I’m almost 2 weeks on 20mg and had the same experience on 10mg before it improved.) 

I’ve had so many theme jumps from harm to schiz-ocd, but this week seems to be kicking my a$$ more than usual. 

Backstory on my story/sexuality. I grew up in a conservative, Christian home and dated an older guy (he was 15, i was 13) when i was younger. In hindsight, i felt extremely pressured and sexualized at a pretty young age. Once coming to high school and finding fellow queer folks, I quickly ended that relationship. 

My first girlfriend was when I was 16 and I initially came out as bisexual. Since then, I’ve only had interest in dating women/non-male identifying people. Even now (at 24) I’m in a 4+ year relationship with my girlfriend who I’ve considered marrying. 

My OCD this week has hit me with “What if your sexuality was all just an act of rebellion against your parents?” “What if you’ve been faking it this whole time?” “What if your parents were right and this was all just a phase?” etc. 

SO IRRITATING! Anyway, just wanted to vent. Like I said, no need for reassurance, but I would love some tips from folks who’ve had similar experiences/themes…or even just words of encouragement from people who’ve had a similar experience adjusting to medication & things just going kinda whack at first lol.

Title: Dating Advice Please

I tend to just avoid it altogether because the rumination and obsessing over whether they like me or not just makes me feel like shit, even though I am pretty confident in my day to day life. The uncertainty is just too much to handle, even if I don’t exactly know how I feel about them. 

I would like to eventually end up in a healthy relationship but right now that just feels impossible. Looking for any advice/ tips on things that have helped those of you with similar issues

Title: Convincing myself I don’t have OCD? Because are they really “compulsions” if they’re not brought on by phobias?
Text:
I always see people talking about how they perform their compulsions because if they don’t they think their family will die, or they’ll off themselves, or hand washing for example is obviously due to germs.

Personally, I don’t really think of these things. I do a lot of things but just because I feel like I have to, in order for it to “feel right”. Light switches, touching certain body parts in certain ways, watching a half second clip of a video a million times for no apparent reason. Could this be something other than OCD? I also have body dysmorphia so those compulsions (outfit changing, mirror checking, validation etc) are sort of fear based I guess, I don’t know.

Title: I am so sick of people joking about OCD

Title: Any tips for dealing with relationship OCD during a break up?
Text:
Hello All, 

I am really struggling with OCD based on the theme of my romantic relationship. We had been together for 5 years and around 2 years in I began to have a lot of thoughts based around whether the relationship was right for me or not. This person had helped me through a lot of OCD spirals and I felt safe with them. Around year 3 my partner proposed to me which really spiked my OCD and indecision, it was a really tough time. But we remained together even though I said I wasn't ready to get married and I still had a lot of doubts but I couldn't tell if they were genuine reasons to break up or OCD. In the past year we moved countries to be closer to my family,  started new jobs, she decided to transition from male to female (which was hard but I wanted to support her through it). Two weeks ago she admitted to me that when we were traveling separately 9 months ago she cheated on me with 2 prostitutes then made up a story about being drugged and assaulted to get me to come fly to the country she was in and support her. I felt like my trust was completely betrayed and I cannot continue the relationship. She has relapsed into alcoholism and quit her job. I feel so awful and she keeps begging me to try to work through it but I don't feel like I can and OCD causing me to look back on all of our interactions the past few months and see all of the good things she is done for me causing me to question my decision and beat myself up. Any tips for how to get through this and discern real thoughts from OCD thoughts. If you read all that thank you! 

TLDR: many relationship problems, my partner cheated and lied to me and my OCD triggers me to be in a constant state of indecision and blaming myself. Need help.

Title: Camera contamination OCD
Text:
My OCD has been real bad this year, I always had it bad with checking locks and padlocks but now it has morphed into “camera contamination”. 
It’s like germ contamination but with tiny spying cameras in the place of the germs.
I feel like whenever I’m out people put tiny cameras in my hair, body, clothes, lashes, brows so that they can see what I’m doing in my phone, they can see my passcodes, where I live, etc and with those info they can go and sabotage my life. 
So everytime I have to put my iPhone passcode or look at important personal stuff I must wash the whole sofa, my hair and body and the cover i use to cover myself while I’m typing my password because I also think there are tiny hidden cameras in the apartment. It’s such a nightmare. So frustrating, so time consuming.
I’m now showering many times per day to rid my body of tiny cameras before I have to look personal stuff on my phone. I’m so scared of being sabotaged! It’s controlling my life. 
I even think that touching a surface that hasn’t been washed it’s going to contaminate my body and the cover I use on top of me to look at personal stuff with tiny cameras. 
I don’t have any germ phobia, because of wasting so much time with my ocd compulsions there are many parts of my apartment that I don’t get to clean in a timely manner that have maggots, flies and mold that bothers me but I’m not scared of getting sick or anything like that. My OCD has mostly been checking ocd and now I have this new worry driving me insane. 
I also check every rubbish item copiously before throwing it in the trash to make sure I didn’t write my passwords and important info in there, why would I even do that, but I check anyway to make sure.. but now I’m managing to give quicker glances before throwing anything out than just staying minutes there analysing every corner.. 
but the camera contamination ocd I simply can’t shake it. It petrifies me

Title: Finally got an OCD diagnosis, but now my autism is being doubted [RANT]
Text:
Not much more to add to this….all I can think is do people not understand co-morbidity ?? 

Like none of this is surprising or spur of the moment, no one has just ever listened to me the when I tell them what’s going on and provide them with detailed evidence and research. I know it seems like OCD explains everything I do, but I implore you guys to realize I’m not doubling down on wanting an autism diagnosis for fun— I just don’t want to wait YEARS (**again**) for someone— a medical professional— to listen when I talk to them.

Please, it took me long enough to accept and understand my autistic symptoms; don’t immediately retract your thoughts and try to convince me that it was this all along when I’ve spent countless hours researching, ruminating, questioning, and tracking everything about everything to be 10000% certain of this before attempting to open my trap to another living soul about this (when I’m rarely taken seriously as is). 

Autism finally explained things where my other diagnoses did not, and if anyone would’ve payed attention or respect sooner we wouldn’t even be here. 🙄

Title: How can I explain my OCD beyond the typical examples of it?
Text:
I think the layman understanding of OCD starts and ends at germs and keeping things in order, but obviously it can be much more than that.

I find it so hard to explain my OCD tendencies and thought patterns to people, I can’t put it into words well enough. I think that’s why for so long I thought I only suffered from plain anxiety.

Another layer that complicates it is the fact that I’m EMBARRASSED about what i obsess over. It makes me feel bad that I don’t worry or obsess over “important” things.

Anyone have any tips on how I can better articulate OCD? Maybe some personal examples?

Title: I have routines that I am afraid will deteriorate my health, but I cannot end these habits and I just need to vent and get some support from people with the same illness
Text:
(Quick warning: Some descriptions of habits might be unpleasant. Do not read if you are extremely sensitive.)




I have several habits that I find extremely embarrassing to talk about with people who don't have OCD. One is that I have been damaging my teeth by grinding them against each other, and no matter how many solutions I try to use, it never works. My teeth have become chipped, loose, and painful. I'm even doing it right now, it seems like I'm doing this every minute and it hurts, but I cannot stop. I have mouth guards to wear but I end up just forcing them out and continuing the grinding of two teeth, leaving me to constantly hear the snapping of them against each other and feeling ashamed. Another thing is the need to lick or taste non-edible materials. I almost always have to taste the soap used to wash my hands. I am constantly doing this with earwax, dirt, soap, and other things like sanitizer. I do not consume these in large amounts, but I feel ashamed to be doing this. I want these things to end but there really is no way to stop the involuntary urges. I just need some support, because I haven't mentioned these issues to many people in the world outside of online communication.

Title: OCD from the start?
Text: This is a throw away account. Since I reached the age of reason—around 8 or 9, or whenever that typically happens—I’ve felt compelled to tell my parents about every little thing I thought I might have done wrong or considered bad. Earlier this year, something happened (I’d rather not go into it), and it triggered a sort of “memory audit” of my past actions. At my worst, I just literately unraveled. I’ve been on many different medications; some have helped, while others haven’t. I’m 21 now and just so tired. Looking back, these thoughts have always been there, like a “dark passenger,” to quote from the show *Dexter*. They usually come up when I’m supposed to be having a good time or when I’ve just finished something stressful. Does my history suggest OCD? I've been officially diagnosed by a psychiatrist but I really can't believe that this could happen in a year.

Title: Just wanted to acknowledge again how strong you all are
Text:
I mean wow, having been through the torture of this disorder at its absolute worst to the point of hospitilization and even now as it re emerges, it's just so strong of you and I to still be here and keep fighting.

Each theme of this disorder brings its own horrors  that can last years. This isn't some trivial thing. You're so brave for putting up with what most others couldn't imagine the extent of suffering of.

Mental illness is just as much of a form of suffering as is physical. As someone also having depression (likely bipolar), autism + ADHD, and huge anxiety in general I'm pretty damn proud I fought through it all. I grew up in a fundamentalist Christian (cult) household which exacerbated and denied the OCD for most of my life and that just made it so much worse. I'm sure you all have your own environmental factors that make things so much harder. 

Meds and therapy have worked, and thankfully I know a medication that personally works very well for me that I'm getting on with this next flare up (Abilify). It's never hopeless with this disorder and just know simply you having dealt with it for so long means you're already an extremely resilient person and that your tolerance of this suffering will allow you to excel in your pursuits elsewhere. Use the brain keen to spend energy on ruminating to instead spend it on your values when it's possible. Of course, I completely understand if you're in too much distress at the moment, but I like to set myself up with activities to avoid the idle rumination time when things calm down to prepare for the future.

Again, I love you all for having such an immense spirit of endurance. Even those of you with those types of OCD who make you think you're a "horrible" person (trust me, you'll get past that too with treatment, as someone who landed in the hospital because of real event OCD and thought it was over). 

My head hurts ATM lol so I could probably benefit from a cold shower and some exercise. Wishing you all peace and happiness which no matter what you may be thinking right now, will be yours in due time ❤️💜💖
