I'm not on medication, but I haven't been able to see my therapist in about a year. She also doesn't specialise in OCD, but there are no other therapists around me who do. I don't have the resources available to me to get proper help.

For anyone older, or who has lived with it for longer, how do you keep going? Does it get better? Or do you just have to keep suffering? Is there any way I can get myself help if there is no psychiatric treatments available to me?

Title: How can I use to the debilitating feeling of overwhelming anxiety?
Text:

But how could I accept those feelings truly, because we are mastering tools at the first place to get rid of those feelings at the end?

Title: Medication is working!
Text:
I was diagnosed with OCD at 42 and realized I’d been suffering from it my whole life. It is mostly purely obsessional but I also have contamination OCD. I would spend all day every day fixating and ruminating so much that I became depressed. There was never a moment when my mind wasn’t racing with thoughts. I was getting 2-3 hours of sleep a night for years because my mind wouldn’t stop. I’ve been isolating myself for 2 years and didn’t feel like doing anything that I had enjoyed previously. My SI was rapidly increasing and became hopeless.
 My therapist finally convinced me to see a psychiatrist to get medication. He wanted to order genetic testing because I had been on 2 SSRIs in the past for anxiety and had bad side effects from both. Testing showed I cannot take any SSRIs and only 4 medications were in the green for me. So he put me on 25 mg of Pristiq. I noticed it helped my depression and anxiety a little but not the obsessive rumination or fixating. When I had my follow up he increased the Pristiq dosage to 50 mg and added a medication called Clonidine.  I began these meds on Tuesday and I haven’t been ruminating or fixating since. My mind is not racing with thoughts. It’s calm. I’ve never experienced a calm mind in my life. I don’t know which medication is the one that is helping but I’m hoping this lasts.

Title: Lexapro (escitalopram) no emotions
Text: Hi guys! My doctor prescribed me 10mg escitalopram daily but i only took half of it for a week which was a good decision i think. This medication basically works day one for me and no it’s not placebo it wiped away my anxiety and ocd almost completely but i have very bad side effects like i don’t feel anything not even happiness not a single thing like a robot i have akathisia as well and on the first days i didn’t feel thirst and hunger (still not much) like not at all i only drank water because i knew i had to. I also wanted to commit suicide because i didn’t have emotions but before i took medications i never really had such toughts which is weird i think maybe i was panicked even tho I didn’t feel panic at all and that’s why maybe. I stopped to take this medication because of these thoughts. My doctor said it’s going to be better and my emotions will return if i take for longer but a lot of people said it’s a common side effect for ssri medications and it will not really go away maybe if i took bupropion with it. My question is should i start taking it again because emotional numbness go away or should i try a different medication? My sister takes anafranil and she doesn’t have emotional numbness but she takes it for narcolepsy not for ocd tho. Sorry for my English.

Title: Mentally stuck since 8-18-24
Text:
My ocd / anxiety was triggered on 8-18 and I'm still working hard to resolve the issue that triggered it. I'm pretty much almost there with just two tasks left to do but I have to wait a week for processing time and at this point I'm exhausted. It's been like 3 weeks. One more week left and it'll be a whole month. 

On and off I've had heart racing, sweaty hot flashes, ruminating thoughts, compulsive actions, and embarrassed over the whole ordeal. I keep reassurance seeking and it makes me feel guilty and shameful. 

I even had a full blown panic attack last Sunday where I was laying on my kitchen floor and felt like my throat closed up so I was struggling to breathe and gasping for air! Finally when I calmed myself down I was just sobbing and scared. 

I'm just really really tired. I've been trying CBD to help me relax which has helped but it's not enough. I'm in therapy and idk if it's helping. She said she specializes in OCD but doesn't give me many useful tools/im already doing them and still feeling like I'm scraping by. 

I try to end my day at the end of the workday AKA at 5pm businesses close so I couldn't be working on solving my problem anyways so there was no point in worrying. But that still means I had anxiety for like 8 hours a day plus at bedtime. At bedtime I try to escape into a daydream that helps me fall asleep (ruminating gives me insomnia) but it's been hard to not ruminate when im already so mentally exhausted. 

I don't know what I'm looking for but if anyone has any advice or similar stories so I don't feel alone I think it'll help. Maybe even what I can bring up to my therapist to try and get her to understand better so I can get more help.

Title: Ocd surrounding pregnancy and STDs is causing issues for me
Text:
Earlier I went to my mom to request an appointment to be examined at the gynecologist because I'm deathly afraid of vulvar cancer caused by a hpv strand that I wasn't vaccinated against.

This is unfortunately a reoccurring thing that I go to her about at least once a month if not more. I'm also afraid of somehow getting pregnant even though it's basically impossible since I'm not sexually active nor do I ever plan to be.

Not only did my mom get upset with me for asking since there's a lot of other medical bills we have to pay, but now she's worried that I'm somehow sexually active behind her back despite never leaving the house unless its with a family member since I cannot drive.

Now I feel like I'm going to have to prove to her that I'm not sexually active. I'm not sure how she thinks I'm doing it, but I'm going to have to somehow prove it to her and I don't think I'll ever be able to prove that I'm not.

I know that this is probably my fault for going to her with my fear in the first place, but I felt like I needed to tell her. It feels like life and death to me in the moment.

So now I'm scared that I'm dying, and that I'll never prove to my mom that I'm not going behind her back lol.

Title: Contamination OCD (?) got worse
Text:
I am not sure if what I have is contamination OCD or another mental illness, but it's genuinely ruining my life and happiness.

To sum it up, I keep getting delusions that I have gotten in contact with a rabid dogs saliva, and that I will contract rabies and die. This makes me wash my hands, but guess what??? The soap looks foamy and reminds me of a foaming dog, which somehow makes me think that's what it is, and I need to wash again. This happens over, and over, and over, until I finally for some reason think it's okay now.

There is literally 0 rationality in these thoughts, but the fear is so debilitating, as because if I somehow did get in contact, I would have an 100% chance of death. I hate it so much, and my hands are so cut up and irritated from washing even moving them hurts like hell.

It doesn't help that my school has had like, I dunno, 3 animals get within the campus (the outdoor area) so that only fuels my delusional thinking and that I somehow got into contact with one. I'm currently at school typing this, and I'm probably going to wash my hands again soon.

Whenever I try to reason that it's ridiculous, the fear is either too much, or my mind creates false memories that didn't happen, making me wash.
 
Are there like meds that would calm this down??? I've never really taken pills, but I'd gladly do so if it meant this ended

Title: How to know when to check?

Title: I feel that i cant handle it anymore and im losing it
Text: Well, i have been suffering with ocd and i dont know since when, maybe 2 years, and for me when i realized that i have this problem i realized its not like everyone else, like washing hands many times or checking the door's locks or anything like this but for me is kinda related to my girlfriend, if i can explain it its like if i dont do my bed in this exact same way something bad will happen between me and my gf or like if i dont prepare my food in the exact same way and if i dont put it in the same exact plate something bad will happen between me and my gf or she will leave me or cheat on me, and this mindest i have literally with everything and its killing me inside because i know its not real but i believe in it so bad and if i do something not like i have been doing it i feel so anxious and start to wait for a terrible thing to happen between me and my gf, (i stopped playing video games, stopped going out to certain places because it reminds me bad memories with me and my gf when we had a fight or had a problem between us, i stopped cooking certain dishes because when i cooked them something bad between me and my gf went bad, i stopped using certain products, wearing certain clothes(i gave them to charity and got new ones) ) please i really need help because im too weak for this, (please dont share my story on any sort of media please respect my ask, and dont laugh at me because of what i had because i know maybe it sounds stupid for some people, please help me.

Title: OCD and work
Text: I've had OCD for years but was properly diagnosed about 4 years aho. I went to therapy but medication is the only way I'm able to function relatively "normally". When my OCD was at its worse I was not able to work or study. My daily life as a working mother was full of insane routines (my OCD concentrates on fear of making people ill, doing something wrong and hygiene) and arguments with my husband when he didn't entertain my compulsions. I was at a very low point until I finally realised I need medication. I was studying when I started medication and felt like I was doing so well and life was pretty good. Recently I've started working again and I have noticed that work-related stress has increased my intrusive thoughts a lot. Sometimes I wonder if I'm ever going to be able to have a career and work full time as I don't seem to be able to cope with any stress. I also really love my job! I want to work but I also cannot cope with these thoughts.

Title: Hasty response
Text:
I recommended a computer component to replace one I had previously suggested, having checked that the power supply would meet the needs. However, with this new component, I forgot to verify if it used the same or less energy than the previous one.

 I was a bit busy, so I just looked at the component and said it was better, and since it was the same price, I advised the person to buy it. Luckily, it uses the same amount of energy , so everything should go well, but I can't stop thinking  I was lucky in not making a mistake here .

Title: Not taken seriously

Also I feel like the so called professionals I have seen gaslight me by saying "believes she have OCD" despite young diagnosis. In fact I've got two diagnosis for it. Gosh this brain condition is awful, I'm a true fighter and I feel this is hard going even for me!

Title: Major struggles with OCD and health
Text:
I just got diagnosed with narcolepsy, and it is making my OCD go WILD. My OCD presents as intrusive, repetitive, distressing thoughts. If I read something or find something out that is pertinent to me and my OCD grabs onto it, I spiral. With narcolepsy, I recently learned that a large portion of people have difficulty differentiating between dream and reality and as a result can have false memories. This has kicked my OCD into OVERDRIVE and I am now hyperfixated and convinced that all of my memories are made up and fake. It seems that most people that experience this have sleep paralysis (which I don't) and usually it pertains to benign things, like thinking they had a conversation they didn't have. But as it does, my OCD is blowing this whole thing up and out of proportions. I have lived my whole life with the fear that I don't have a sense of reality, or I am "losing my mind", or that nothing is real. And now, here I am, with a diagnosis that might actually mean that my fears are true. This is a nightmare.

Any advice? Guidance? I'm having a huge existential crisis over here. :(

Title: Isolation
Text:
Hi not rlly sure how to explain it because Im not even sure if it is explicitly related to my OCD. Over the past week Ive just been really sad and Ive basically become nocturnal so I can avoid people but then I also know I physically could just stop this and go out in the day and ‘be normal’ but I also know when Im out in the day around people I just feel worse. 

So now I’m just really confused as to what to do because I have had these sad/lonely episodes many many times throughout my life but I don’t think I have had such extended periods/attempts where I choose to isolate myself. It’s also weird because the sadness is lowkey addictive, because when Im sad somehow im way less anxious and spend way less time on compulsions, I guess cause im occupied/tired from other shit. Idk does anyone relate and what did y’all do? Thank you.

Title: Sense of humour helps. A lot.
Text:
Spent some good time the past month just trying to find some humour regarding my compulsions. I started watching Marvelous Ms. Maisel and, despite it being a series, I just admired how she dealt with cheating, family problems with a sense of humour, and even in the middle of arguments she'd crack a joke. 

A problem I have (and I think most OCDers do as well) is taking thoughts way too seriously. It helps to think of a joke to break the cycle a little bit.

I was having an argument with my friend about something really stupid (a thing that happens while we're working together on a project) and that triggered me so hard. I need to count up to 999 from 9 when I'm having an argument and a thought just came to me where I was Count von Count from Sesame Street counting and arguing and that thought just made me burst out laughing. He was confused and then I explained it to him and I didn't have to do the compulsion (well, did it after the argument but still, this is one of the difficult ones that I haven't been able to get rid of). 

This felt... relieving. It might not work for you, but I hope this helps someone the way it helped me.

Title: How do you hold down a job?
Text:
Hey. Sorry for the long post, but I'm spiraling. 

I'm a 28 year old man who's always struggled to keep a job. For a little backstory,  I was first diagnosed with OCD about ten years ago. Though, I think I've had symptoms since I was a kid. I was going to a psychiatrist for a little while, but they have closed down a long time ago. There isn't another one in my area. I've been getting some medicine prescribed through my normal doctor, but the results have been mixed. It's made my life pretty hard. My mother, and brother also have it so I think it's genetic, but I digress.

I've had like 20 jobs over the course of 9 years. Sad, I know. I struggle to keep one for more than a few months at a time. As a result, its pretty hard to find decent work. I usually end up in fast food or retail. Which, if any of you know, fucking sucks in its own right without any OCD.

This is what always happens. I'll be fine for the first couple weeks, but slowly get worse as time goes by. At first, I don't have any obsessions or "rules" about how to do my job. I do what I'm asked to do, and everyone's happy. I'm a fast learner, and people always compliment my performance for the first little bit. 

But the longer I stay, and get more familiar with it, my OCD always creeps up. It turns into constant obsessions and compulsive behavior that cripples me. I try to hide it but it's obvious I'm doing things weird. I never tell anyone why, I just let them assume I'm stupid or something for doing things in an odd way. It eventually gets to the point that I'm in a constant state of panic all day just doing simple tasks. My performance plummets, and I end up missing a lot of work until I'm either fired, or quit because I can't do it anymore. It's embarrassing. People look at me like I'm just lazy, but in reality I'm fighting an invisible war in my head that I can't tell them about.

About 8 months ago, I actually managed to get a decent job at my local school district. It's the longest I've ever worked at one place, actually. It was going good, but the last couple of weeks have been torture. Constantly late because I can't get out of the shower in time, redoing and checking my work over and over to the point of tears, etc. The other day I was trying to fight it off, but it's gotten much worse. I'm at the point now where I don't know how much longer I can go. I'm falling into the same cycle again, pissing off my family in the process. I still live at home, too because I don't make enough to live on my own. 

I've missed a lot of work recently, and I'm worried I'm about to lose the best job I've had. My boss is nice enough, but I haven't told her what's wrong. I I know I shouldn't be, but I can't help but feel ashamed of myself. I feel like like I'm letting everyone down again. 

Does anyone else have this problem? What can I do?

TLDR: OCD has made it hard to hold down a job And I'm about to lose the only one I've been able to keep longer than a couple months.

Title: My gf labeled me a cheater for my intrusive thoughts n brings them up every argument.
Text:
Ima keep this short. 
I started having intrusive thoughts when I was 12. Usually me killing someone I love or having sexual intimacy with my siblings or parents. Very scary for a 12 year old. 

Never told anyone about them besides my sister. Spent a good chunk of my childhood allowing absolutely no one to touch me (I think that was an obsession/compulsion? Idk) 

Finally heard of ocd around 16 and became somewhat relieved I wasn’t a psychopath. 

Dated my first gf in 2022, had intrusive thoughts of cheating on her (obviously unwanted) confessed and got told I cheated on her. N have been told I cheated on her in every fight ever since. She also let her friends know my very personal thing only one other person knows about. 

Been told if I was dating anyone else they’d spit in my face if I told them about my intrusive thoughts. Tried explaining they’re literally made to be the opposite of me/what I want. She didn’t come to an understanding. 

Ever since I’ve been in therapy trying to manage. Improved my self hatred. But still even when we’re not fighting I still deal with the repercussions with the weight of the guilt n shame on my shoulders. 

Sometimes I think of offing myself to quiet it down a bit but I doubt I’ll ever have the heart to do that. Usually now I just feel a sense of numbness with a bit of a heavy heart. Perfect blend lmfao.

Title: Struggling with angry, horrifying intrusive thoughts after an obsessive true crime & doomer news binge
Text:
I've seen OCD in relation to true crime brought up here quite a lot, so I'm sure I'm not the only one affected by this. However most people I've read have intrusive thoughts about being either being a victim or even a psychopath themselves.

For me, my struggle is I keep thinking about the victims in these awful cases I've read and how terrible I feel for them and what they went through. Sometimes I get random flashbacks throughout the day remembering their photos or ruminating about some of the grisly details of the murder (I'll spare you the details but most of the cases I read through involved SA, murder, sometime torture, etc).

This lasts for at least a day or two depending on how "bad" the case was and how haunting the subject matter I read was. Then, once a particular case or victim starts to slowly fade from my mind, I get into another obsessive cycle and start reading through cases again until I can find another horrifying case for my mind to obsess about.

Does anyone else deal with something like this? I haven't been medically diagnosed yet and am not currently seeking treatment, but this has gotten to the point where it's debilitating for my life. If anyone has advice on how to handle this I would greatly appreciate.

Title: Trying to better understand OCD
Text:
I had an appointment yesterday with a psychologist who specializes in OCD regarding a potential OCD diagnosis, and I explained what has been distressing me lately and provided examples. He said what I described sounds like OCD, however I'm doubting his assessment.

I was expecting a more comprehensive assessment that also involved conducting a differential diagnosis, but I don't think he did that.

So, now I want to more clearly define what OCD actually is, because I'm not sure if I should trust him or not, and it seems like it can manifest in different ways. The main goal would be for treatment reasons - If I'm diagnosed incorrectly, then I don't know if we can treat my issues in the way that OCD issues would be treated.

I don't know how treatment can apply in situations where there is a possibility that you need to take action to address a problem from a mistake, but when I explain the situation to people, they tell me it's fine and nothing needs to be done at all. It can feel like being gaslit.

This is my understanding of OCD so far (don't take any of this explanation as fact, I'm trying to learn about the condition):

There can be only obsessions, only compulsions, or both. 

Obsessions are thoughts that cannot be easily rid of and cause distress.

Compulsions are actions performed to either ease distress from an obsession, or to avoid a negative outcome. Seems to be that, when referenced in relation to avoiding a negative outcome, the compulsions are not logical. Meaning, the behaviours involved do not realistically influence the result of a feared outcome. Unclear if this is always the case. Unclear how compulsions can manifest in relation to easing distress caused by an obsession, and if they can be defined as illogical. If a behaviour is easing worry, then is that not logical?

Have also learned that the physical structure of the brain is different in people with OCD compared to non-OCD.

Unclear if specific obsessions can last for years? 

Ego-dystonic experience seems to be referenced in two ways; in relation to intrusive thoughts which relate to Harm OCD, e.g. thoughts that you will hurt someone even if you don't want to hurt anyone. And in relation to the level of belief people have in the logic of their OCD thoughts. The DSM mentions that the level of insight sufferers experience is on a spectrum (full insight to no insight).

Unclear if OCD is only 24/7, or can be triggered and experienced in an episodic/acute way?

My experience is the latter - triggered by events that can result in an outcome I believe would be devastating. The DSM says it has to impact at least an hour of your life daily, so I don't know how I could get a diagnosis to begin with considering I have stretches where I'm fine.

My main 'theme' (not sure if I can call it a theme at this stage) would be contamination and disease/illness concerns. But it's not limited to that. I believe that any concern I have is always born from an action I took (e.g. making a mistake), or from something that happened to me. I only have one example of a time that could be classified as false OCD which caused considerable stress, and is something I am still unsure of even now. 

I seem to be more concerned than those around me about contracting disease, however I would say the measures I take to manage this are logical. It makes sense to me to not want to use baskets at grocery stores, or be wary of door handles in public toilets. 

If I feel I have been exposed to something, I spiral and catastrophize, and the incident replays in my mind, and I either; go over the situation hoping that there is something there that can prove that I was not exposed and will be fine, or, I will replay the exact moments I feel were 'damning' (the image flashes in my mind), which is also associated with a stab of anxiety in my stomach. I end up researching online looking for hope that I will be fine, but a lot of the time it can't be found because there IS a chance, even if slim (probability stops existing and I feel like I'm doomed. If there is a chance, then in my mind it is likely).

Everything I've been stressed about in this way has been dismissed by others as something I should not be bothered worrying about. Every single time. MOST OF THE TIME, this reassurance from others is enough and my anxiety is eased, but not every time. I feel very reliant on the reassurance of others, though. I often can't reassure myself, only someone else can. After receiving reassurance, I often feel the anxiety starts to dissipate and I can look back on what I was worried about and feel fine about it (but not every time).

I would really describe these moments as acute incidents that can last from a few days to a whole month. 

The level of worry during these incidents is excessive and has interfered with my quality of life at times. I've felt unable to eat or get out of bed from the anxiety and ruminating. Sometimes feeling like I don't deserve to be happy when I'm obsessing over a mistake I think could have disastrous consequences, or thinking I can't enjoy my life because my freedom is going to be taken away soon (e.g. going to jail or having to appear in court, or preparing how to live with myself if a feared consequence comes true because of a mistake I made).

This post got a bit messy towards the end. I want to discuss more with my psychologist when I see them next. Appreciate any comments or insights.

Title: "The lines from the furniture are impaling me" Has anybody heard of this?
Text:
Hi reddit! I have ABSOLUTELY no clue how to describe the psychological phenomenon I'm about to ask about so PLEASE bear with me. An acquaintance of mine (who gave me consent to post this) was having a discussion with me about her OCD and the interesting habits that come along with it, when she mentioned something super fascinating I have never heard of before.

She said that she cannot stand in certain places of a room because the "lines that come from furniture will hit her". I asked her to elaborate and she said that the "edges" or "lines" of furniture continue in space and will "hit her" if she stands in certain points of the room. I asked if it makes her uncomfortable when the lines "impale her" and she says its a subconscious thing at this point and she can almost "feel it in her temples" when there is a line "impaling" her. She also says she knows the exact position to lay in in her bed where the lines from her nightstand and dressers aren't touching her. It's not just furniture though. For example, if she had a sheet of paper in front of her on a table, it cannot be facing her directly, because the lines from the sides of it will hit her, so she has to turn the paper so it is slanted.

Could this somehow be related to her OCD? Has anybody else even heard of something like this? It's so interesting and I need answers. I have never heard of anyone else experiencing this.

Title: Has anyone else experienced this rare form of OCD?
Text:
Well, I just found out today from Chat GPT that I have a rare form of OCD called sensorimotor OCD. I always thought I was alone in my symptoms because I quite literally have never ever heard anyone else talk about having these types of thoughts in my entire life, and this is coming from someone who studied psych and is vocal about mental health. This type of OCD is rare, often undiagnosed, and still unknown to many people including mental health professionals because it’s not common. Here is a description of Sensorimotor OCD: 

Sensorimotor OCD is a type of OCD where a person becomes intensely focused on automatic bodily functions that most people don’t consciously notice. This could include things like breathing, blinking, swallowing, or even the way their body feels while sitting or standing.

Imagine that instead of these actions happening in the background, as they do for most people, your mind suddenly fixates on them. You become hyper-aware of each breath, blink, or swallow, and you can’t “un-notice” it. The more you try to ignore it, the more attention it demands. It’s like when someone tells you to think about your breathing, and suddenly you can’t stop being aware of it—but for someone with sensorimotor OCD, this heightened awareness doesn’t go away and can last for hours, days, or even longer.

People with sensorimotor OCD might feel anxiety or frustration over these sensations, as they try to get their focus off something that’s meant to be automatic. They may feel compelled to “control” these functions in some way or worry about them becoming disrupted. It’s not something they can easily turn off, and the fixation often feels intrusive, much like other OCD obsessions, which can be exhausting and distressing.

It’s different from general anxiety in that the focus is often very specific and persistent, with the mind latching onto these bodily functions in a way that disrupts daily life and feels very hard to control.

Edit: I asked you guys if you HAVE EVER EXPERIENCED THIS. THAT IS THE ONLY QUESTION I HAD. I didn’t ask to be lectured on how it’s not actually rare, how ChatGPT is terrible, etc. I asked one single question and maybe one person commenting actually answered because everyone on here is apparently an OCD expert that wants to lecture me on how common this is. Guess what— that’s what I was trying to figure out! Which is why I asked the question that not one person answered. And guess what? It DOESNT EVEN MATTER how common it is. What does that have to do with anything? Who cares if I think it’s rare vs not rare? Please get a grip & dont comment if you can’t answer the only question I asked. If me calling it rare pissed you off that much you could maybe seek some help for that too

Title: OCD scares me so much
Text:
Long post ahead, so I apologize! 

So, I think I am in a phase of harm OCD. I never experienced this before. I'm also in a state of depersonalization (which was activated by grief and physical unwellness). I have read a lot about harm OCD and now, I have a lot more questions and doubts in me. Maybe, some of you could give me some advice. 

My harm OCD latched itself onto my loved ones. It's funny to be because a month ago, I was crying just thinking about losing my parents because they are the only people that I have in my life. And now, baam, intrusive thoughts give me the absolute most vile thoughts. Combined with depersonalization, I feel like I have no control since my entire body and mind feel so foreign. It constantly makes me wonder, if my body will lose control on its own and just do these horrible things. I've been losing sleep, appetite, my heart is constantly pounding, headaches, ear pressure and I have severe anxiety (yesterday, it made me retch all day as well). I also have this sort of a brain fog, which makes me worry I'll just "snap" one day and not even realize it. It's been about a week and it's scary, because it came on so sudden.

My thoughts are mostly about either hitting myself, my loved ones, throwing something, etc. And it's like a movie in my head. And then, I feel this strange sensation in my hands and body, as if it wants to "check" if I can do this. I don't know, like grabbing an object to see if I'll throw it at someone. Or to make me say to my loved ones that I'm a danger to them. It's so hard to fight against it because it feels like a mind of its own. I've cried yesterday all day, because I was convinced I'm just a psycho, who's going to end up on TV as someone who harmed her family and then locked in jail forever. Just writing this gives me a headache. I've never had to deal with this and this feeling of "no control" spikes my anxiety so much. And then, I also worry that if I won't be as phased and worried about these thoughts anymore, that I've accepted them and will actually do them. Or that deep inside, this is some sort of a desire. I could never harm my loved ones. It's so hard to describe it. I've read that you're supposed to accept these thoughts but my god, that makes me feel like I give the thoughts a better ability to make them happen.

I don't want to go on meds, as I have horrible experience with them. Therapy isn't really a thing here. So, I'm mostly on my own. I've lost interest into my daily activities as well. It's just so crippling. My mind is active 24/7 and it's constantly making me doubt everything. Myself, my sanity, my control. How do you live with this? I feel so weak that I can't do regular activities. Is there really a way out of this? Will the depersonalization go away? I'm so scared.

Title: OCD imprints on my favourite things
Text:
Once my mind decides a certain product is bad I can’t use it anymore cause I think I might go to hell for using the product or the product might bring me bad fortune. I can’t turn off this feeling even when I know it’s wrong. 

Right now my mind has imprinted on my cream that I use daily and it keeps telling me to switch it out or something bad will happen.

Title: Mixed messages from counsellors OCD or “social anxiety”
Text:
I'm feeling so broken. I've been mentally unwell for as long as I can remember and often this is manifested in obsessively thinking about a problem, ruminating non stop to the point where I feel sick or need to confront the problem in an at times detrimental way. I sought emergency counseling at the school I'm currently at a couple months ago and one of the first things this person asked me was if I had been assessed for OCD. I hadn't. I finally found a counsellor who specializes in OCD who I met in person with recently and they think that I just have social anxiety. I was asked if I do any ritualistic things like pray or organize certain things ritualistically.... But I don't. I do ruminate non stop and am super avoidant of trauma triggers; like I won't go to my partners family dinner because I know if I do l'll obsess and ruminate about my behaviour or what I said or did for days/weeks. But this is just social anxiety? Man, idk I've been told I've have social anxiety for years... this just feels more than that.
l also will become obsessed with people/events and spend weeks/months/years (very passively and pointlessly) instagram stalking them before bed.
Like I won't be able to sleep until I spend another 30 minutes scrolling through Liam Payne content, like hold on while I for a 5th night in a row I obsessively search for the video of him falling to see if it's been leaked (I'm not a psychopath I just can't not think about it), scroll through his whole family's Instagram, search for his high school ex gf and then view every one direction members account and their ex partners... for no reason. Now that's no' social anxiety!!

Title: Numbers
Text: So I have a thing with numbers. 1 is okay, 2 is ugly, 3 is okay, 4 is terrible, 5 is good, 6 is okay, 7 is horrible, 8 is slightly better than just okay and 9 is horrible. 27 is the WORST number to me and whenever I see a post or a comment (even if I don’t agree with it) I have to like it. It’s frustrating. Can anyone relate?
